title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: Catholics Rise Everywhere But Europe
description: The number of Roman Catholics in the world rose to 1.086 billion in 2003, from 1.071 billion in 2002, with Africa registering the largest growth, 4.5 percent, the Vatican said. North and South America rose by 1.2 percent and together accounted for half of all Catholics, while Asia's numbers were up 2.2 percent. Only in Europe did the number of Catholics fail to rise, according to the new Vatican figures. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Toshiba Posts Profit
description: The Japanese electronics maker Toshiba returned to profit for the quarter ended Dec. 31 but cut its forecast for the full fiscal year because of falling semiconductor prices. Toshiba, one of Japan's biggest electronics makers, yesterday reported net profit of 1.6 billion yen ($15 million) for the period, reversing a loss of 9.2 billion yen a year earlier as sales increased 3 percent, to 1.37 trillion yen. Toshiba, however, trimmed its forecast for net profit for the year ending March 31 to 45 billion yen, from an earlier forecast of 50 billion yen, citing faster-than-expected declines in the prices of flash memory chips and other semiconductors. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEYERS, EDNA OCKO, PH.D.
description: MEYERS--Edna Ocko, Ph.D. Daughter of Isaac and Bessie Ocko, sister of Bernard Ocko, beloved wife of Sidney Meyers, died January 26, 2005 at the age of 96. Born October 8, 1908, she had a long and varied career. During her lifetime, she was a poet, a high school English teacher, a dance accompanist, a modern dancer, a dance critic, the editor of TAC Magazine, a political activist, and publicist for The Albert Einstein School of Medicine. In her fifties, she returned to college and earned a doctorate in psychology, then became a tenured professor at City College and Chief Psychologist at the Northside Center for Child Development. In addition to all that, she had time to be a loving mother and a great cook. She is survived by her son, Nicholas, his wife, Sarah, and their three children, Gabriel, Ada, and Charlotte.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cable Operators To Carry Public TV Digital Signals
description: Cable television operators including the Comcast Corporation and Time Warner have agreed to carry the digital broadcasts of all local public TV stations when conventional analog TV signals are phased out. The National Cable & Telecommunications Association, representing cable operators, and the Association of Public Television Stations said yesterday that their preliminary agreement would take effect by the time the American broadcast TV system converts fully to digital technology. No firm deadline exists for that transition, though the departing Federal Communications Commission chairman, Michael K. Powell, and some members of Congress have been pushing for one. The agreement, which is likely to get final approval within two months, would require cable operators to carry as many as four channels of each local public TV station.

Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZREICH, SIDNEY
description: SCHWARTZREICH -- Sidney. Died on January 30, 2005 at the age of 90 in Fort Lauderdale, FL. Beloved husband of the late Lillian and survived by his wife Marion. Loving father of Russell and Steven and father-in-law of Stephanie and Elaine. Loving and devoted grandfather of Eric, Paul, Ken, Jay, Lauren, Mila, Alexis, Elana and Leigh and great-grandfather of Jacob, Skyler, Lucy and Sydney. Also survived by his brother Edward and sister Blanche Klein. An attorney and early pioneer in the food service industry, for many years he was the President of the New York Produce Association and was instrumental in the building of the New York Food Distribution in Hunts Point. He was a leader in business and, more importantly, a leader in his family. He gave us all the drive to succeed and gave us the tools and support to do so. We will miss him so. Services will be held on Tuesday, February 1, 2005 at 2 PM at RiversideGordon, 6701 W. Commercial Blvd., Tamarac, FL. He will be buried with a graveside service in Greenwich, CT.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bid For Retailer Considered
description: Apax Partners Worldwide, a private equity group, said it was considering making a bid for the Woolworths Group, a British retailer that was once a subsidiary of F.W. Woolworth in the United States. Woolworths has more than 800 stores in Britain, and could be worth more than $1.5 billion, analysts said. Apax, which is based in London, said that the process was at an early stage and that a deal might not materialize. Woolworths stock rose 22 percent on the London Stock Exchange and closed at 49.50 pence a share. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Brewery Dispute
description: The Gambrinus Company, a major importer of Corona beer into the United States, has entered into arbitration to settle a dispute with the Mexican brewer Grupo Modelo over the continuation of its import license, Gambrinus said. Gambrinus, which is based in San Antonio, said that Modelo first sought unsuccessfully to buy it and then told it that its license would not be renewed after the end of 2006. Gambrinus, which is privately held, is contesting that decision before the International Court of Arbitration of the International Chamber of Commerce. Corona is the top-selling imported beer in the United States. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Auto Parts Company Acquired
description: A Mexican auto parts company, Nemak, said it would buy a German auto parts company, Rautenbach. Nemak, a division of the conglomerate Alfa, based in Monterrey, produces engine blocks and reported sales of $970 million last year. Acquiring Rautenbach will expand Nemak's operations in Europe, where it has a plant in the Czech Republic. Rautenbach, which has plants in Germany and Slovakia, makes aluminum cylinder heads and has annual sales of $175 million. The purchase price was not disclosed. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Campaign Fund Limits
description: Civic groups and public officials testified yesterday that campaign contributions by those seeking to do business with the city should be restricted, but there was little agreement on how to do it. The city's Campaign Finance Board is considering ways to curb what are known as "pay-to-play" political contributions. In written testimony to the board, Arthur Levitt, a former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said that the board should study securities-industry rules that limit contributions from municipal-bond market employees to $250. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has proposed limiting contributions to city candidates from municipal contractors to $250 and making them ineligible for public matching funds. Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: Did You Hear the One About the Drug Laws?
description: RANDY CREDICO, the stand-up comic better known as a flamboyant advocate for inmates serving sentences under the Rockefeller drug laws, hurtles along the quaint confines of Gay Street from Joe's, the coffee shop where he routinely fuels up like a Hummer at a gas pump. His destination is "the Kunstler house." He's not actually late, yet he's in a rush -- always. Recent legislation has made it possible for 446 inmates convicted under New York's drug laws, among the nation's harshest, to appeal their sentences, but that leaves roughly 15,000 prisoners still doing time for, in his opinion, too long.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Storms Restrain Expansion
description: The Philippine economy grew 0.6 percent in the fourth quarter, the slowest rate in three years, as typhoons and floods hurt the agricultural industry, but growth for the year still reached a 15-year high, the National Statistical Coordination Board said. The quarterly growth rate compared with 1.4 percent in the third quarter and 1.5 percent a year earlier. The farm sector, which accounts for about 20 percent of the nation's economy, shrank 3.8 percent in the quarter. The economy, led by a 7.3 percent expansion in the services sector, grew 6.1 percent for the year, topping the forecasts of the government and analysts. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Disputed Election Reviewed
description: A battle over a closely contested State Senate seat in Yonkers that has dragged on since Election Day continued yesterday before the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals. Lawyers for Nicholas A. Spano, the Republican who is seeking re-election to the seat, and Andrea Stewart-Cousins, a Democrat who has waged a vigorous campaign to unseat him, argued for more than an hour before the panel of seven judges, who are expected to issue a ruling in the case this week. The legal arguments centered on unresolved questions about hundreds of paper ballots in the 35th Senate District. Mr. Spano is leading by 58 votes. He has served in the State Legislature for 26 years, 18 of them in the Senate. Ms Stewart-Cousins is a Westchester County legislator. Al Baker (NYT)

title: HORMEL GETS MAKER OF MEXICAN FOODS FOR $47 MILLION
description: The Hormel Foods Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired a Mexican food maker, Arriba Foods, from the Arbor Private Investment Company for $47 million. Arriba's tortillas, salsas, seasonings and chips are sold under the Manny's, Gringo Pete's and Mexican Accent brand names, Hormel said. Last month, Hormel bought the closely held Clougherty Packing Company, which makes Farmer John pork products, for $186 million. Arbor, based in Chicago, specializes in investments in the food and beverage and related industries. Hormel is based in Austin, Minn.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Subway Fire Cause Unknown
description: More than a week after the fire that hobbled the A train and closed the C line, the cause of the blaze remains a mystery, the Fire Department said yesterday. Transit officials initially said that they thought a homeless person had inadvertently set the fire, a theory that the police later called premature. After what fire marshals called "a thorough investigation" of the Jan. 23 fire that gutted a signal relay room at the Chambers Street subway station, they have determined that there is "no conclusive information to arrive at a definitive cause for this fire." Officially, the cause of the fire will be listed as "not ascertained," a relatively rare determination. Sewell Chan (NYT)

Paid Notice: Deaths   LEFF, NAOMI
description: LEFF--Naomi. Noted interior designer died January 30, 2005 in NY City at Mt Sinai Hospital from a congenital liver disease. Born in Park Chester, the Bronx, daughter of Frank and Johanna Leff, Naomi attended the High School of Music and Art in NYC, earned a BS from Cortland State University, an MA in Sociology at the University of Wisconsin, and an MFA in Environmental Design with a minor in Architecture from Pratt Institute. Naomi began her career at JC Warnecke, designing interiors for Nieman-Marcus and Bergdorf Goodman and from 1975-80 as a senior designer at Bloomingdales. She opened her namesake firm in 1980, concentrating on retail and residential design. Leff's skills became widely admired in 1986 when she transformed the 1898 Rhinelander Mansion at Madison and 72nd into the flagship store for Polo Ralph Lauren. Other retail clients in the U.S. included Saks Fifth Avenue, Ferragamo, Gucci, Giorgio Armani, and Helena Rubenstein, and in Canada a series of stores for Holt Renfrew. In 1991 she designed Shearson Lehman American Express' 25,000 sq/ ft Saddle Ridge Conf. Center in Beaver Creek, Colorado. She designed homes, planes, and yachts for some of the most prominent bicoastal entertainment and business people of today. Naomi was truly a star among stars. Leff was given the Mayor's Award by John Lindsay for her design of youth centers in NY and won "Store of the Year" for many of her designs. In 1990 she received the Distinguished Alumni Award from Pratt Institute, joined its board in 1991 and in 2000 received its "Living Legends" award. She was also a member of the Board of Directors of the Fashion Group. In 1991 she was inducted into the Interior Design Magazine Hall of Fame. She was perennially included in Architectural Digest's listings as one of the world's 100 top designers and recently was chosen by them as one of the top 30 in the country. Leff is survived her cousins Elle Engel of Orlando, FL and Lewis Oransof Houston, TX as well as several nieces and nephews. At Naomi's request there will be a very private service. A memorial service will be arranged for early March. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to "Patient Access Fund", Development Office, Mt. Sinai Hospital, Gustave Levy Place, Box 1049, NY,NY,10029. Barbara Ashley Karen Cohen Jack Hayflick

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TRAGER, WILLIAM
description: TRAGER--William. The Rockefeller University community mourns with deep sadness the loss of our beloved colleague and friend, William Trager, a world renowned authority on parasitic diseases, insect physiology and tropical medicine who served the university with distinction for more than 70 years. A member of the US National Academy of Sciences, Dr. Trager was best known for his seminal contributions to our understanding of the malaria parasite. Dr. Trager opened the way to the cellular and molecular analysis of the malaria parasite through his breakthrough techniques for culturing the parasite in the test tube. He was a passionate collector of parasite strains and was deeply interested in genetic variation of the malaria parasite and the mechanisms that generated parasite diversity. He trained generations of parasitologists and his impact on malaria research is immeasurable. Dr. Trager loved the lab, loved doing experiments and was active at the bench into his late '80's. He was truly one of the seminal figures in malaria research of the twentieth century. He will be profoundly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Paul Nurse, President David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Russell Carson, Vice Chairman

description: A Salem man was arrested after an hourlong standoff in the State Senate chambers, where he threatened to cut his throat. House members, who had already convened, locked themselves in their chambers and continued with their business as the Senate was cleared. description: An article in The Arts on Jan. 10 about television news coverage of the tsunami in Asia included erroneous figures from Nielsen Media Research for CNN's average prime-time audience for 10 nights after the waves hit and for the increase in viewers over a similar period last year. Nielsen said last week that the average audience on the 10 nights was 1.07 million people, not 935,000. More than $80 million of improvements will be made at the plants, reducing Alcoa's earnings by $40 million after taxes this year, Alcoa said. The Federal Antimonopoly Service in Russia approved the sale last month after Alcoa agreed to keep supplying Russia's aerospace industry. The plants, about 500 miles from Moscow in Samara and Belaya Kaliva, make aluminum sheets used for beverage cans, wheels for automobiles and the fuselages and wings of airplanes.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Taiwan Semiconductor Settles Patent Suits
description: The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corporation, the world's largest custom chip maker, said yesterday that it had settled its patent and trade secret lawsuits against Semiconductor Manufacturing International, a Chinese rival. The settlement calls for Semiconductor Manufacturing to pay Taiwan Semiconductor $175 million over the next six years, and for the two companies to cross-license their patents through 2010. Taiwan also agreed not to sue Semiconductor Manufacturing for misappropriating trade secrets. No other details of the settlement were made public. In a lawsuit filed in December 2003, Taiwan Semiconductor accused the Chinese company of corporate espionage, including stealing trade secrets, and asserted that Semiconductor Manufacturing had copied some of its processes. The complaints were filed in both California and Taiwan, as well as with the United States Federal Trade Commission. Shares of Taiwan Semiconductor rose 54 cents, to $8.75. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Smith: Report of My Retirement Is Premature
One Among 10,000 Others Deformed by a Drug
description: With the recent recall of the drug Vioxx because of adverse side effects, Richard Willett's play "The Flid Show" gains an unsettling topicality. The play, first produced Off Off Broadway in 2003, traces the history of Thalidomide, the drug used to combat morning sickness and as a sleep aid that was widely distributed in Europe in the late 1950's and early 60's and caused birth defects when taken by pregnant women. Some 10,000 children were born with deformed or missing limbs, among other problems.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Bank's Profit Surges

The bank said it earned 1.06 billion reais (about $400 million) and its credit portfolio expanded 15.6 percent, to 62.8 billion reais, with most of the growth coming from retail clients and small and midsize companies. Bradesco finished the year with 184.9 billion reais in assets, a 4.5 percent increase from 2003. Todd Benson (NYT)

Brando's Ex Tells Her Story
description: Describing a tumultuous 43-year relationship, the memoirs of Tarita Teriipaia, a former wife of Marlon Brando, were published yesterday in France. Her book, "Marlon, My Love, My Suffering," described the Oscar-winning star of "The Godfather" and "On the Waterfront," who died last year, as a temperamental character cruel one minute and loving the next. "He attracted me and at the same time he scared me," she told the French press. She said, for example, that Brando had begged her to have his child and then tried to make her abort it. She decided to keep her baby boy, Teihotu, and the couple later had a daughter, Cheyenne. Over the years, said Ms. Teriipaia, left, with the actor on the set of the 1962 film "Mutiny on the Bounty," Brando distanced himself from her and his increasingly mentally disturbed daughter, and only seldom visited Tetiaroa, the island he had bought in the Tahiti atoll. Ms. Teriipaia, who is Tahitian, said that writing the book was cathartic. The publisher, XO Editions, is in discussions about translations. CAROLE CORM

description: Erbil, Iraq  OF all the remarkable things that happened at the Iraqi polls on Sunday, perhaps the most striking was pulled off by the Kurdish independence movement. From what I saw, almost everyone stopped to vote in the referendum, and the tally was running 11 to 1 in favor of independence.

But the president of the National Federation of Farmers Unions, Jean-Michel Lemtayer, said the package was "much less than what we were hoping for" and unable to resolve the worst crisis to hit the industry in decades. The French themselves are consuming less wine. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: EL PASO PAYS $211 MILLION FOR TEXAS DRILLING PROPERTIES
description: The El Paso Corporation, an owner of natural gas pipelines, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy drilling properties in East and South Texas for $211 million to revive gas production. With the purchases, which were made in two separate deals, El Paso acquired 124 billion cubic feet of proven reserves and an average of 29 million cubic feet a day of production, the company said. Bruce Connery, an El Paso spokesman, declined to provide the names of the sellers. The reserves are about 90 percent gas and 10 percent oil, he said. The purchases will increase the company's capital budget for exploration and production to $900 million from about $750 million, El Paso said. El Paso is based in Houston.

description: "Numbers," CBS's new procedural drama in which a math genius (David Krumholtz) helps his F.B.I agent brother (Rob Morrow) solve crimes, made its debut last Sunday after the American Football Conference championship game, the most-watched broadcast of this television season. So it was no surprise that "Numbers" did well, drawing 24.92 million viewers and ranking fifth in Nielsen's weekly ratings. On Friday, it made its first appearance in its regular time slot at 10 p.m. and held up well on a much quieter night for television: 15.22 million viewers watched the show, which anchored a victory for CBS in households and among 18-to-49-year-olds. In the absence of a new "Desperate Housewives" on ABC, CBS also won Sunday night with a strong performance by an original movie, "The Magic of Ordinary Days," but ABC's slate of repeats was No. 1 in the 18-to-49 demographic. title: National Briefing | Washington: N.A.A.C.P. Won't Aid Inquiry Into Tax Status
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the nation's oldest civil rights group, has said it will not cooperate with an Internal Revenue Service investigation into its tax-exempt status. Lawyers for the group called the agency's inquiry politically motivated and refused to provide copies of documents that investigators requested. After President Bush declined to attend an N.A.A.C.P. convention in July, becoming the first president since Herbert Hoover not to address the 95-year-old organization, Julian Bond, the group's chairman, sharply criticized Mr. Bush's policies on education, Iraq and the economy. Mr. Bond has said that his remarks prompted the I.R.S. to undertake an investigation into whether the criticism constituted improper partisan activity and violated the organization's tax-exempt status. John Files (NYT)

Bodman, left, by voice vote, completing a smooth trip through the Senate by a man who previously held senior positions in the Commerce and Treasury Departments. A one-time chemical engineering professor, Mr. Bodman replaces Spencer Abraham as the head of the agency responsible for a energy issues and research. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Councilman Won't Run
description: David Yassky said yesterday that he would not run for Kings County district attorney, but would instead seek re-election to the City Council. Mr. Yassky, left, a Brooklyn Democrat, had been exploring a candidacy for much of last year. He said he decided that there remained "more that I wanted to do as a member of the Council." Democratic candidates hoping to defeat the incumbent, Charles J. Hynes, include State Senator John Samson; Mark G. Peters, a former aide to Attorney General Eliot Spitzer; Paul Wooten, an election law expert; Arnie Kriss, who served as special counsel to the police commissioner; and Sandra Roper, a civil rights attorney who ran unsuccessfully against Mr. Hynes four years ago. title: A Spoonful of Sugar
description: In tomorrow's State of the Union speech, President Bush will no doubt escalate his campaign to replace Social Security with private retirement accounts. We don't know exactly what he'll say, but we're willing to bet that he won't say "private accounts," even though privatization is exactly what he's calling for, and exactly how he and other administration officials have described their scheme hundreds of times before. But the polls and focus groups that Mr. Bush says he ignores show that the public doesn't like to hear the word "private" when the topic is Social Security. So the administration now scrupulously uses the label "personal accounts," and in a 104-page book on selling the plan, it urges Congressional Republicans to do the same.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DONOVAN, MARY ANN
description: DONOVAN--Mary Ann. President and a founding member of The Neuropathy Association, died in New York on January 30. Ms. Donovan, a victim herself of peripheral neuropathy, became a spokesperson for education and research efforts of the disease. With Dr. Norman Latov, Medical Director of the Association, she authored the first informational booklet on peripheral neuropathy, an unrecognized and often misdiagnosed condition. Prior to her retirement, Ms. Donovan was a Creative Director for Wunderman Worldwide Advertising. Ms. Donovan graduated from The Brearley School and Smith College, and she was active in both alumnae associations. She is survived by three sisters, Kathy Donovan of New York, Judith Sally of Evanston, IL, and Pat McNamara of Southport, CT, one brother, John Donovan of Los Angeles, seven nephews, one niece and ten grandnieces and nephews. Funeral mass at St. Thomas More Church, 65 E. 89th St., on Thursday, February 3 at 10:30AM. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested donations to The Neuropathy Association, 60 East 42nd Street, NY, NY 10165.

description: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it had offered about $980 million to acquire Creo, a maker of software used by printers as well as digital printing and imaging systems. Daniel A. Carp, Kodak's chief executive, said that the deal would be the last of a series of acquisitions intended to improve the company's position as a supplier to the printing industry as its traditional film and photographic paper businesses decline. Kodak is based in Rochester. Shareholders of Creo, which is based in Vancouver, British Columbia, will vote on the bid on March 29. While Creo's sales rose 10 percent during its last fiscal year to reach $636 million, a group of shareholders who are dissatisfied with its stock price have been trying to oust Amos Michelson, the chief executive; on Monday the dissident shareholders said they welcomed Kodak's bid. title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: General's Case Over; Another's Begins
description: The United Nations war crimes tribunal sentenced a former Yugoslav general, Pavle Strugar, to eight years in prison for his role in the 1991 shelling of the Croatian port of Dubrovnik after Croatia declared independence from Serbian-dominated Yugoslavia. The court found that while he did not order the bombing of the city after a three-month siege, he failed to stop it "when he could have done so." He was also convicted of failing to prevent the destruction of medieval structures in Dubrovnik's Old Town, a United Nations World Heritage site since 1979. The court also opened the trial of the former chief of the Bosnia Army, Sefer Halilovic, on charges of killing Bosnian Croat civilians in 1993. He is the most senior Bosnian Muslim commander to face a trial at the tribunal. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEFF, NAOMI
description: LEFF--Naomi. We'll always remember your warmth, talent and friendship which we treasured dearly. Ruth and Bil LEFF--Naomi. Noted interior designer died January 30, 2005 in NY City at Mt Sinai Hospital from a congenital liver disease. Born in Park Chester, the Bronx, daughter of Frank and Johanna Leff, Naomi attended the High School of Music and Art in NYC, earned a BS from Cortland State University, an MA in Sociology at the University of Wisconsin, and an MFA in Environmental Design with a minor in Architecture from Pratt Institute. Naomi began her career at JC Warnecke, designing interiors for Nieman-Marcus and Bergdorf Goodman and from 1975-80 as a senior designer at Bloomingdales. She opened her namesake firm in 1980, concentrating on retail and residential design. Leff's skills became widely admired in 1986 when she transformed the 1898 Rhinelander Mansion at Madison and 72nd into the flagship store for Polo Ralph Lauren. Other retail clients in the U.S. included Saks Fifth Avenue, Ferragamo, Gucci, Giorgio Armani, and Helena Rubenstein, and in Canada a series of stores for Holt Renfrew. In 1991 she designed Shearson Lehman American Express' 25,000 sq/ ft Saddle Ridge Conf. Center in Beaver Creek, Colorado. She designed homes, planes, and yachts for some of the most prominent bicoastal entertainment and business people of today. Naomi was truly a star among stars. Leff was given the Mayor's Award by John Lindsay for her design of youth centers in NY and won "Store of the Year" for many of her designs. In 1990 she received the Distinguished Alumni Award from Pratt Institute, joined its board in 1991 and in 2000 received its "Living Legends" award. She was also a member of the Board of Directors of the Fashion Group. In 1991 she was inducted into the Interior Design Magazine Hall of Fame. She was perennially included in Architectural Digest's listings as one of the world's 100 top designers and recently was chosen by them as one of the top 30 in the country. Leff is survived her cousins Elle Engel of Orlando, FL and Lewis Oransof Houston, TX as well as several nieces and nephews. At Naomi's request there will be a very private service. A memorial service will be arranged for early March. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to "Patient Access Fund", Development Office, Mt. Sinai Hospital, Gustave Levy Place, Box 1049, NY,NY,10029. Barbara Ashley Karen Cohen Jack Hayflick LEFF--Naomi. Mourning the loss of a talented & nationally-recognized interior designer and dear friend. Zetlin & De Chiara LLP

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France Warned Over Alstom
description: The European competition commissioner, Neelie Kroes, left, said France risked court action after failing to take steps agreed to in return for approval of a state-led bailout of Alstom. The steps included opening its market for rail cars. "None of the list of measures which were supposed to be taken have been taken," a commission spokesman, Jonathan Todd, said in Brussels. France led a 4.4 billion euro ($5.7 billion) rescue of Alstom after the company was threatened with bankruptcy, jeopardizing 20,000 French jobs. Ms. Kroes has written to the French finance minister, Herv Gaymard, urging that terms of the agreement be met soon.

Throughout the years, Mr. Hagedorn was a generous and supportive friend to Hofstra and the entire Long Island community. The generosity of Horace and Amy Hagedorn, combined with a grant from New York State, enabled Hofstra to completely renovate the former federal courthouse, named Hagedorn Hall in 2003, which houses the School of Education and Allied Human Services. In tribute to the memory of Horace Hagedorn, all Hofstra University flags have been lowered to half staff. Salvatore F. Sodano Chairman, Board of Trustees Stuart Rabinowitz President Hofstra University HAGEDORN -- Horace. Project Reach Youth, Inc. salutes the life of a champion and mourns his death. We are deeply saddened that Horace Hagedorn who has given so much to our Brooklyn community has died. It was Horace and his family that fertilized a garden of fifty low-income youth and their families (Miracle Gro Kids Program) to make a college education "a promise not a dream." He did it with the power of kindness, generosity, and conviction. He truly put back into the soil what he took out. He will be truly missed. David Puth, Board Chair Mark Gibbel, Board President Robert Madison, Exec. Dir. HAGEDORN -- Horace. He brought beauty to our landscape, then enriched it with endless acts of charity. Ever frugal, never flamboyant, he favored charities whose expenses were low, to maximize the impact of his gifts. For us he was special, always testing our skills, but when he called us "friend" we knew we had done well. His memory endures in his legacy of giving and through his wonderful family who carry on his tradition of "always putting back something, not simply taking." We will miss him. The Partners of Joel E. Sammet & Co. HAGEDORN--Horace. Family and Children's Association Board Chair Daniel Brown; President and CEO Richard P. Dina; the Board of Trustees, Staff, Volunteers and Clients extend heartfelt sympathy to Amy Hagedorn and the entire Hagedorn family as we mourn the passing of Horace Hagedorn, our cherished Trustee, Benefactor, Mentor and Friend. HAGEDORN--Horace. Horace Hagedorn was an original. His dedication and commitment to children's issues was extraordinary. Our condolences to Amy and the family. The company, based in Milwaukee, made the prediction as it reported fourth-quarter results. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FIELD, JOHN W.
description: FIELD--John W., age 90, died on Sunday, January 30, 2005 in Redding, Connecticut. Mr. Field was born in Bridgeport, Connecticut on September 15, 1914. He graduated from the Hotchkiss School and Yale University where he was a member of Phi Beta Kappa. After graduation in 1937, Mr. Field joined Time Inc. as a junior news editor. During World War II, he served as a war correspondent for Life magazine and later as war editor. He was National Affairs Editor of Life in 1947 when he left to join the Warner Brothers Company now Warnaco. Mr. Field was elected President in 1957, Chief Executive in 1958 and Chairman in 1973. During his years there, the company grew to become a diversified publicly held apparel company with brands such as Warner's, White Stag, Hathaway, Speedo and many others. He retired in 1979 and remained on the board until the company was sold in 1986. Before and after his retirement Mr. Field was a trustee of Colby College in Waterville, Maine, chairman of the board of the University of Bridgeport and chairman of Fairfield Country Day School. He was on the board of the Connecticut National Bank and its successor, the Hartford National Bank (both now Bank of America). He served on the board of the Bridgeport Hospital, the Fairfield Red Cross and the International Silver Company (later Insilco). Returning to writing after his retirement, he wrote and had published "Rendezvous With Destiny", a history of his generation told through the experiences of his Yale 1937 classmates. For this work he received the Yale Medal, the highest honor Yale gives for service to the University. Mr. Field was a member of the Country Club of Fairfield, where he was also President, and a former member of the Pequot Yacht Club, the Aspetuck Fish and Game Club, the Fairfield County Hunt Club and the Yale Club of New York City. Mr. Field's wife, Priscilla, died in February 2003 after 64 years of marriage. He is survived by their daughter, Margaret W. Field of Warren, CT, sons, John W. Field, Jr. and his wife Elizabeth of Greenville, DE and David W. Field and his wife Victoria of Chapel Hill, NC, six grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held 11:00 AM on Friday, February 4, 2005 at Trinity Episcopal Church, Southport, CT. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to Trinity Episcopal Church, 651 Pequot Ave., Southport, CT 06890.

title: UNITED'S MECHANICS SAY THEY WON'T STRIKE DURING TALKS
description: The mechanics' union at United Airlines said yesterday that it would not strike while talks continue on wage and benefit cuts. The Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal Association threatened walkouts, which the airline contends would be illegal, if a federal bankruptcy court set aside its contract. Mechanics at the airline rejected an agreement last week that would have called for $96 million in cuts, part of the $725 million in union concessions sought by the airline, which is in bankruptcy protection. Judge Eugene R. Wedoff of the United States Bankruptcy Court in Chicago imposed a temporary pay cut of 9.8 percent for mechanics on Monday, and reduced their sick time, but gave the two sides four months to come up with a new agreement. Pilots and flight attendants have already agreed to cuts in wages and benefits. United, a unit of the UAL Corporation, is based in Chicago. Micheline Maynard (NYT)

The Knights have not endorsed the position taken by some other coalition members, that same-sex marriage would promote pedophilia, pornography and unprotected sex.

title: GLAXO TRIES TO BLOCK GENERIC VERSION OF DIABETES DRUG
description: GlaxoSmithKline, the drug company, filed a lawsuit to block Teva Pharmaceutical Industries from selling a generic version of Avandamet, Glaxo's diabetes treatment. Teva is seeking Food and Drug Administration approval to sell a low-cost version of the drug, which combines Glaxo's diabetes drug, Avandia, with metformin, a generic diabetes drug. Glaxo's combined United States sales of Avandia and Avandamet were $1.15 billion in the first nine months of last year. Glaxo, based in Brentford, England, contends that two patents on Avandamet protect it from generic competition until 2015. Teva, based in Israel, did not return a phone call seeking comment.

The bank said that it was cooperating with the investigation. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Date Set For Elections
description: The government scheduled elections to Parliament for March 31, but it remained unclear whether the sole opposition party of note, the Movement for Democratic Change, would participate. Zimbabwe and its neighbors endorsed guidelines for democratic elections in the region last year, but the opposition party has said it would not campaign until President Robert G. Mugabe's authoritarian government adheres to the rules, something critics say is unlikely. Mr. Mugabe's party, Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front, or Zanu-PF, which has governed uninterrupted since 1980, appears likely to dominate the vote, in which 120 of the Parliament's 150 seats will be contested. Michael Wines (NYT)

description: On Monday, just in time for Chinese New Year, Anita Lo and Kenny Lao are opening Rickshaw Dumpling Bar, a sleek place for inventive steamed and fried dumplings at 61 West 23rd Street, (212)924-9220. Six varieties, including the fried Peking duck dumplings above, are $4.95 for six, $6.95 for nine, steamed or fried. For $3 more you can pair them with a noodle soup or salad. Eat them at a 16-foot counter or at banquettes and small tables in the shimmery sea-blue and deep taupe room, the work of Hiromi Tsuruda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHICK, HILDA
description: SHICK--Hilda, nee Lind, died peacefully on January 29, 2005. Loving wife of the late Simon L. Shick, M.D. Mother of Linda Aaronson, Elizabeth (Joseph) Sorstein and the late William Michael Shick. Grandmother of Eric Aaronson, Diana Clarke, Caroline and Emily Sorstein. Revered aunt, great-aunt and devoted friend. Raised in Savannah, Hilda was an educated and independent woman before her time, earning her B.S. at University of Georgia & M.S. at Columbia. Her drive and tenacity were legend to all who knew her. She cared selflessly for those close to her. She will be greatly missed.

title: Bumper Crops for the Eye
description: SALINAS, Calif. - Out of the fertile fields of the Salinas Valley, the giant figures loom: 18-foot-high plywood workers harvest iceberg lettuce. An irrigator, his boot on a shovel, surveys the land. A farmer crouches nearby, his hand cupping the loamy soil. Women in headscarves thin just-budding crops. The creases in their shirts, their bodily expressions, even with their backs turned, these figures are so lifelike that their appearance startles passers-by, which is what their creator, the artist John Cerney, intends.

His tender and thoughtful nature will be greatly missed. We extend our sincere sympathy to his wife, Sharon, daughter Beth Eifert and son Bill Heissenbuttel, and his beloved grandchildren. Eric A. title: Arts, Briefly; Cuts at Boston Ballet
description: The Boston Ballet has cut the salaries of nearly all its nonunionized employees to balance its budget after revenue from its annual production of "The Nutcracker" was lower than expected. The ballet started its cuts at the beginning of January, said its executive director, Valerie Wilder. Ninety to 100 employees were affected, she said. The cuts are graduated according to pay scale, she said, with senior management bearing the brunt. Full salaries will be restored at the beginning of the new fiscal year in July, she said, and no one will lose a job. Ms. Wilder said that there are other unspecified cost-cutting measures and that the company is exploring ways to have unionized labor, including dancers, help pare expenses. KATIE ZEZIMA

description: Interior Minister Dominique de Villepin told Parliament that he would ask the government to support a proposal to disband all neo-Nazi organizations. He said it would be in accordance with a 1936 law authorizing the dissolution of associations seen as a threat to public order and democracy. While just 3,000 people are believed to belong to neo-Nazi groups across France, such groups were responsible for 65 acts of violence in 2004, against 27 such acts in 2003, he said. title: The Costly Right to Know

This huge tab, presented to the People for the American Way Foundation, is well beyond established criteria and amounts to an insult to the law's intent: letting citizens in on some of the murkier things the government may be up to.

Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fire Engine Staffing Restored
description: The Fire Department is restoring staff levels at 49 engine crews to five firefighters each, two months after invoking a contract provision that allowed it to reduce the number of firefighters at each company to four, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. The change follows criticism by the firefighters union that smaller crews, which save the city money, posed a danger to firefighters and the public. But Mr. Bloomberg said the decision was made because fewer firefighters are on sick leave. Under the contract with the union, the city can remove the fifth firefighter if more than 7.5 percent of city firefighters are on medical leave. The mayor said the percentage has fallen below that threshold. Mike McIntire (NYT)

BRIGGS & STRATTON BUYS MURRAY, MAKER OF LAWN MOWERS
description: The Briggs & Stratton Corporation, the world's biggest maker of gasoline-powered engines used in lawn and garden equipment, won a judge's approval to buy almost all of the assets of Murray, a bankrupt lawn mower maker, for $125 million. Judge Marian F. Harrison of United States Bankruptcy Court approved the sale on Monday at a hearing in Nashville, according to Murray's lawyer, Paul G. Jennings. Objections to the sale by Murray customers were resolved during the proceeding, Mr. Jennings said. The closely held Murray, based in Brentwood, Tenn., has about 1,400 employees and makes lawn mowers, snow blowers, go-carts and hand-held power equipment like hedge trimmers. Briggs & Stratton is based in Wauwatosa, Wis.

Margaret Kyle, the pastry chef, also does delicious things with frozen white chocolate and raspberries, Mexican chocolate with dulce de leche, and chocolate pastry with pears. description: Skanska, a construction company based in Sweden, said it fired the head of its construction unit in the United States after it posted unacceptable results for last year. The executive, Mike Healy, was dismissed after escalating costs on a United States government contract forced the company to absorb a charge of 410 million kronor ($59 million), the company said yesterday. Mr. Healy, who leaves immediately, joined the company in 1990. He will be succeeded temporarily by Johan Karlstroem, an executive vice president who had been in overall charge of Skanska's United States operations, the company said. A permanent successor is being sought. Skanska is based in Stockholm. It's construction division in the United States is based in Parsippany, N.J.

title: Buying Literary Treasures
description: The National Library of Scotland in Edinburgh has received $33.5 million in the British government's latest round of Heritage Lottery Fund Awards to help it buy the John Murray Archive, including more than 150,000 letters and manuscripts from writers like Jane Austen, Charles Darwin, right, J.M. Barrie, William Wordsworth and Lord Byron. The archive, spanning 1768 to 1920, was created by John Murray, who founded a publishing house in Edinburgh in 1768. It had been valued at $85 million, but was offered to the National Library of Scotland for $59 million to keep it in Britain. The library, which will also receive money from the Scottish Executive, must raise an additional $12.2 million toward the final price. PAM KENT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARNWELL, WILLIAM J., KNOWN TO ALL AS ''JIM,''
description: BARNWELL -- William J., known to all as "Jim," died on February 1 after a brief illness. He was 86 and had lived in Rye for the past 22 years. Jim retired in 1989 as a NY State Parole Board Commissioner. He graduated from Fordham University with a BA in 1940, later earning a Master's in Social Work. As an undergraduate he was the sports editor for the Fordham newspaper and later became a "stringer" for the New York Times, covering subjects from religious services to college sports. He served in the US Army during WWII. Jim was a kind, gentle man with the great Irish gift of wit. He enjoyed tennis into his early 80's. Mr. Barnwell was married to Elizabeth Griffin in 1953. She predeceased him as did his daughter Carolyn. He is survived by his children Elizabeth B. Boucher of Rye, NY and Nicholas J. Barnwell of Harrison, NY, as well as four grandchildren. Family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home in Rye from 24 and 7-9 on Friday February 4th. Funeral mass will be held at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye, NY at 10AM on Saturday, February 5th.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Basque Leader Calls Early Elections
description: The president of Spain's semiautonomous Basque region, Juan Jos Ibarretxe, announced that he would dissolve the region's parliament at the end of the month and hold elections on April 17 for a new one. The announcement came a day after the national Parliament in Madrid rejected his plan for a new relationship with the central government, in which the Basque region claims the right to break away. Mr. Ibarretxe said the elections would not take the place of the popular referendum he intended to hold on his plan. Instead, they will "serve to transmit the clamor that exists in the Basque society" for negotiations with Madrid over the region's ties with it, he said. Renwick McLean (NYT)

From 1981 until 1985 Ms. Carlson was the Director of Corporate Programs for Catalyst, the leading research and advisory organization devoted to expanding opportunities for women in the workforce. "There's one standard frame, like a Barbie doll, but you must dress it," Mr. Boontje said. "Without a cover, it looks naked." Little Flowers Falling, a swath of laser-cut Ultrasuede also designed by Mr. Boontje, is pictured here as a throw draped over the Doll chair and can also be used as a screen or wall hanging. It comes in red, orange, black or beige and sells for $630. Both products will be shown -- and sold -- at Moss, 152 Greene Street (corner of Houston Street), beginning Feb. 9, as part of a yearlong, citywide celebration of Dutch design that began last month.

The judge, Sue L. Robinson, had been asked to reconsider the matter by Medtronic. The infringement question will be taken up at the same time as Medtronic's claim that Guidant's patent is invalid. title: Arts, Briefly; More Accolades for Usher
description: Usher, whose album "Confessions" sold more than eight million copies to become last year's best seller, has earned a leading five nominations for the 19th Annual Soul Train Music Awards. The nominations, announced on Tuesday, included those for best male R&B-soul album for "Confessions," best male R&B-soul single for "Confessions Part II" and his duet with Alicia Keys ("My Boo," which earned Ms. Keys a nomination as well). title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Couple Killed In Robbery Attempt
description: A couple who owned a jewelry store were shot and killed yesterday evening during a robbery attempt, the Fairfield police said. Timothy and Kimberly Ann Donnelly, both 52, were shot multiple times in their store at 1438 Post Road just before 6 p.m. Mr. Donnelly died at the scene, and Mrs. Donnelly died at Bridgeport Hospital. It was unknown last night what was stolen, said Detective Sgt. Gene Palazzolo. The police said witnesses described the suspect as a white man with a stocky build, in his 20's, with curly hair and driving a dark sport-utility vehicle. Detectives from Rockland and Nassau Counties in New York rushed to Fairfield last night to investigate whether there was a link to robberies in those counties. In December, a clerk at a jewelry store in Glen Head, on Long Island, was shot and killed during a robbery. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Dismantle Colombia's Paramilitaries
description: In 2003, the Colombian government offered right-wing paramilitary leaders worried about extradition to the United States a sweet deal: pay a fine and do no time. After a public outcry, the government improved the proposal: members of paramilitaries, including major drug traffickers and mass murderers, could put down their guns in exchange for very little jail time. They could keep their war booty and would not have to cooperate with investigators. They could continue as criminal mafias, undisturbed. The United States ambassador in Colombia publicly supported both proposals. Thankfully, other nations that donate to Colombia's peace process did not, and the plan was scrapped.

title: The World in a Bowl From Tokyo to Midtown
description: The boutique at the Cornelia Day Resort, a Midtown beauty spa opening on Monday, will sell a range of housewares produced by artisans, including the hand-painted glass bowls above by Kumiko Hayashi. Ms. Hayashi, who lives near Tokyo, designs the glassware, which is made by Japanese factories and then sent to her studio. There she etches, paints and fires the pieces in her kilns. The bowls range in size from 2 inches to 10 1/2 inches in diameter, and in price from $65 to $825. The spa is at 663 Fifth Avenue (52nd Street). Information: (212)871-3050.

title: An Improvising Conductor Celebrates an Anniversary
description: When you do something for 20 years, an elegance and economy of motion set in; you cut more quickly to the point. In a jazz group, with a musician leading the band, the point is the freedom of all the group's individual players, atop the consensual boundaries of a tune and the tailored group sound. In conducting classical music, the point is the written work filtered through the conductor: his temperament, his tempos, his interpretation of the score.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Summit Meeting Canceled Over Security Concerns
description: A meeting of South Asian prime ministers scheduled for next week was indefinitely postponed after India said it would not attend because of turmoil in the region. Citing both turmoil in Nepal and a deteriorating security situation in Bangladesh, where the meeting was to be held, India's foreign secretary, Shyam Saran, said Prime Minister Manmohan Singh would not take part. On Tuesday, King Gyanendra dismissed Nepal's government, imposed a state of emergency and curtailed constitutional guarantees, including the right of assembly. Rights groups said they had reports of media censorship and of a substantial number of arrests. The king had announced that he would attend the summit meeting in place of the prime minister he had just fired, and India clearly intended to send strong messages not only to Nepal, but also to Bangladesh, plagued by increasing lawlessness and political violence. Last week, a former finance minister was killed in a grenade attack. Indian officials said there were concerns about how safe Mr. Singh would be in Dhaka. On Tuesday, several bombs were thrown in Dhaka, including one at the hotel where Mr. Singh and the other leaders were to stay. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Mr. Bush's Two Big Ideas
description: The State of the Union speech has come in recent years to be a laundry list of everything the president would do if he had the power to do everything. Bill Clinton was a particular fan of that approach, and polls have always shown that Americans like it. Last night, George W. Bush delivered a modified version, with a raft of initiatives that included some things new but a great deal that was very familiar. We were pleased to hear the call for better defense in death-penalty cases and more community health centers in poor areas, and the mention of $350 million in aid for Palestinians to promote the peace process with Israel. But we were disheartened by the renewed call for a constitutional amendment banning gay marriage and the failure to mention development aid to Africa or virtually any other country that is not identified as a prime source of terrorism.

description: ROME, Feb. 2 - Pope John Paul II was stable and working from his hospital bed on Wednesday, the Vatican said, after a scare that again raised questions about his failing health and the succession of leadership in the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Arts, Briefly; Tsunami Jokers Fired
description: Under intense pressure from protests, Hot 97 (WQHT-FM) has fired its morning-show producer, Rick Delgado, and a cast member, Todd Lynn, over a tsunami parody song. Referring to the station's parent company, Emmis Communications, a statement on Hot 97's Web site, www.Hot97.com, reads, "An internal investigation by Hot 97 and Emmis determined that the singularly egregious actions of Lynn and Delgado warranted termination from their employment at the station." Mr. Delgado wrote and produced "The Tsunami Song," which included racial epithets and lyrics that mocked the victims of the Asian tsunami. On the air Mr. Lynn threatened to begin "shooting Asians." Miss Jones, star of the morning show, as well as DJ Envy and a production assistant, have been suspended without pay for two weeks. The City Councilman John C. Liu, a Queens Democrat, is not satisfied. He is calling for Miss Jones's dismissal. Mr. Liu is also asking that the $1 million pledge made by Emmis to Give2Asia, a Tsunami aid organization, be increased to $10 million. Mr. Delgado is no stranger to controversy. He was a producer for the Opie & Anthony show, which ended on WNEW-FM after a 2002 scandal created when a couple called the show to say they were having sex in St. Patrick's Cathedral. LOLA OGUNNAIKE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLAY, HENRY JONES
description: CLAY--Henry Jones. Prominent New York City attorney, died January 26 in Greenwich, Ct, age 89. He was the son of George H. and Amelia Jones Clay. He attended the Taft School, Union College and the University of Virginia Law School. He served as a U.S. Naval Reserve Commander during World War II. He was a partner of the law firms DeWitt Lockman & DeWitt and Abberley Kooiman Marcellino & Clay where he practiced law until his retirement. He was Assistant Attorney General of the State of New York from 1948 to 1950 and subsequently Chairman of the U.S. Foreign Claims Settlement Commission during the Eisenhower administration. An ardent squash and tennis player, backgammon player, and toastmaster, he was a man of many interests -- sports, game shooting, hunting, needlepoint and collecting Oriental carpets. He was a member of the Wyandanch Club and Piping Rock Club on Long Island, and the Brook and the Union Club in New York City, were he served as President from 1983 to 1988. He is survived by his children Marcia Clay Hamilton of Greenwich, CT.; Henry Jones Clay, Jr. of New York City, and Jonathan Clay of Maui, Hawaii; two granddaughters Alexandra and Clay Hamilton; two grandsons Benjamin Jones Clay and William Scudder Clay; and a sister Dorothy Hogg. Burial will be private.

title: VALEANT TO BUY XCEL PHARMACEUTICALS FOR $280 MILLION
description: Valeant Pharmaceuticals, which makes medicines for cardiovascular and nervous-system disorders, agreed to buy Xcel Pharmaceuticals for $280 million to add neurology products, including the epilepsy drug retigabine. The price does not include expenses to retire $44 million of Xcel debt. Valeant, which is based in Costa Mesa, Calif., has been expanding its neurology treatments to help increase sales, which have dropped from a year earlier in each of the last five quarters. Xcel, which had $45.9 million in revenue for the nine months ended Sept. 30, also makes the epilepsy drug Diastat and Migranal for migraine headaches. Xcel is based in San Diego.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIPPIN, WARREN G.
description: LIPPIN--Warren G. Age 82. He left us to join his beloved wife Elaine on Sunday, January 30, 2005, while living in Coconut Creek, FLorida. Mr. Lippin was born in Brooklyn, NY and resided in Tarrytown, NY, Hemlock Farms, Pennsylvania, and Coconut Creek. Loving father to Doreen, Janet, and Howard, he was predeceased by his wife, his brothers Robert and Leon, and his sister Blanche. Mr. Lippin served in the US Army during WW II and fought in the Battle of the Bulge with the famed 35th Infantry Division. Mr. Lippin was recognized as a marksman, and was awarded the Good Conduct Medal, the Combat Infantryman's Badge, and the Bronze Star. A gifted businessman, Warren will be remembered for his contributions to the fertilize industry, and his relationships with his friends and associates. He will be deeply missed by all who ever knew him. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, February 4, 2005 at 12 noon at the Riverside Memorial Chapel located at 21 W. Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY, 914-664-6800. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction, 317 East 34th Street, New York, New York 10016, phone (212) 263-6656.

SEARS HOLDINGS TO LIST SHARES ON NASDAQ STOCK MARKET
description: Sears Holdings, the company to be formed by Kmart's acquisition of Sears, Roebuck, said it would list its shares on the Nasdaq stock market, ending Sears's run of 95 years on the New York Stock Exchange. Sears began trading on the Big Board on March 3, 1910. Kmart was delisted from the New York Stock Exchange in December 2002 after it filed for bankruptcy. Kmart agreed to buy Sears for $11 billion on Nov. 17. A New York Stock Exchange spokesman, Christiaan Brakman, said the move by Sears had been expected. Nasdaq did not say what symbol the combined company would trade under.

Arts, Briefly; Fox Rides High on 'American Idol'
description: The tide raised by "American Idol" lifts all of Fox's boats. In last week's ratings, Fox was No.1 in the coveted 18-to-49-year-old demographic with its regular programming -- meaning without sports -- for the first time since the May finale of "American Idol," the talent show. According to Nielsen's overnight ratings, "American Idol" drew an estimated 28.30 million viewers this Tuesday, a number slightly higher than last week's installment on the same night. Among the 18-to-49-year-olds who were watching television at 8 p.m., 30 percent were tuning in to "American Idol." They saw, amid other bits, Paula Abdul, above, throwing a fit to convince her fellow judge Randy Jackson to vote a James Brown soundalike through to the next round: her tears and threats that she would quit to back her convictions eventually won over Mr. Jackson, and the happy-footed contestant made it to Hollywood. In an abrupt tonal shift to the hospital drama "House" at 9 p.m., Fox stayed on top in all major ratings measures, winning the night overall. KATE AURTHUR

title: FEDERAL-MOGUL NAMES A CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: Federal-Mogul, a maker of engine bearings, named Jose Maria Alapont president and chief executive as it continued efforts to shed its asbestos liability through a bankruptcy reorganization. The interim chief executive, Robert Miller, will remain chairman. Mr. Alapont, 54, is a former chief executive of Fiat's truck and bus unit and a former executive at the Delphi Corporation. Judge Raymond Lyons of the United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., approved Mr. Alapont's appointment. Federal-Mogul, based in Southfield, Mich., filed for bankruptcy in 2001 after a drop in auto parts sales and a rise in lawsuits from people who claimed that their illnesses were caused by asbestos-laden products the company had once made.

title: This One's for You, Buckminster Fuller, Wherever You Are
description: A gold geodesic dome in Oklahoma City, built as an attention-grabbing bank in 1958, will become offices with faceted ceilings and curved walls on Feb. 20. Dr. Irene Lam, an optometrist, has spent $2.1 million buying and restoring the anodized aluminum hemisphere to house her practice, a dozen tenants and an Asian cultural center. The previous owner, Bank One, announced plans four years ago to raze the dome, setting off picket lines, petitions and angry Web postings. (The National Trust for Historic Preservation placed the dome on the 2002 list of most endangered historic places.)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Bid For Mining Company Raised
description: Xstrata, a mining company based in Switzerland, raised its hostile takeover bid for the Australian mining company WMC Resources by more than 13 percent, to 8.4 billion Australian dollars ($6.5 billion) as the company's stock price continued to rise on higher commodity prices and speculation that a rival bidder would emerge. In October, WMC rejected an Xstrata offer of 7.4 billion Australian dollars, or 6.35 dollars a share, saying it was too low, and later hired an independent firm to conduct an appraisal that valued WMC at 7.17 to 8.24 Australian dollars a share. Many analysts and investors still expect that either Rio Tinto or BHP Billiton will make a counteroffer for WMC, whose stock price rose above Xstrata's bid on Wednesday, to 7.32 Australian dollars a share. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOMERFIELD, ELSIE J.
description: SOMERFIELD--Elsie J., age 88, died peacefully at home on February 3, 2005 with her beloved husband of 68 years, Ralph Murray Somerfield at her side. A native New Yorker, she was a 1937 graduate of Hunter College, later completing her masters degree in Guidance and Counseling at Queens College and doctoral coursework at Fordham University. Her career as a gifted teacher, a compassionate guidance counselor and assistant examiner in charge of counseling and school psychology at the NYC Board of Examiners characterized her commitment to the importance of education and the value of skilled counseling for children in need of help. Her interest in and innate ability to "hear" and help others, not only determined her career, but was also a gift she gave to her family and friends. She touched many, many lives. After her retirement she served as a member of the Advisory Council of Queens Children's Psychiatric Center. A mother who deeply loved her children, she worked hard to make sure they had every opportunity to learn the skills they would need to stand on their own two feet in the world, as well as to benefit from life's joys -- music, dance, the beach and country, foreign travel, books, and so much more. She will be profoundly missed by her husband, her daughters Benita Somerfield and Barbara Somerfield-Guffey, her sonin-law John Guffey, her niece Joan Levick, her cousins Roslyn Moskowitz, Bonnie Haber, Sven Mohr, and many others. Memorial donations in her memory may be made to Calvary Hospice, 1740 Eastchester Rd, Bronx, NY 10461.

description: Liking the little known character actor James Urbaniak has long been a sign of downtown cool. For years, Mr. Urbaniak, above, who specializes in portrayals of sensitive outsiders racked by angst, obsession or artistic genius, has been a star in hipster circles because of his oddball roles in black-box theaters (he played the French theorist Guy Debord in the stage adaptation of "Lipstick Traces"), Hal Hartley movies (the shy poet/garbage man in "Henry Fool") and the occasional television cameo (the foot fetishist in "Sex and the City"). But lately, he has begun to branch out, making his Broadway debut earlier this season in a scene-stealing turn as a gossipy servant in the revival of the 18th-century comedy "The Rivals." And he is currently starring in a commercial Off Broadway production as the jumpy title character in Will Eno's one-man-show "Thom Pain (based on nothing)," a teasing play that might remind audiences of one of Edward Albee's more abstract dramas. Mr. Urbaniak, whose angular face and slender body gives him the look of a hungry bird, delivers an astonishing performance of a vacant, yet somehow charming, man who rambles in an almost stream of consciousness style for 60 minutes. The script is willfully inscrutable, full of jokes without punch lines and magic tricks that peter out. But what is consistent throughout is the alert and icy gaze of Mr. Urbaniak, who keeps your attention totally transfixed, generating suspense with hardly any plot to assist him. He may be performing above 14th street, but Mr. Urbaniak remains as cool as ever. (This weekend's schedule: Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 6 and 9 p.m. and Sunday at 3 and 7 p.m. DR2 Theater, 103 East 15th Street, Manhattan. (212)239-6200. Tickets: $45.) JASON ZINOMAN

Paid Notice: Deaths   BERSON, SAMUEL
description: BERSON--Samuel. Short of immortality, no one could have done it better than my father. Dad, most people who met you instantly developed fond and lasting affection for you. Simply stated, you were clearly an honest man. Your kind heart and easy manner, your charming sense of humor, and your unaffected modesty, all inspired affection in everyone who met you. But that was not all. You inspired admiration as a gifted physician and an innovative leader in the private hospital industry. You worked hard until your ninth decade. You remained devoted to your wife of 63 years and above all involved and interested in every member of your family; all 26 of us. The only facet you hid from everyone was your fighting spirit. You were always willing to compromise on every point in order to achieve harmony because you respected other people and felt that was the way to move forward in a spirit of cooperation. But you fought with all your heart for an extended life. And Dad, thankfully, you won that battle. You won it for yourself and you won it for us, your family. You gave us the gift of being here for so long. I thank you for being the man you were and for teaching all of us the real value of life and for loving each one of us so individually. In your own words, "one is as precious to me as the next." I know you are at peace. You will always be alive in my heart. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CANICK, MOSES LEON, M.D.
description: CANICK--Moses Leon, M.D., age 82, died on February 2, 2005 at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was a Professor Emeritus and former Chief of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery at SUNY Health Science Center, Director of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery at Kings County Hospital and former Chief of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery at Brookdale Medical Center, all of Brooklyn. The only twice elected President of the Alumni Association-College of Medicine, SUNY Downstate Medical Center, he was a recipient of the Frank L. Babbott Memorial Award for Excellence in Teaching, a Diplomate of the American Board of Plastic Surgery and Fellow of the American College of Surgeons, and the author of numerous publications on plastic and reconstructive surgery. Born on the fourth of July in 1922, Leon was a 1942 graduate of Rutgers University. He left medical school in 1943 to enter the U.S. Navy, and was skipper (Lt. J.G., USN) of an LCT in the Pacific theatre during WWII. He was present at the invasions of Okinawa and Iwo Jima and was a witness to the raising of the US flag on Mt. Surabachi. Returning to medical school after the War, Leon earned a medical degree at Long Island College Hospital (now SUNY Medical School) in 1949, and a graduate degree in history from New York University in 1980. Leon's life was dedicated to the practice of plastic surgery, imparting his knowledge and modesty to his beloved medical residence, and to enhancing the quality of life for his patients. An avid cyclist and accomplished pianist, from Chopin to the golden oldies, Leon's enthusiastic "bravos" at the opera and ballet will be missed. His enthusiasm, curiosity and appetite for life made him an interesting and great conversationalist and enabled him to bear the infirmities of aging with dignity, courage and humor. Many thanks to his doctors, whose support and affection for him was unflagging, to his nurses Elaine, Brigid and Eileen, who cared for him with professionalism and love and to loving and faithful Virginia and Dora. Eternal gratitude to his friends who gave care, love and compassion. Leon is survived by his beloved wife Josephine L. Berger-Nadler, his children Michael, Jonathan, Jenny and Eliott from his former marriage, his sisters Emma and Rachal and three grandchildren, Julia, Lily, and Melissa and is predeceased by his son William. Services at Park Avenue Synagogue, Tuesday, February 8, 2005 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Oral History Program-WWII Program of Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ.

title: Arts, Briefly; At Providence Athenaeum

The 252-year-old Athenaeum, in Rhode Island, is one of the nation's oldest private lending libraries, established before public libraries were the norm. In 2002, financial pressures and sagging beams led its board to authorize a sale of the library's large-size copy of John James Audubon's "Birds of America." Dozens of library users sued, and the infighting was one factor in last year's resignation of the previous executive director, Jonathan Bengtson. Richard A. Olsen, a retired head librarian, filled the vacancy on an interim basis. Ms. Maxell, who has master's degrees in library science and business administration, has run the Consortium of Rhode Island Academic and Research Libraries and the Richards Memorial Library in North Attleboro, Mass. One of her lingering challenges will be the contretemps over the birds. Art experts say a sale could raise more than $5 million. In August, the Rhode Island Superior Court ruled that the board acted in good faith and declined to block the sale, but the decision has been appealed. ALISON LEIGH COWAN

The officer, who was not immediately identified, was slightly injured in the arm and was treated at a local hospital, according to the police. The police said the principal, Michael Soguero, 42, intervened when the officer began arresting the student for disorderly conduct just before noon. The school aide, James Bergos, 23, then intervened when the officer began to arrest Mr. Soguero, said Keith Kalb, a spokesman for the Department of Education, which is looking into the incident. Both men were later arrested and charged with assault and obstructing governmental administration. The student was charged with disorderly conduct and resisting arrest. Mr. Soguero denies assaulting anyone, according to a statement released by the principals' union. Mr. Bergos could not be reached. description: President Bush was right in exhorting Egypt, in his State of the Union address on Wednesday night, to be a country that could "show the way toward democracy in the Middle East." The helpful role of Egypt's president, Hosni Mubarak, as a peace broker between Israelis and Palestinians should not earn him immunity from criticism of his self-perpetuating dictatorship. After nearly 24 years in power, he appears ready to add 6 more in a single-candidate referendum this fall, all the while grooming his son Gamal for an eventual Pharaonic succession. American taxpayers have bankrolled this regime to the tune of tens of billions of dollars over the years. It is about time that Washington woke up to the explosive powder keg that has been building up under Mr. Mubarak's despotic rule.

title: The Listings; SHERMAN DREXLER: 'ART PARADISE: 50 YEARS OF PAINTING'
description: That things primitive and archaic should have been such compelling points of orientation for forward-thinking Modernists is one of the more fruitful paradoxes of 20th-century art. Sherman Drexler, 80, is a case in point. Mr. Drexler, who has been heard from little since a solo exhibition at P.S. 1 in 1984, has followed his own slightly eccentric path for more than five decades, but his paintings of generalized female nudes (based on his wife, the Pop painter and writer Rosalyn Drexler), horses or deer in the midst of broad, flat areas of paint combine the primordial and the abstract in a way that is close to the center of a Modernist mainstream running from Matisse to Susan Rothenberg. The large canvases featured in this small retrospective show have a scruffy, raw appearance; they are not beautiful but they exude a persuasive urgency of purpose. That Mr. Drexler thinks of himself at least in part as a kind of modern cave painter is affirmed by a remarkable installation of about 120 small paintings and objects imported from his Newark studio. Distributed over a plywood table, above, are scores of stones and fragments of construction debris on which the artist has roughly painted little dancing female nudes as though to evoke the timeless, pantheistic soul of the modern material world. (Mitchell Algus, 511 West 25th Street, Chelsea, (212)242-6242, through Feb. 12; free.) KEN JOHNSON

title: The Listings; PAUL BADURA-SKODA
description: Among the new generation of concertgoers, the eminent Austrian pianist Paul Badura-Skoda, who is 77 , may not have the name recognition he once had. But he has had an impact on his field through decades of performances and recordings, especially of the Viennese classical repertory, and also through his important scholarly contributions, including valued editions of works by Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert. Mr. Badura-Skoda, above, whose last name is a combination of his father's and stepfather's given names (both of Czech heritage), will give an all-Schubert recital at the Austrian Cultural Forum tonight. The recital comes just after the release by Kleos Classics of a seven-CD set, "Paul Badura-Skoda: A Man and His Music," that chronicles his long career. It includes private recordings from his teenage years that may startle those who know of him only as an urbane musician and scholar. There are, for example, his performances of some Rossini overtures played on the accordion in his own transcriptions. The accordion was his stepfather's passion, and young Paul was essentially compelled to learn it. In the extensive liner notes to the recording Mr. Badura-Skoda charmingly recalls how he used to sneak into the standing-room section of the Vienna State Opera through an obscure entry. He also vividly describes some formative experiences, like taking master classes with the great pianist Edwin Fischer, performing a Mozart concerto with Furtwngler just 18 months before the conductor's death, and working with Herbert von Karajan. The last CD documents Mr. Badura-Skoda's 75th birthday concert in 2002 in Vienna, a program of Schubert, Brahms and Ravel played with poise, style and insight. His all-Schubert recital tonight offers 13 waltzes, four impromptus and the Sonata in A (D. 959). (Tonight at 8, Austrian Cultural Forum, 11 East 52nd Street, Manhattan, (212)772-1132. Free; reservations required.) ANTHONY TOMMASINI

title: The Listings; HOU HSIAO-HSIEN
description: It's hard not to be instantly captivated by the early films of Hou Hsiao-hsien, the Taiwanese filmmaker who is being honored with a retrospective beginning today at Anthology Film Archives. The 1985 movie "A Time to Live and a Time to Die," screening tonight at 7, is an autobiographical account of Mr. Hou's childhood that seems to consist almost entirely of incidental details -- tops spinning in the dirt of a village square, a towel fluttering in the wind -- which eventually add up to a full, vibrant portrait of a provincial city. Mr. Hou has the great gift of being able to stand back from the characters he has created, observing them from a careful distance while they go about their apparently autonomous lives. Mr. Hou's great subject has always been Taiwan, the island outpost to which his family fled after the Communist takeover of mainland China. The early films focus on social problems -- alienated youth in "The Boys From Fengkuei" (1983), unemployment in "Dust in the Wind" (1987) -- while the later work, like "The Puppetmaster" (1993), "Good Men, Good Women" (1995) and "Goodbye South, Goodbye" (1996), above, takes a more historical and cultural approach, observing contemporary Taiwan through a cloud of cigarette smoke and a jangle of cellphones. (All of these titles will be screened this week at Anthology, 32 Second Avenue, at Second Street, in the East Village; for a complete schedule, check www.anthologyfilmarchives.org or call (212)505-5181. Tickets: $8; $6 for students and 65+; $5 for members.) DAVE KEHR

title: In Dallas
description: BIG D, the city of big money, big shopping and big hair, J. R. Ewing and Southfork, the Cowboys and their cheerleaders, is now dreaming up something even bigger. The Trinity River Corridor Project is being billed as one of the the country's largest urban parks and will include a complex of hotels, shops and clubs and feature a bridge designed by the architect Santiago Calatrava. That's the Dallas of legend, always thinking of the next big deal. But there's another face to the city, the loose and flirty side. In areas like Deep Ellum, with its converted lofts, art studios and night haunts; in the gritty Lower Greenville strip of bars and restaurants; and in new youth magnets like West Village and Travis Walk, the city is peeling off its placid skin and building a reputation as a multiethnic megalopolis and a sophisticated arts center. Dallas is getting a new rhythm, and you can feel it in the hot spots where trendsetters turn the night into one long party. LUISITA LOPEZ TORREGROSA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVIS, OSSIE
description: DAVIS--Ossie. The loss of Ossie Davis is a like a death in the family for us at 1199. Ossie was a man of genius and principle who always did the right thing. He was a beloved friend and trusted advisor to several generations of 1199ers. His association with our union began 50 years ago when he wrote and performed a dramatization for our members of the Mississippi lynching of black teenager Emmett Till. For over a quarter of a century Ossie and his magnificent wife Ruby Dee chaired our annual Black History Month Salutes to Freedom, events which drew thousands of health care workers to hear figures ranging from Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. to Mahalia Jackson, Dick Gregory, Pete Seeger and Stevie Wonder. Ossie and Ruby have been guiding spirits in our Breadand Roses Cultural Project. And, since 1965, they've been fixtures on 1199 picketlines, whether with their grandson marching for union recognition in 2001 outside a hospital in Bronxville, N.Y., or inspiring-and energizing-5,000 of 1199SEIU's Union activists for the 2004 presidential election campaign. In their autobiography, they called their experience with 1199 "one of the most fruitful and rewarding associations of our lives." For half a century, our Union has been fortunate to have the opportunity to feel the same way. Our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife Ruby Dee and their beautiful family.
