title: Arts, Briefly; 'Happy Days' Here Again for ABC
description: The first night of February sweeps was a robust evening for CBS, NBC and ABC. The Nielsen overnight ratings for Thursday's prime-time programming indicated that 19.55 million viewers were nostalgic for "Happy Days": that was the estimated number of people who watched ABC's two-hour 30th-anniversary reunion of the cast of that 1970's sitcom. Thursdays are generally a feeble night for ABC, but the power of the Fonz and Richie Cunningham (Henry Winkler, left, and Ron Howard) put it in a strong position for the night. The program was nearly three times as popular as the network's regular lineup, "Life as We Know It" and "Extreme Makeover." But CBS's dominance on Thursdays is entrenched, and new episodes of "CSI" and "Without a Trace" brought the No. 1 network a victory in both total viewers and households. On NBC, the combination of "The Apprentice" and the still-strong "ER" brought in the 18-to-49-year-old audience. NBC won the night in that demographic. KATE AURTHUR

description: New Haven - HERE is yet another indication that the government hasn't learned the lessons of Sept. 11. In December, the Senate Intelligence Committee voted for the second year in a row against the single largest item in the intelligence budget, with members calling it a wasteful misallocation of money that had not been adequately debated by Congress. Nevertheless, not only did the project -- which is officially top secret, but has been widely reported to be the latest version of a $9.5 billion surveillance satellite system called Misty -- again receive its financing from the Congressional appropriations committees, but at least one intelligence agency has also asked the Justice Department to investigate members of the Senate committee and their staffs for having the temerity to reveal to the press that the closed-door debate over it even took place.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: New Government
description: Parliament voted overwhelmingly to approve President Viktor A. Yushchenko's nominee as prime minister, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, left. She then quickly announced her new cabinet of ministers after days of jockeying for posts with party leaders who had supported Mr. Yushchenko's campaign. Boris Tarasyuk, a former foreign minister in the 1990's who strongly supports Ukraine's tilt toward the European Union, returned to the post. Anatoly Hrytsenko, a prominent military analyst, became defense minister. Mr. Yushchenko also appointed one of Ms. Tymoshenko's closest allies, Oleksandr V. Turchinov, to replace Ihor P. Smeshko as the chairman of the Security Services of Ukraine. Mr. Smeshko worked behind the scenes to avert a potential crackdown against protesters who massed in Kiev in November. Ms. Tymoshenko's nomination was supported by 373 of Parliament's 450 deputies. Thirteen others present either did not vote or abstained. The only twice elected President of the Alumni Association-College of Medicine, SUNY Downstate Medical Center, he was a recipient of the Frank L. Babbott Memorial Award for Excellence in Teaching, a Diplomate of the American Board of Plastic Surgery and Fellow of the American College of Surgeons, and the author of numerous publications on plastic and reconstructive surgery. Born on the fourth of July in 1922, Leon was a 1942 graduate of Rutgers University. He left medical school in 1943 to enter the U.S. Navy, and was skipper (Lt. J.G., USN) of an LCT in the Pacific theatre during WWII. He was present at the invasions of Okinawa and Iwo Jima and was a witness to the raising of the US flag on Mt. Surabachi. Returning to medical school after the War, Leon earned a medical degree at Long Island College Hospital (now SUNY Medical School) in 1949, and a graduate degree in history from New York University in 1980. Leon's life was dedicated to the practice of plastic surgery, imparting his knowledge and modesty to his beloved medical residence, and to enhancing the quality of life for his patients. An avid cyclist and accomplished pianist, from Chopin to the golden oldies, Leon's enthusiastic "bravos" at the opera and ballet will be missed. His enthusiasm, curiosity and appetite for life made him an interesting and great conversationalist and enabled him to bear the infirmities of aging with dignity, courage and humor. Many thanks to his doctors, whose support and affection for him was unflagging, to his nurses Elaine, Brigid and Eileen, who cared for him with professionalism and love and to loving and faithful Virginia and Dora. Eternal gratitude to his friends who gave care, love and compassion. Leon is survived by his beloved wife Josephine L. Berger-Nadler, his children Michael, Jonathan, Jenny and Eliott from his former marriage, his sisters Emma and Rachal and three grandchildren, Julia, Lily, and Melissa and is predeceased by his son William. Services at Park Avenue Synagogue, Tuesday, February 8, 2005 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Oral History Program-WWII Program of Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GELMAN, ANNA CHESKIS
description: GELMAN -- Anna Cheskis. The faculty, students, alumni and staff of Columbia University's Mailman School of Public Health are deeply saddened by the loss of our beloved Professor Emerita Anna Cheskis Gelman. Her dedication to the School and to Columbia's students extended beyond the classroom. She served as director of student affairs, editor of the first alumni directory and a founder of both the alumni and student government associations. Her dedication to public health and her love of teaching were extraordinary. A pioneering epidemiologist for over 60 years, Professor Gelman was teacher, mentor and friend to countless students, and her devotion to the School was unparalleled. Her contributions to the School include the establishment of the Gelman Professorship in the Department of Epidemiology in honor of her late husband. She also established the Gelman Laboratory Suite for Infectious Disease Research in the Jerome L. and Dawn Greene Infectious Disease Laboratory. She was a remarkable woman and we are the less for her passing. A memorial service will be held this spring on the Columbia University Medical Center campus. In lieu of flowers, it was her request that contributions in her memory be made to either the Mailman School's Fund for Public Health Leadership, or to support the Gelman Laboratory. For further information please contact the School at 212-305-6083. Allan Rosenfield, M.D., Dean GELMAN--Anna. The Board and Staff of Circle Lodge/Kinder Ring and The Workmen's Circle/Arbeter Ring mourn the passing of a dear friend. She was the consummate advisor, supporter and advocate; her presence made every summer a special joy.

While not taking sides on the issue, the regulator said the exchange's shareholders should ask how bidders would regulate the British market. If the exchange were acquired and merged with one run from outside Britain, British listing rules would not necessarily govern companies listed on the exchange, said Callum McCarthy, chairman of the authority. "The attractiveness of the U.K. financial markets, and ultimately the competitiveness of the E.U. capital markets, depends in part on a system of corporate governance and of regulation which is of a high standard," Mr. McCarthy said. In addition, corporate acquisitions would become more complex, he said. The Deutsche Brse has bid for the London exchange, and Euronext, based in Paris, has expressed interest in a takeover. title: The Punk-Christian Son of a Preacher Man
description: As a bookstore manager in Atlanta, I was host to a book signing in 2001 with Jay Bakker, as he signed copies of his autobiography (John Leland, Jan. 23). As a Southern liberal, I had often rolled my eyes at the antics of his parents and frankly expected the evening to be a more youthful version of the same. title: Shabby Chic
description: Muslin is the cheap friend of cottage curtains. But in haute couture, it's the handmaiden to the evening gown. No designer worthy of being called a couturier would risk spoiling 30 yards of Lyons silk to make a prototype that will be stuck with pins, stained with ink and even garishly daubed with Post-its. That's what humble muslin is for. It's the R.E.M. phase of the couture dream cycle, when designers transfer each sketch to a plain raiment they call a toile. They actually spend more time with the toiles than they do the finished dresses, since couture workrooms don't begin to assemble all the various parts of a garment -- the jacket front that may be at Lesage for embroidery, a collar that may be waiting for its hand-dyed ribbon trim -- until a few days before the show. This gives the toiles a certain influence beyond their quiet ability to impart a sense of line and silhouette to the designer as he sits in his studio refreshing himself with a Diet Pepsi (here you think of Karl Lagerfeld at Chanel) or another Marlboro (that would be John Galliano at Dior). That the toiles are as ghostly as they are beautifully made is not surprising; they serve as the patterns for the atelier when it's time to roll out the silk and organdy. And that's why they're embellished not with beads but with photocopies of beads and words like "droit" and "grosgrain." But the toiles are deceptive. A coat from Chanel looks wholesomely sweet in muslin, but when the needles are done, it may be in smoky shades of gray mohair embroidered on tulle and cost a pretty penny. And when you see Dior's Directoire-inspired dresses in white chiffon under coats worthy of Empress Josephine herself, the muslin loses its temporal power and returns to the cottage windows. After all, it's just a dream. Cathy Horyn

But I've always longed for the camaraderie that succeeding at guy talk confers. Whenever I've tried to bridge this language divide, I've only crashed and burned. (Lobbying to read my college roommates' tarot cards rather than attend a frat party did not go over well.) In attempting a male Esperanto, a hybrid between how straight men talk and how I talk -- a Manglish if you will -- I've only freaked guys out. title: The Making of a Molester
description: Bergner establishes that inappropriate erotic thinking can manifest in many individuals, and then he asks why some cross "that clear line" and act on their thoughts. If you stand back from the content of the crime and look at the broader narrative of Roy's life, you see a remarkable absence of "clear lines" all around: like the early involvement with his victim's mother, who was the wife of his childhood friend; his employer's and co-workers' remarkable blindness to the character pathology despite adjudication and sentencing; his new wife's blindness to the significance of her own dissonance, despite saying, "I can't understand how he could write crap like that to a little girl." The run for the fence at the end of the story is the first evidence of any awareness of a clear line in many aspects of Roy's life.

title: UP FRONT

The practice of presenting books and authors as news later evolved into the single front-cover review, the section's weekly signature until the mid-1990's when advancing technology -- color illustration, online photo access, sophisticated graphics and flexible layouts -- made new options available. Our latest redesign, introduced in October, enables us to vary formats from week to week. Sometimes we use text on the cover, sometimes not.

title: Inside the List
description: GOING NEGATIVE: The books that make the Times hardcover fiction list tend to be, by and large, review-proof. Nothing Michiko Kakutani or Jonathan Yardley can say will keep Michael Crichton or Clive Cussler or Danielle Steel from claiming a place at this 15-seat table. But what about nonfiction? Consider the hardy book at No. 6 this week, the British writer Lynne Truss's "Eats, Shoots & Leaves: The Zero Tolerance Approach to Punctuation." Truss's book has sat on the nonfiction list for 42 weeks, much longer than any other current title. Her book also happens to have withstood one of the most withering reviews in recent memory, Louis Menand's acid account, in The New Yorker, of the book's own grammatical errors. ("Either Truss needed a copy editor or her copy editor needed a copy editor," Menand cracked.) Truss's editor reacted; he called Menand a name that's not printable here. And in the London newspapers, at least one writer rushed patriotically to Truss's defense, describing Menand as humorless and observing that many of his criticisms are matters "of taste and not correctness." American readers, in love with Truss's breezily outraged tone, haven't seemed to care either way. Her new book, "Talk to the Hand," will be published in November. It is about manners. The suspense -- will she put her forks in the right place? -- is almost too much to bear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WINTERS, BEN
description: WINTERS--Ben. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Ben Winters of Beverly Hills, CA. A driving, inspirational force in the ATS, he served as chairman and president of the Western Region and Southern California Chapter, and on the National Board of Directors, where he held positions as chair of the Campaign Cabinet and National Investment Committees. Vice president of Rabin-Winters, Inc. and founder of a successful consulting practice in mergers and acquisitions, Mr. Winter's passion for service dominated his life. Actively involved in a wide range of medical, educational and Jewish institutions in Southern California and Israel, he was a distinguished life trustee of Cedars-Sinai Medical Center and past president of the Stephen S. Wise Temple. Demonstrating his profound belief in the Technion as the future of Israel, he and his beloved wife, Elaine, supported a variety of ATS projects, including the Ben and Elaine Winters Computer and Communications Network, which linked many of the Technion's research laboratories and departments to mainframe computers by fiber optics. In recognition of his dedicated service, Mr. Winters was presented with the Albert Einstein Award, the highest ATS honor. A member of the Technion International Board of Governors, he was recognized by the university with an honorary doctorate of science in technology and an honorary fellowship. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Elaine, children Sherry and John David Winters, grandchildren, and the entire Winters family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Stephen A. Laser, President Evelyn Berger, Chairman Melvyn H. Captured in the Philippines in May 1942, he was a prisoner of the Japanese for nearly 31/2 years, and awarded two bronze stars for his service. He did his psychoanalytic training at the Menninger Clinic in Topeka, KS, became a professor of clinical psychiatry at Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons, and founded the Department of Behavioral Physiology at New York State Psychiatric Institute, from which he retired in 1995. Dr. Glusman is survived by his wife, Louise; his brother, Sydney; his sister, Estelle; his son, Dr. Steven Glusman of El Paso, TX; his daughter, Dr. Joan Glusman of Whippany, NJ; his son, John of Glen Ridge, NJ; and six grandchildren. A private memorial service will be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CANICK, MOSES LEON, M.D.
description: CANICK--Moses Leon, M.D., age 82, died on February 2, 2005 at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was a Professor Emeritus and former Chief of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery at SUNY Health Science Center, Director of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery at Kings County Hospital and former Chief of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery at Brookdale Medical Center, all of Brooklyn. The only twice elected President of the Alumni Association-College of Medicine, SUNY Downstate Medical Center, he was a recipient of the Frank L. Babbott Memorial Award for Excellence in Teaching, a Diplomate of the American Board of Plastic Surgery and Fellow of the American College of Surgeons, and the author of numerous publications on plastic and reconstructive surgery. Born on the fourth of July in 1922, Leon was a 1942 graduate of Rutgers University. He left medical school in 1943 to enter the U.S. Navy, and was skipper (Lt. J.G., USN) of an LCT in the Pacific theatre during WWII. He was present at the invasions of Okinawa and Iwo Jima and was a witness to the raising of the US flag on Mt. Surabachi. Returning to medical school after the War, Leon earned a medical degree at Long Island College Hospital (now SUNY Medical School) in 1949, and a graduate degree in history from New York University in 1980. Leon's life was dedicated to the practice of plastic surgery, imparting his knowledge and modesty to his beloved medical residents, and to enhancing the quality of life for his patients. An avid cyclist and accomplished pianist, from Chopin to the golden oldies, Leon's enthusiastic "bravos" at the opera and ballet will be missed. His enthusiasm, curiosity and appetite for life made him an interesting and great conversationalist and enabled him to bear the infirmities of aging with dignity, courage and humor. Many thanks to his doctors, whose support and affection for him was unflagging, to his nurses Elaine, Brigid and Eileen, who cared for him with professionalism and love and to loving and faithful Virginia and Dora. Eternal gratitude to his friends who gave care, love and compassion. Leon is survived by his beloved wife Josephine L. Berger-Nadler, his children Michael, Jonathan, Jenny and Eliott from his former marriage, his sisters Emma and Rachal and three grandchildren, Julia, Lily, and Melissa and is predeceased by his son William. Services at Park Avenue Synagogue, Tuesday, February 8, 2005 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Oral History Program-WWII Program of Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOMERFIELD, ELSIE J.
description: SOMERFIELD--Elsie J., age 88, died peacefully at home on February 3, 2005 with her beloved husband of 68 years, Ralph Murray Somerfield at her side. A native New Yorker, she was a 1937 graduate of Hunter College, later completing her masters degree in Guidance and Counseling at Queens College and doctoral coursework at Fordham University. Her career as a gifted teacher, a compassionate guidance counselor and assistant examiner in charge of counseling and school psychology at the NYC Board of Examiners characterized her commitment to the importance of education and the value of skilled counseling for children in need of help. Her interest in and innate ability to "hear" and help others, not only determined her career, but was also a gift she gave to her family and friends. She touched many, many lives. After her retirement she served as a member of the Advisory Council of Queens Children's Psychiatric Center. A mother who deeply loved her children, she worked hard to make sure they had every opportunity to learn the skills they would need to stand on their own two feet in the world, as well as to benefit from life's joys -- music, dance, the beach and country, foreign travel, books, and so much more. She will be profoundly missed by her husband, her daughters Benita Somerfield and Barbara Somerfield-Guffey, her sonin-law John Guffey, her niece Joan Levick, her cousins Roslyn Moskowitz, Bonnie Haber, Sven Mohr, and many others. Memorial donations in her memory may be made to Calvary Hospice, 1740 Eastchester Rd, Bronx, NY 10461.

Mr. Haverstick was born in Carlisle, PA and lived most of his life in NYC. He moved to Summit in 2002. A graduate of Amherst College, Mr. Haverstick retired as the Editorial Secretary of the United Church of Christ based in Philadelphia. Previously he had been an executive editor at various publishing houses, including Holt, Rinehart & Winston, and religion editor for LIFE Magazine. A direct descendant of Colonel Michael Haverstick, head of the Pennsylvania Quartermaster Corps for Washington's Army, and Lieutenant William Haverstick, the noted Philadelphia silversmith, who was decorated for bravery at the Battle of Princeton, Mr. Haverstick served in World War II as a correspondent for YANK Magazine. Mr. Haverstick's interest in American religion led him to write numerous articles for the Saturday Review, The New York Times Book Review and LIFE Magazine. His pinnacle achievement was the publishing of his book, The Progress of the Protestant, in 1968. The book is still used in college curriculums. His marriage to the former Iola Wise Stetson, now deceased, ended in divorce. We went to Mauritius last year, and we got a bit bored, really; we don't like being too hot and just lying down. I've always wanted to go to Alcatraz, and Andrew's a big fan of "The Rock," with Sean Connery. The main thing for both of us was just the realness of it; it's very lifelike. You can imagine everything as it was, and you could imagine the prisoners in the cells. They haven't put big, fancy tourist attractions all over it; they've just sort of left it, which is attractive to us. Andrew spent most of his time looking for the shower block that was featured in "The Rock." Then we met a guard who said it didn't exist at all. It was completely made up. As told to Seth Kugel

title: Dead and Bloated

Not even a superior genre specimen like FLESHMARKET ALLEY (Little, Brown, $22.95), Ian Rankin's latest Edinburgh police procedural featuring Inspector John Rebus, escapes the consequences of good prose gone to flab. The crime that jolts Rebus out of his customary state of cynical composure -- the murder of a Turkish Kurd living illegally in Knoxland, one of the city's most squalid and dangerous housing projects -- promises to be political dynamite. With both police and press treating the homicide as Edinburgh's first hate killing, the investigation opens the door to the hostility toward foreigners that has long been smoldering in the city's wretched slums.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERSON, SAMUEL
description: BERSON--Samuel. Short of immortality, no one could have done it better than my father. Dad, most people who met you instantly developed fond and lasting affection for you. Simply stated, you were clearly an honest man. Your kind heart and easy manner, your charming sense of humor, and your unaffected modesty, all inspired affection in everyone who met you. But that was not all. You inspired admiration as a gifted physician and an innovative leader in the private hospital industry. You worked hard until your ninth decade. You remained devoted to your wife of 63 years and above all involved and interested in every member of your family; all 26 of us. The only facet you hid from everyone was your fighting spirit. You were always willing to compromise on every point in order to achieve harmony because you respected other people and felt that was the way to move forward in a spirit of cooperation. But you fought with all your heart for an extended life. And Dad, thankfully, you won that battle. You won it for yourself and you won it for us, your family. You gave us the gift of being here for so long. I thank you for being the man you were and for teaching all of us the real value of life and for loving each one of us so individually. In your own words, "one is as precious to me as the next." I know you are at peace. You will always be alive in my heart. And Dad, remember this always, our memory of you is the most precious of all!! Your adoring daughter, Bonnie Stern

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, RICHARD E.
description: SMITH--Richard E. A wellknown figure in the consumer goods world and heralded as an innovator who was formative in shaping the ice cream and frozen dessert industry, passed away on Saturday, January 29, at the age of 62. Descended from three generations of New York City purveyors of ice cream, Richard was Co-Chairman and CoChief Executive of CoolBrands International Inc., the Canadian ice cream maker which owns Chipwich, Eskimo Pie and the license for many branded frozen desserts, including Godiva Ice Cream and Tropicana fruit bars. He led the company from Ronkonkoma, New York, and was a resident of Southampton, New York. It was said that ice cream was in Richard's blood. His grandfather started Smith Brothers Ice Cream in the early 1900's, one of the first distributors of ice cream in the New York metropolitan area that made deliveries using horse drawn carriage. His father, Lester Smith, founder of Duvall French Ice Cream, owned and operated the last ice cream manufacturing plant in Manhattan, located at 92nd and 2nd Avenue. Richard Smith, however, built his own business from the ground up. In his mid-20's, he bought a partnership interest in Calip Dairies, Inc., and created what is today one of the largest distributors of ice cream in the tri-state region and the manufacturer of such ice cream brands as Dolly Madison, Schrafft's and Sedutto. In 1980 he created FrsenGladj, the super premium ice cream with the memorable name and the futuristic white, sculptured container that he later sold to Kraft Foods in 1995. That same year he bought Steve's Ice Cream of Boston, which he took public in 1986 as Steve's Homemade Ice Cream, Inc. The company then acquired Swensen's Ice Cream and grew to be a major ice cream manufacturer and franchisor. He merged his company (then called Integrated Brands, Inc.) with Yogen Frz World-Wide Inc. to create CoolBrands International Inc. in 1998. Under Richard's leadership, CoolBrands acquired The Eskimo Pie Corporaton in 2000, then Fruit-A-Freeze and Chipwich in 2002. In 2003, the company also bought Nestle's U.S. ice cream distribution operations; Dreyer's super premium brands Dreamery Ice Cream and Whole Fruit Sorbet; and the license for Godiva Ice Cream. Most recently, CoolBrands entered into an agreement to acquire Breyer's Yogurt from Kraft Foods. Richard was seen as the consummate entrepreneur whom many have called a "larger than life" figure. His colleagues and competitors remember him as a passionate and tireless worker who was remarkable for his creative intelligence, detailed knowledge of the business, and tremendous determination and persistence. He was also known for his deep devotion to his family and for his unpretentious demeanor and generous spirit. He was active in raising money for philanthropic causes, including the Diabetes Research Institute and many other charities. Richard Smith was born in 1942 in the Bronx, and attended Great Neck North High School on Long Island. He received a Bachelor of Arts degree from Ohio University and attended Syracuse Law School. Richard is survived by his mother, Fay; his loving wife of 39 years, Susan; his son, David; his two grandsons, Jared and James; and three godchildren, Ben, Hannah and Juliana Stein. He will be greatly missed.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Long Island: Two Teens Die In Fiery Crash
description: Two teenage boys were killed early yesterday when the car they were riding in was crushed by a Ford Explorer that landed on it, causing a fiery crash that closed the Southern State Parkway for five hours, the state police said. The accident occurred shortly before 2 a.m. along the Southern State Parkway in North Bay Shore, when the Explorer, which was traveling westbound, hit the guard rail and flew into the eastbound lanes, landing on the boys' Chevrolet Cavalier and killing the driver and a rear seat passenger. The names of the boys, ages 17 and 19, were not released. A third passenger, a 19-year-old boy, was taken to Stony Brook University Hospital for treatment and later released. The 21-year-old driver of the Explorer was treated at Southside Hospital in Bay Shore and later released. A 22-year-old passenger in the Explorer refused medical treatment. No charges have been filed, and the police are continuing their investigation. They asked anyone who saw the crash to call them at (631) 231-6389. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WERTIMER, SIDNEY
description: WERTIMER -- Sidney. 84, professor of economics for 52 years at Hamilton College, died on February 1, in Charleston, SC, while visiting members of his family. In addition to teaching finance, money and banking, and accounting to Hamilton undergraduates as the McEwen Professor of Economics, Dr. Wertimer served at various junctures of his career as economics department chairman, associate dean of the college, provost and college marshal. For half a century he was a volunteer firefighter for the Village of Clinton and kept a department radio crackling in his kitchen 24 hours a day. Born in Buffalo, New York, on October 28, 1920, Sidney Wertimer graduated in 1942 from the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, then reported for active duty as an Ensign aboard the Navy destroyer William D. Porter. Following WWII, Lieutenant Wertimer returned to the University of Buffalo to obtain an M.A. degree in economics and went from there abroad to study at the London School of Economics where he earned a Ph.D. in 1952. Via transatlantic telephone, he was offered an assistant professorship at Hamilton, where he remained a conspicuous and highly energetic presence on campus for the next five decades. He is the author of "Economics and Man," a college textbook used nationally. Professor Wertimer is survived by his wife of 57 years, the former Eleanor M. Walsh; four children: Peter (Alicia Mendicino), Sheila (Gary Gruca), Stephen (Jane Boster), and Thomas (Raylene Saltouse); and ten grandchildren. He is also survived by a brother Edward (Skyne Uku-Wertimer). A memorial service will be held on Thursday, February 10, at 4 pm, in the Hamilton College Chapel. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Professor Wertimer's name to the Town/Gown Fund, c/o Hamilton College, 198 College Hill Rd, Clinton, NY 13323.

title: Arts, Briefly; Banned in Milan
description: Milanese authorities have decided that some publicity is best avoided. Last week that city rejected a billboard campaign for the French fashion house Marith et Franois Girbaud depicting a female version of Leonardo da Vinci's "Last Supper" after it was deemed potentially offensive to Christians. The campaign plays off the popularity of Dan Brown's bestseller "The Da Vinci Code," which insinuates that the figure of St. John the Evangelist in that work actually embodies Mary Magdalene. The outlawed billboard portrays John, the only man in the picture, in a provocative half-naked pose being embraced by a female apostle, and the municipal advertising ethics committee decided that this "made the imitation more offensive." The fashion house has reportedly defended its campaign as a tribute to women. ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Perth Amboy: Leak Blamed In Fatal Explosion
description: The industrial gas explosion that killed three workers and injured a fourth on Jan. 25 at a plant in Perth Amboy appears to have been caused by acetylene that leaked from an open valve, federal investigators say. A preliminary inquiry indicated that the acetylene flowed through pipes intended to carry water into a shed near the production area, where an electric switch or a propane heater's pilot light ignited it. Stephen J. Selk, an investigator with the United States Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board, said that the presence of an open-flame heater near an acetylene production site could be a violation of federal fire-safety codes, and that if it were not, the rules might need to be rewritten. The explosion occurred at the Acetylene Service Company. Messages left on Friday for company officials were not answered. Damien Cave (NYT)

description: POOR--Charles Lane III. Resident of Washington, DC, and Nonquitt, MA, died Thursday morning, February 3, 2005, at Georgetown University Hospital after a prolonged illness, at the age of 85. Mr. Poor was a graduate of Harvard College, Class of 1941, and an aeronautical engineer. He served in the Navy during World War II. His career included work at the Aberdeen Proving Grounds, where he was instrumental in establishing the first supersonic wind tunnel in this country following World War II. He also served as Assistant Secretary of the Army for Research and Development. Mr. Poor was an avid sailor, and was a member of the Cruising Club of America, the New Bedford Yacht Club, and the Annapolis Yacht Club. He sailed extensively on the Chesapeake Bay and in ocean races. He also worked for years on US Sailing's International Measurement System Committee, and on the international Ocean Racing Congress (ORC), at one time serving as chairman of the International Technical Committee, and more recently as a member of the ORC Committee of Honour. Mr. Poor was active in various groups in the Washington, DC, area. He served as chairman of the Citizens Association of Georgetown. He was also a member of the City Tavern Club, and the Chevy Chase Club. He loved choral music, and was an active participant in Bach and Beer, a men's singing group. Mr. Poor is survived by his wife, Edith Cowles Poor of Washington, DC, his brother Sheppard Poor of Rumson, NJ, his four sons, Lane Poor of Warren, RI, David Poor of Jenkintown, PA, Alfred Poor of Perkasie, PA, and Robert Poor of Boston, MA, and his two step-daughters, Nancy Greene of San Luis Obispo, CA, and Lila Greene of Paris, France. He is also survived by 14 grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Saturday, February 12, 2005, at 3 pm, at St. Alban's Church at 3001 Wisconsin Avenue NW in Washington, DC. A reception will be held in the church social hall immediately following the service. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made in his memory to either the Lombardi Comprehensive Cancer Center at Georgetown University Hospital, or the Chesapeake Bay Foundation in Annapolis, MD.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CANICK, MOSES LEON, M.D.
description: CANICK--Moses Leon, M.D., age 82, died on February 2, 2005 at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was a Professor Emeritus and former Chief of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery at SUNY Health Science Center, Director of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery at Kings County Hospital and former Chief of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery at Brookdale Medical Center, all of Brooklyn. The only twice elected President of the Alumni Association-College of Medicine, SUNY Downstate Medical Center, he was a recipient of the Frank L. Babbott Memorial Award for Excellence in Teaching, a Diplomate of the American Board of Plastic Surgery and Fellow of the American College of Surgeons, and the author of numerous publications on plastic and reconstructive surgery. Born on the fourth of July in 1922, Leon was a 1942 graduate of Rutgers University. He left medical school in 1943 to enter the U.S. Navy, and was skipper (Lt. J.G., USN) of an LCT in the Pacific theatre during WWII. He was present at the invasions of Okinawa and Iwo Jima and was a witness to the raising of the US flag on Mt. Surabachi. Returning to medical school after the War, Leon earned a medical degree at Long Island College Hospital (now SUNY Medical School) in 1949, and a graduate degree in history from New York University in 1980. Leon's life was dedicated to the practice of plastic surgery, imparting his knowledge and modesty to his beloved medical residents, and to enhancing the quality of life for his patients. An avid cyclist and accomplished pianist, from Chopin to the golden oldies, Leon's enthusiastic "bravos" at the opera and ballet will be missed. His enthusiasm, curiosity and appetite for life made him an interesting and great conversationalist and enabled him to bear the infirmities of aging with dignity, courage and humor. Many thanks to his doctors, whose support and affection for him was unflagging, to his nurses Elaine, Brigid and Eileen, who cared for him with professionalism and love and to loving and faithful Virginia and Dora. Eternal gratitude to his friends who gave care, love and compassion. Leon is survived by his beloved wife Josephine L. Berger-Nadler, his children Michael, Jonathan, Jenny and Eliott from his former marriage, his sisters Emma and Rachal and three grandchildren, Julia, Lily, and Melissa and is predeceased by his son William. Services at Park Avenue Synagogue, Tuesday, February 8, 2005 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Oral History Program-WWII Program of Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVINSON, ROSE (QUITMAN)
description: LEVINSON--Rose (Quitman), 95, of Crestwood, NY. Died surrounded by family after a short illness on Monday, February 7, 2005. Married for 70 years to her loving husband, Louis, she will be mourned by him and family, including daughters Elsa Kleinman (Ira), Susan Zolov, Gigi (Keith Brubaker); her grandchildren, Michael Zolov (Liz), Karen Kleinman, Eric Zolov (Emmy), Marni Fried (Kevin); and three precious greatgrandsons, Noah, Toby and Jonah. A spokesman for the Sanitation Department, Vito Turso, said that the driver, who had worked for the department since July 2000, was on a 7 p.m. to 3 a.m. shift and was one of many nighttime drivers who haul garbage away. title: GOODRICH PROFIT CLIMBED 62% IN FOURTH QUARTER

Net income climbed to $36.7 million, or 30 cents a share, from $22.6 million, or 19 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 12 percent, to $1.26 billion. Goodrich, based in Charlotte, N.C., said sales to the Boeing Company and to the European aircraft maker Airbus rose more than 12 percent in the quarter, while military and space sales climbed almost 14 percent. Sales of spare parts rose almost 7 percent. The company said it expected revenue in 2005 to increase 6 percent to 8 percent, from $4.72 billion in 2004. Shares of Goodrich rose 93 cents, or 2.7 percent, to $35.43.

title: Avoiding the Real Challenge
description: President Bush's latest deficit-steeped budget, for all its tough talk of reining in spending, stands out as a monument to misplaced political capital. It would take some hard work, indeed, to get Congress to face up to the binge of deficit spending that is haunting the nation and future generations of taxpayers. Yet Mr. Bush is not going to face the music. Instead, he's investing his precious re-election clout in pushing a wildly expensive plan to divert some Social Security payments to private accounts, a step that would not even address the long-term financial problems with the current system. His proposed budget, meanwhile, is a picture of reduced revenue and swollen pockets of hidden spending. The lip service about draconian clampdowns will hardly solve the problem, particularly in the eyes of the international markets that are studying the administration for signs of commitment to closing the budget deficit.

description: Hasbro, the world's second-largest toymaker, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit rose 7.2 percent after it cut costs to offset a decline in sales. Net income increased to $82.1 million, or 44 cents a share, less than the 49 cents a share forecast by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Revenue fell 5.6 percent, to $1.1 billion. The company, based in Pawtucket, R.I., said it faced a "tougher retail environment" than expected in the fourth quarter. Toy sales in the United States fell 17 percent, to $263.7 million, hurt by a decline in sales of Beyblade spinning tops, which generated about 11 percent of the company's 2003 sales. The chief executive, Alfred J. Verrecchia, cut an unspecified number of jobs in December to trim costs. Shares of Hasbro, which trails Mattel in overall sales, fell 40 cents, or 2 percent, to $20.

Ms. Thomas-Graham, who had been president and chief executive of CNBC since July 2001, was named chairman of the network, a new position, the company said. Ms. Thomas-Graham, 41, was succeeded as president by Mark Hoffman, 47, who has been president and general manager of WVIT, the television station owned by NBC in central Connecticut, since September 2001. CNBC's average daily viewership last year -- 145,000 -- represented a drop of more than 50 percent since 2000, according to Nielsen Media Research. NBC Universal is owned by the General Electric Company, which is based in Fairfield, Conn. Jacques Steinberg (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel Agrees To Airwaves Swap
description: Nextel Communications will spend $2.8 billion and give up some capacity for sending wireless calls in exchange for airwaves worth $4.86 billion, accepting a federal government plan to lessen interference on police radios. Nextel, based in Reston, Va., announced its agreement with the government's terms in a statement yesterday. After more than two years of deliberating how to eliminate interference between Nextel phones and public-safety radios, the Federal Communications Commission decided in July to award Nextel a different set of frequencies. Nextel balked at initial financial terms, and the government has agreed to reduce the amount the company would have to pay. Nextel's new frequencies, which might be used to provide high-speed wireless Web access, are closer to channels used by other cellphone carriers like Sprint, which agreed to buy Nextel in December. The same month, the F.C.C. granted a Nextel request to trim by $452 million the amount the company would pay.

The weapons and false bills were discovered after officers detained Julio Negron, 38, who had shot another man in the leg during a parking dispute, the police said. After speaking to Mr. Negron's neighbors, officers went back to the building where he lives, at 583 Woodward Avenue, and found the weapons in plastic bags on a nearby roof, said Capt. Scott Shanley, the commanding officer of the 104th Precinct. Fernando Caban, 36, Monica Guartan, 28 and Mr. Negron were charged with criminal possession of a weapon, and Mr. Negron was charged with assault as well. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

description: Dutch prosecutors in a pretrial hearing for 12 defendants suspected of being terrorists said their arrests late last year had prevented them from carrying out "one or more very serious attacks" in the Netherlands. The suspects, mostly young men of North African descent said to belong to a militant Muslim network, are accused of threatening to kill several Dutch politicians. Muhammad Bouyeri, a Dutch-Moroccan accused of killing the filmmaker Theo van Gogh in November, had ties to some of the suspects, the prosecutors said. Lawyers for the men said the prosecutors did not have enough evidence to prove their case, and some Dutch media reports questioned the extent of some of the alleged threats. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Vodafone Names President

Vodafone Japan said that Mr. Tsuda would become chairman and would share management responsibility with Mr. Morrow. The appointment of Mr. Morrow, above, who is currently chief executive of Vodafone Britain, comes as Vodafone struggles to turn around its operation in Japan. Vodafone lost 58,700 subscribers in January, falling further behind DoCoMo, the market leader, and KDDI, the No. 2 company, in the highly competitive Japanese mobile phone market. Vodafone has failed to match the feature-laden phones offered by its rivals. Mr. Morrow was formerly president of Japan Telecom, the fixed-line carrier that Vodafone sold two years ago. The company, based in Wickliffe, Ohio, said net income rose to $19.9 million, or 30 cents a share, from $11.1 million, or 21 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 80 percent, to a record $936.2 million, fueled by acquisitions. The chief executive, James L. Hambrick, said 2005 earnings would be $2.72 to $2.87 a share, above the $2.57 average estimate of four analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Lubrizol shares rose $3.22, or 8.7 percent, to $40.25.

title: Arts, Briefly; Literally a Basement Band
description: Despite early reports that its historic tour of Libya had been scuttled, the American rock group the Heavenly States said yesterday that it had in fact managed to play one show. Reached at the group's hotel in Cairo after continuing with the tour, its manager, Eugene Bari, said the band had finished all necessary paperwork for the concerts long in advance, but upon arriving in Libya it was told by diplomatic and government representatives that the tour could not go on. "They told us, 'You shall not do this,"' Mr. Bari said. "'If you do this people, will get hurt."' The band's four scheduled concerts were abandoned, but it managed to arrange a show in the basement at the home of a British diplomat in Tripoli, Mr. Bari said. "It was a lot like a basement show in the States," said Ted Nesseth, the band's singer and lead guitarist. "There was all this aggression and energy. We played as if we had never played before." BEN SISARIO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAERI, JOHN H. JR.
description: LAERI--John H. Jr., son of the late J. Howard and Betty C. Laeri of Greenwich, CT, died February 2, 2005 at his home in Fairfield, CT surrounded by his family. Mr. Laeri was born on December 21, 1935, Laeri was a graduate of Deerfield Academy and Williams College with honors in 1958. Following college he joined the United States Marine Corp. He began his career at First Boston Corporation in 1959. In 1961 Mr. Laeri worked for World Bank and served as special assistant to George Woods, President of World Bank. From 1963 to 1978 Mr. Laeri worked at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and Hornblower & Weeks, Hemphill, Noyes. In 1979 rejoined First Boston as Managing Director. Mr. Laeri established the largest Reorganization Group at that time on Wall Street. After retiring from First Boston in 1990, Mr. Laeri established and served as Chairman of Meadowcroft Associates Inc., a private investment banking firm located in Westport, CT. Mr. Laeri was also Chairman and owner of The GolfCoach Inc. At his passing Mr. Laeri served on several Board of Directors and Trusts. Mr. Laeri is survived by his beloved wife Kember and their three sons John, William and Christopher, a sister Sue Plein and her children Jim, Julie and Todd, two step-children John and Beth, and his uncle Robert Cochrane. Memorial service is being held on February 8 at 11:30 A.M. at St. Timothy's Episcopal Church in Fairfield, CT. In lieu of flowers donations in Mr. Laeri's memory to Deerfield Academy, 7 Boyden Lane, Deerfield, MA. 01342.

title: A Transcontinental Challenge
description: A TRANSCONTINENTAL CHALLENGE -- The troubled carrier Independence Air said yesterday that it would start low-fare nonstop flights to the West Coast this spring, plunging into transcontinental routes, the most fiercely competitive market in the domestic airline industry. Independence said that it would begin flying between its hub at Washington Dulles International Airport and San Diego on April 4 and to Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle and San Jose, Calif., on May 1, using new 132-passenger Airbus A319 aircraft. The low-fare carrier, which began independent service in November 2003 after operating as a regional jet service for United Airlines and Delta Air Lines, has been struggling financially. Last month, its load factor -- the average percentage of seats sold on each flight -- was 45.7 percent, well below the average of 70 percent to 80 percent of competitors. Transcontinental flights have "always been part of the plan for Independence Air," said Rick DeLisi, a spokesman. He said the strategy was to promote low-fare transcontinental flights to passengers connecting to Dulles from airports on the East Coast. Another low-fare carrier, America West, recently abandoned the transcontinental flights that it introduced in 2003, citing intense price-cutting by competitors. Since it dropped out of that market, America West said, some of its competitors' transcontinental fares have gone up by as much as 130 percent. It is not clear if Independence Air's plans will set off more fare wars.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Tsunami Quake's Force Revised Higher
description: The earthquake on Dec. 26 that generated a devastating tsunami across the Indian Ocean released three times as much energy as previously thought, according to calculations by scientists at Northwestern University. Earlier calculations that put the magnitude at 9.0 relied on seismic data that recorded oscillations up to five minutes long. In revising the magnitude to 9.3, Dr. Seth Stein and Dr. Emile Okal of Northwestern said their calculations included oscillations up to 54 minutes in length. That would fit with suggestions that the earthquake broke 750 miles of the fault stretching north from the Indonesian island of Sumatra. Kenneth Chang (NYT)

title: Hemingway Recycled
description: Ernest Hemingway, right, just keeps churning them out, it seems. Kent State University Press will publish an unabridged version of one of his last manuscripts in September, six years after a shorter version, edited by his son Patrick, was released to generally poor reviews. "Under Kilimanjaro," the new version of a novel chronicling a safari trip to Kenya, reinstates the content expurgated from "True at First Light: A Fictional Memoir," released in 1999 by Scribner. That book, at 319 pages, was on the New York Times best-seller list for four weeks. The unabridged version will top 500 pages, said Will Underwood, director of the Kent State press. Since the mid-1980's, at least three previously unreleased Hemingway works have been published, including "Garden of Eden," "The Dangerous Summer" and "True at First Light." Hemingway died in 1961. EDWARD WYATT

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel To Ship Dual-Core Chips
description: Intel, the world's largest semiconductor company, said yesterday that it would begin shipping its first two dual-core chips in the second quarter and had already briefed its largest customers on the technical details. The announcement offered the first details of Intel's plans for moving to dual-core design, which puts two processing engines on a single piece of silicon, giving the chips a huge increase in performance. The change is possible because of Intel's move over the last few years to more advanced manufacturing processes that permit more circuitry to be squeezed into a given area. Intel, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said last year that by 2006 about half the company's chips will be based on the dual-core design, and last summer it scrapped plans for a faster Pentium 4 chip in favor of the new design. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Biogen Reports 4th-Quarter Profit
description: Biogen Idec, the biotechnology company, said yesterday that it had a fourth-quarter profit of $48.4 million on sales of its Avonex and Tysabri treatments for multiple sclerosis. Net income was equal to 14 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $4.03 a share, or $990.6 million, a year earlier, said Biogen, based in Cambridge, Mass. Revenue jumped to $586 million. Biogen merged with the Idec Pharmaceuticals Corporation in November 2003. Sales of Tysabri totaled $3.12 million in the drug's first weeks and may help Biogen gain market share as growth of the eight-year-old Avonex slows. Tysabri, approved in November, is the most expensive multiple-sclerosis therapy on the market, costing about $23,000 a year. Biogen released its results after markets closed. The shares fell 80 cents, to $66.15. Excluding merger-related costs and other items, the company was expected to earn 36 cents a share, the average estimate of 29 analysts in a Thomson First Call survey.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Napster Shares Fall On Competition Concerns
description: Shares of Napster fell yesterday on concern that increasing competition from other providers of Internet music subscription services like RealNetworks might restrain growth. Napster declined 91 cents, or 9.4 percent, to $8.73. RealNetworks might benefit from growing demand for music on the Internet, Barron's reported, citing investors. Napster said last week that it planned to spend $30 million to promote its monthly music subscription service. The advertising campaign began during the Super Bowl on Sunday. Napster, whose shares jumped 82 percent in the fourth quarter, started offering a subscription service last week offering access to an unlimited number of songs for $14.95 a month. The service competes with RealNetworks' Rhapsody service, which gives members access to more than 900,000 songs for $9.95 a month. ITunes from Apple Computer and the MSN online store from Microsoft both charge 99 cents a song.

Paid Notice: Deaths   COX, LAWANDA FENLASON
description: COX--LaWanda Fenlason, who passed away February 2, 2005, in her home in New York City at the age of 95, was one of the most distinguished, respected, and influential historians of her generation. Her books and articles on Abraham Lincoln, emancipation, and Reconstruction had a profound impact on historical scholarship and became classics that are read by historians in the twenty-first century. She had also resided many years in Bethel, CT. Born in Hoquim, Washington, on September 24, 1909, LaWanda Fenlason earned her B.A. at the University of Oregon in 1931, a masters from Smith College in 1934, and her Ph.D. from the University of California, Berkeley, in 1941. At Smith, she studied with Merle Curti, the pioneering social historian whose commitment to social justice deeply influenced her. Curti became a lifelong friend. In 1940, Cox came to New York City, where her husband, John Cox, accepted a teaching position at City College and she a position at Hunter College. Except for a brief stint at Goucher College in Baltimore (1944-46), she was a member of the history faculty at Hunter and the City University of New York's Graduate Center until her retirement in 1971. She was a legendary teacher at Hunter, influencing two generations of students there. As a doctoral student at Berkeley, Cox studied with John Schuster Taylor, the economist who collaborated with the great documentary photographer Dorthea Lang to study of the plight of the impoverished agricultural workers who migrated to California to escape the ravages of the Dust Bowl and Great Depression. Taking up Taylor's challenge, Cox completed a pioneering study of agricultural labor in the United States as her dissertation. Cox's work on agricultural labor led her to study the plight of former slaves in the post-Civil War South and, ultimately, Reconstruction policy and politics. Her scholarly writing dramatically revised understanding of Reconstruction. Civil rights was the era's defining issue, she demonstrated, not merely a product of Republican vindictiveness toward the South or a smoke screen to obscure the party's efforts to advance the interests of big business. The most complete and eloquent statement of her position came in Politics, Principle, and Prejudice, 1865-1866: Dilemma of Reconstruction America, which was published in 1963 by the Free Press and won the American Historical Association's John H. Dunning Prize. Subsequent work, including Reconstruction, the Negro, and the New South, published by Harper & Row in 1971, extended the argument to emphasize the farreaching--if hotly contested--changes Reconstruction era civil rights policy effected. Cox was also a highly influential Lincoln scholar. In Lincoln and Black Freedom, which appeared in 1981, she boldly challenged the reigning scholarly consensus that held that Lincoln was, at best, a reluctant emancipator. Cox argued that Lincoln's circumspect and indirect style of leadership--while highly effective in advancing the cause of black freedom--had misled historians about his commitment to emancipation and critical role in achieving it. While acknowledging the role African Americans themselves played in ending slavery, her characteristically meticulous research and careful reading of the sources made a compelling case for Lincoln's pivotal role in emancipation and commitment to civil rights for the former slaves. Throughout the 1980s, Cox remained an active scholar, conducting research and publishing essays that examined the demise of Reconstruction and the nation's failure to achieve substantive freedom for former slaves. She also conceived and guided the Symposium on Emancipation and Its Aftermath, which met annually in New York City from 1979 to 1989. A lively forum, it offered an opportunity for scholars to present workin-progress and served as an incubator for a number of important studies that appeared in the 1980s and 1990s. Failing vision brought an end to Cox's historical research and writing in 1989. Nevertheless, in a career that spanned almost fifty years, she left an indelible imprint on the field of Reconstruction, Lincoln studies, and American history more generally. While some of her contemporaries published more, few produced scholarship that equaled hers in its originality, depth of research, analytical power, and enduring significance. Few historians of any generation can equal the crisp lucidity of her writing and analysis. And perhaps no historian was as generous in nurturing the work of young scholars. She was preceded in death by her husband, John Cox, and is survived by her niece, Joan Mason of Los Angeles. A graveside service will be held Friday afternoon, February 11, 2005, at 1:30, at Center Cemetery, Bethel. There are no calling hours. The Bethel Funeral Home of Hull Funeral Service, 215 Greenwood Ave., Bethel, is handling arrangements.

description: KATZ--Rabbi Dr. Michael. The administration, faculty, students, and alumni of Yeshiva University and its affiliate, Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary, record with grief the passing of one of its longest serving and most beloved professors of Talmud and Bible, who was a Rosh Yeshiva for 59 years and the first Rosh Yeshiva ever appointed to the Bible faculty of Yeshiva College. He also served as spiritual leader of Congregation Petach Tikvah, Bronx, NY for 20 years. Born in Amdur Grodna, Poland, he was the scion of the world-renowned Chief Rabbi of Petach Tikvah, Israel, Rabbi Reuven Katz, and brother of distinguished scholars and rabbinic leaders, all of blessed memory. He was ordained by Israel's Chief Rabbis Avram Yitzhak Kook and Yitzchak Isaac Herzog, as well as by Rabbi Avigdor Amiel, Chief Rabbi of Tel Aviv, and Rabbi Issar Zalman Meltzer of Eitz Chaim Yeshiva, Jerusalem. He earned a Teacher's License at Hebrew University in 1940, was a graduate of Yeshiva College, BA'45, and Bernard Revel Graduate School, DHL '63. He was the respected author of several erudite volumes. He was a father figure and friend to thousands of students. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his beloved wife of 59 years, Rebbetzin Hinda Katz, to their children: Zahava (and Michael) Jeff, and Yitzchak (and Elaine) Katz, and to their 6 grandchildren and 3 great grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees

Called "Cooking and Gender in Postwar America," it includes cookbooks for single working women, for example, and books on the role of cooking in seduction. Many are owned by Jeffrey Makala, a former assistant archivist at the university, who wrote that the collection, "while perhaps being the pulp fiction of the cookbook world, provides ample opportunity for serious study as social texts."

Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Flaw Suspected In Home Syringes
description: Health officials said yesterday that six people receiving home health care had become infected after using syringes that may have been contaminated. On Jan. 31, the Food and Drug Administration recalled the syringes, which are manufactured by IV Flush and distributed by Pinnacle Medical Supply, saying they may have been contaminated. The product label reads, in part, "IV Flush Dallas, TX." So far, however, investigators from the city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene have found only one home health care agency that received the syringes, and they are working to contact all of the agency's clients. The bacterial infection that is involved typically results in fever, low blood pressure and general malaise. Officials are still determining how many of the syringes made it to New York. Marc Santora (NYT)

The Coming Clash Over Kirkuk
description: Atlanta - AS the Iraqis turn their focus from holding elections to writing a constitution, the make-or-break issue for their nation may be the city of Kirkuk. Situated next to Iraq's northern oil fields, Kirkuk is a setting for all the ethnic-sectarian conflicts that are the historic reality of Iraq -- Muslim against Christian, Sunni against Shiite, Kurd against Arab. It is also home to the Turkmens, who are the ethnic cousins of the Turks and look to a willing Turkey as their protector. In their fierce competition for the right to claim Kirkuk, the Turkmens and the Kurds threaten to turn Iraqi internal politics into a regional conflict.

Paid Notice: Deaths   GEYER, HAROLD CARL, JR.
description: GEYER--Harold Carl, Jr. Of Chilmark, MA, died February 3, 2005 on Martha's Vineyard at age 99. A Phi Beta Kappa, he graduated from Yale University in 1926 and went on to earn an MFA in its School of Architecture in 1930. Raconteur extraordinaire, poet, lecturer, painter, writer, photographer and master of etching, he first fused his varied talents while living in his beloved Troyes, France. His first illustrated book was All Men Have Loved Thee, A Song of France. Mr. Geyer inaugurated the Etching Workshop in New York's Town Hall. After the publication of his second book, The Long Way Home, he was elected an Associate of the National Academy of Design. He created over 200 etchings, many of which are exhibited in national collections in Washington and Paris. He traveled throughout Europe, South and North America and incorporating wit, photographs and personal experience lectured to appreciative audiences all over the world. He married Ina Helen Doane, DDS in 1949 and continued living in New York City and Martha's Vineyard until her retirement. Mr. Geyer was born in Boonton, New Jersey on August 16, 1905 of Harold Carl Geyer and Mary B. Geyer. A memorial service will be held in the First Congregational Church of West Tisbury, West Tisbury on Saturday, February 12, at 11 A.M. Donations may be made in his memory to the Vineyard Nursing Association, PO Box 2568, Oak Bluffs, MA 02557. For information, contact the Chapman, Cole & Gleason Funeral Home, Oak Bluffs. For online guest book and information visit www.ccgfuneralhome.com

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Level 3 Posts Narrower Loss
description: Level 3 Communications Inc., which operates a fiber optic telecommunications network, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter loss narrowed as sales rose, but warned that communications revenue would shrink in 2005. Shares of Level 3 sank 35 cents, to $2.64. For the fourth quarter, the company, based in Broomfield, Colo., posted a net loss of $77 million, or 11 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $121 million, or 18 cents a share, a year earlier. Level 3 said the latest results included a $50 million gain after the retirement of debt associated with a tender offer completed in December and a $9 million gain on the sale of investments. These items were partly offset by a $14 million lease-impairment charge. Revenue rose 7 percent to $1.06 billion, from $988 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BUCKLEY, SONJA M., MD
description: BUCKLEY--Sonja M., MD was born in Zurich, Switzerland. She married an American citizen, John J. Buckley in 1941 while both were in medical school. Both graduated with medical degrees in 1944. Dr. John J. Buckley left for the Johns Hopkins University in 1945, and Dr. Buckley joined him in 1947. Dr. Buckley was professionally active in engagements such as Department of Microbiology, the Johns Hopkins University, New York State Department of Health, and the Sloan - Kettering Memorial Cancer Center, New York. Dr. Buckley was a staff member of the Rockefeller Foundation (RF) from 1957 to 1974. As a staff member of the Rockefeller Foundation, Dr. Buckley isolated the Lassa virus (the etiologic agent of Lassa fever) in 1969 at the Yale Arbovirus Research Unit (YARU), Dept. of Epidemiology and Public Health, Yale University School of Medicine, New Haven, CT. She was a Research Affiliate at Yale until 1994. She retired in 1999 at Roland Park Place, Baltimore, MD. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Thomas More R.C. title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Aquarius Profit Declines
description: Aquarius Platinum Ltd., which mines platinum and palladium in South Africa and Zimbabwe, said fiscal first-half profit plunged 59 percent after output dropped and costs rose. Aquarius, which is based in Bermuda, said it produced 145,714 ounces of platinum, palladium and other metals, down 19 percent from a year earlier. Production fell at the Marikana mine in South Africa because of operational difficulties and poorer-quality ore.

title: Arts, Briefly; Harry Potter Crosses Wands With the U.S. Army
description: With hot topics that include "maintenance advisory for new helmet" and "old M2 barrel supports," it is not unusual for Preventive Maintenance Monthly, a 50-year-old publication of the Army Materiel Command at Fort Belvoir, Va., to try to spice up its advice to the troops with cartoon drawings. But this month, eyebrows levitated in Britain when the color cartoons in an article about the maintenance of brooms and other supplies featured a boy with black hair and round glasses named Topper and his friends and teachers at the Mogmarts School of Magic in England, an institution headed by a Professor Rumbledore. "At Mogmarts wands need a light coating of LC40 once a week," the article advised. "Wizards who do battle with death-eaters need to polish their wands daily." Now lawyers for J.K. Rowling, the author of the perennially best-selling Harry Potter novels, are investigating a possible breach of copyright, something they say they take very seriously. Tesia Williams, a spokeswoman for the Army Materiel Command, said yesterday that its "intellectual-property-law attorneys indicated that the illustrations in question were permissible parody under the fair use exception to a copyright owner's exclusive rights." After discussions between the Army and Ms. Rowling's representatives, Ms. Williams said, "We are not going to use the likeness of 'Harry Potter' characters again." LIZETTE ALVAREZ

Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Rebuilt Ferry Terminal Opens
description: City officials formally opened the new Whitehall Ferry Terminal yesterday, completing a $201 million project begun after a fire badly damaged the old Staten Island Ferry terminal in September 1991. The new terminal, which opened to the public last month, includes a 75-foot-high entry hall, solar energy panels that supply power to the building and new connections to the No. 1 and No. 9 subway lines at South Ferry. It encompasses 200,000 square feet, including a 19,000-square-foot waiting room, and is expected to serve 65,000 travelers a day. On the other side of the harbor, the city's Department of Transportation expects to complete the rebuilding of the St. George Terminal in the spring. The principal designer, Frederic Schwartz Architects, won a competition held in October 1992. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: 2 Officers Cleared Of Abuse Charges
description: In separate incidents in the Bronx, two men have pleaded guilty to falsely accusing police officers of using excessive force to obtain confessions, a police official said yesterday. Jose Peralta, 26, accused officers of the 41st Precinct of burning his arms and striking him with a stick to elicit a robbery confession after arresting him in November 2002, said the official, Capt. Tim McCarthy of the Internal Affairs Bureau. Investigators reviewed a videotape of the robbery confession and noticed that there were no burns on Mr. Peralta's arms at the time of the confession, and he later admitted that he had been burned by a fellow inmate and not by the police, Captain McCarthy said. In a separate incident, Andrew Facey, 19, accused officers in the 47th Precinct of sexually abusing him after arresting him on a trespassing charge in September 2004. He pleaded guilty last month to a charge of filing a false report, Captain McCarthy said. Since 1997, there have been 30 allegations of excessive force by police officers, and 5 of those have resulted in arrests, Captain McCarthy said. Michael Brick (NYT)

Paid Notice: Deaths   BOXER, ROBERT, M.D.
description: BOXER--Robert, M.D. The Department of Pediatrics of the Schneider Children's Hospital mourns the loss of our beloved friend and colleague, Robert Boxer, MD. Dr. Boxer was a gifted pediatric cardiologist and intensivist who was totally committed to providing exceptional and compassionate care to his patients. He was a model to be emulated in his clinical commitment to patients and was a talented teacher of fellows, residents and medical students. He was a remarkably kind and warm individual who was loved by all who came in contact with him: physicians, students, nurses, patients and their families. He leaves a remarkable legacy to his colleagues, students and to the thousands of seriously ill children whose lives were affected by his care. His passing leaves a large void in both the medical community and the community at large. Our thoughts and prayers go out to his beloved wife, Harriet Boxer, MD, and hischildren, Joshua and Sarah. description: Mondays at 10 p.m. used to belong exclusively to CBS's "CSI: Miami." And while that show is often Monday's most watched program, ABC's and NBC's new entries in that time period are forcing it to share the wealth. On the first Monday of the February sweeps period, CBS won the night in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49. And indeed, "CSI: Miami" brought in the most viewers of all the prime-time offerings. During its fall run, "CSI: Miami" regularly attracted more than 20 million viewers for its original episodes, but the audience for Monday's show, in which Horatio Caine (David Caruso) and the gang tracked down counterfeiters in one case and a murderous swinger in another, drew an estimated 18.44 million. During the same hour, ABC's "Supernanny" continued its run as a solid new performer, bringing in an estimated 11.4 million viewers. And also in the 10 p.m. period, NBC's "Medium," the show that poses the biggest challenge to "CSI: Miami" because it, too, is a crime series, drew an audience estimated at 14.01 million. KATE AURTHUR

title: Arts, Briefly; The Game Climbs Back
description: The Game, the newest West Coast rap phenomenon, made a big splash two weeks ago with the release of his debut album, "The Documentary" (Interscope), but when sales dropped more than 50 percent the next week, it slipped to No.2. The album returned to the top spot on Billboard's chart this week, though sales were a moderate 190,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The runner-up this week is a surprise: Tina Turner's "All the Best" (Capitol), a two-disc anthology, sold 121,000 copies, beating her previous chart high of No.3 for "Private Dancer" in 1984. Kenny Chesney's "Be as You Are" (BNA), which topped the chart last week, fell to No.4, selling 109,000 copies. BORDERS SAYS HOLIDAY SHOPPERS LIFTED EARNINGS
description: The Borders Group said yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings rose as holiday shoppers bought more books and DVD's. The company forecast that profit would increase in the new fiscal year. Net income in the quarter ended Jan. 23 climbed to $1.61 to $1.62 a share, from $1.50 a year earlier, the company, which is based in Ann Arbor, Mich., said in a preliminary earnings statement. Sales rose 4.3 percent, to $1.37 billion. Borders said it probably earned $1.69 to $1.72 a share in the year ended Jan. 23. The company expects profit in the new fiscal year to rise to $1.85 to $1.92 a share and sales to increase about 7 percent. Analysts expected earnings of $1.72 last year and $1.91 this year. Shares of Borders, which trails Barnes & Noble Inc. in sales, fell 62 cents, to $26.48.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CRABTREE, ROBERT EDWARD, SR.
description: CRABTREE--Robert Edward, Sr. Of Greenwich, CT and Vero Beach, FL died of heart failure at his home on Wednesday, February 9, 2005. He was an active automobile executive for Crabtree Automotive Group. Mr. Crabtree was born in New York on October 11, 1926. He was a graduate of the United States Merchant Marine Academy, and served in WWII. An exceptional athlete, he held the Iona Prep 220 and 440 track record for over 20 years. He also competed in the Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden. An avid skier and golfer, he was a member at the Stanwich Club, Double Eagle, Windsor, Red Stick, John's Island Club, Quail Valley River Club, and Stratton Mountain Club. His automotive career spanned 52 years. Mr Crabtree became the youngest Dodge dealer in the country at only 26 years of age when he succeeded his father, Joseph Clarke Crabtree, founder of Crabtree Motors, a ChryslerPlymouth, and Dodge dealer in New Rochelle, NY. In 1971, he became one of the original Toyota Dealers in the Eastern United States. He later built his business in New Rochelle to include Ford, Jaguar, Nissan, Cadillac, Mitsubishi, MG, Triumph, and Suzuki. Subsequently, he sold his Westchester properties to expand into Connecticut with Colonial Toyota, Westport Toyota, Lexus of Westport, Derby Dodge, Shelton Mitsubishi, and Crabtree Cadillac, Subaru, Kia. Mr. Crabtree was a devoted husband, father and grandfather. His greatest love was his family. Robert is survived by his wife, June Langran Crabtree, and four children, Margaret "Muffy" Lyster of Versailles, KY; Constance "Pinky" Markey of Greenwich, CT, Joseph Crabtree of Huntington, CT, and Robert Crabtree, Jr. of Easton, CT. He was pre-deceased by his son Michael Crabtree. In addition, Robert Crabtree is survived by his step children, Marilyn Juan of Greenwich, CT, and Walter Peek of Rye, NY, plus thirteen grandchildren; Meredith Joncs, Gray Lyster, Bryan Lyster, T.J. Markey, Kelly Markey, Sarah Crabtree, Morgan Crabtree, Emily Crabtree, Joseph Crabtree, Michaela Crabtree, Maggie Crabtree, Michael Crabtree, and Katie Crabtree, three step grandchildren Walter Peek, Alex Juan and Elizabeth Juan, as well as his brother, Richard Crabtree. Viewing will be at St. Michael's Church on Friday, February 11, from 4 to 9 PM. Services will also be held at St. Michael's Church on Saturday, February 12, at 11:00 AM. Contributions may be sent to St. Michael's Church, 469 North Street, Greenwich, CT 06830.

title: Arts, Briefly; Televising Torture
description: Will torture be a ratings winner? Channel 4, the British commercial channel, has scheduled "Guantnamo Guidebook," a series of four programs on the subject. One, to be broadcast in March, will examine the effectiveness of the interrogation techniques that freed inmates say were used by the United States military in its internment camp at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba. Seven rigidly screened volunteers, three of them Muslims, were subjected over the course of 48 hours to techniques based on information from declassified United States government documents and approved in writing by Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, right, a spokesman for the channel said. The effects of sleep deprivation, exposure to extremes of temperature, removal of clothing, and prolonged and painful stress positions, induced by expert interrogators from the United States, are investigated. Dorothy Byrne, head of news and current affairs at Channel 4, said the series, which includes a film by the first British lawyer allowed into Guantnamo, Clive Stafford Smith, challenges viewers to consider: "Is such torture ever justified? Does it work? How are the values of Western society undermined by involvement in torture?" PAM KENT

description: TURI--Dr. Paul George. 87, on February 7, 2005. Winner of the 1934 Hungarian national mathematics prize, denied entry to medical school under fascist laws and confined to slave labor during World War II, he escaped to America in 1956. He worked for three decades as a Ph.D. research chemist in pharmaceutical sciences at Sandoz (Novartis). An optimist despite adversity, a passionate traveler with a far-ranging intellect, he was a scientist, Latin scholar, poet, chess player and philosopher. description: The city teachers' union voted overwhelmingly last night to approve a plan to open and operate two charter schools, embracing an alternative form of education often viewed as a threat to unionized school employees. The union, the United Federation of Teachers, plans to apply to the State Board of Regents for charters to operate a kindergarten-to-5th-grade school and a 6th-to-12th-grade school in East New York, Brooklyn. The union hopes to open the elementary school in September, and officials said teachers would work under the existing teachers' contract in part to rebut critics who say the contract is an obstacle to running successful schools.
