title: Editors' Choice
Paid Notice: Deaths   HAGEDORN, HORACE
description: HAGEDORN--Horace. The Buckley Country Day School community mourns the passing of our good friend Horace Hagedorn. As a former parent and grandparent, and member of the Board of Trustees from 1986 to 1992, Horace shared his wisdom and leadership in the areas of marketing, personnel, development, long-range planning and on various ad-hoc committees. He is remembered by his colleagues on the Board as "a gentleman and a gentle man who in a quiet way had the power to get things done and did." In 1988, he generously established a scholarship fund to aid Buckley's commitment to diversity. Through this endowed fund, students of color who exhibit outstanding scholarship and leadership are afforded the opportunity to benefit from Buckley's superior education. It was with great pride that he supported the philanthropic endeavors of his son James '71 who continued the family legacy with the establishment of the Hagedorn Library Learning Center in 2000 on Buckley's campus. The entire Buckley community expresses heartfelt condolences to his family. We will remember him for the twinkle in his eye and celebrate his life for the difference he made and the joy that he brought to so many. The Board, Faculty, Staff, Students and Families of Buckley Country Day School

title: The Art of the Upchuck

Perhaps that's because of reality television, with its penchant for recreational drinking and upchuck-inducing eating competitions. Or maybe it's the clinical approach the "CSI" shows take to bodily fluids. "I watch 'CSI,' and I just go, 'Oh, my God,"' Mr. Shore said. Whatever the reason, Tuesday's episode of "House" features a man not only vomiting prodigiously, but also doing so on another person. How do they film that? It takes several camera angles, some yogurt and a machine. Kate Aurthur talked to the people who made it work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COMINS, FREDERIC MARSHALL
description: COMINS--Frederic Marshall, of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., died peacefully, at home, February 8th, after a long battle with Prostate Cancer. Born in New York City, October 8, 1916, Fred graduated from Fieldston School in 1933 and graduated Magna Cum Laude, in Economic Theory, from Harvard College in 1937. Fred then worked several years, in manufacturing, in Manila, P.I. From 1942-1945 he served with the rank of Major and Tank Commander in WW II under Brigadier General Willard Holbrook, with the 11th Armored Division of the 3rd Army. He also served under General George Patton at the Battle of the Bulge. He was awarded the Bronze Star. With the first group of American soldiers, of the 11th Armored Division, Fred opened the gates of the Mauthausen Concentration Camp, in Austria, and freed the prisoners at the war's end. Fred retired from the Army in 1946 as a Lt. Colonel. Most of his business life was spent as a distributor for RCA. For many years, he was a member of the Schools and Scholarship Committees, at Harvard University, in Cambridge, MA. A past President of the Harvard Club, of New Jersey, and former member of the Boards of the Harmonie Club, and the Harvard Club, both of NYC. Longtime member of the Hollywood Golf Club, Deal, NJ, and Sunningdale CC, Scarsdale, NY. Fred and his family lived for many years in Short Hills, NJ, and at 870 United Nations Plaza, in NYC. He retired from business in 1995 and then worked Pro Bono for SCORE (Service Core of Retired Executives). Beloved and devoted husband, for 57 years, of Edith Krich Comins, he leaves their three sons, Frederic Jr., of Fort Myers, FL, Bruce Max, of Woodstock, VT., and Andrew M., of Los Angeles, CA., four grandsons, Justin Scot, Jamison, Jordan, and Drew Comins, and two nieces, Alice Tepper Marlin and Nancy Moyer.

title: A Liberal in Damascus
description: When I first met Ammar Abdulhamid in Washington in the fall, the 38-year-old Syrian novelist, poet and liberal dissident had Damascus on his mind. He had received word from his wife back in Syria that the political situation at home was becoming more precarious for rights activists like himself. As a fellow at the Brookings Institution, he'd been meeting with leading figures in the Bush administration and writing articles in the Arab and Western presses that were sharply critical of the Syrian government; he simply didn't know what to expect on his return. Now, sitting here in a Damascus coffeehouse in late January a week after his return, he is telling me that he had found reason for optimism about the country's future in the least likely of places.

title: Inside the List
description: SMARTY-PANTS: If the name Ann Brashares means nothing to you, you probably don't have a teenage girl in your house. Brashares, who is 37 and lives in New York, has published two enormously popular young-adult novels, "The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants" and "The Second Summer of the Sisterhood," both of which read like episodes of "My So-Called Life" that have been flecked with pixie dust. (Her books are No. 2 in a combined ranking on the children's series list, which appears this week on Page 18.) Brashares's novels are about four close friends who negotiate the final years of high school with the help of some slightly magical jeans. (What's magical about them? They fit each of the girls, who have different body sizes, perfectly.) The third novel in this series, "Girls in Pants," is just out. It includes a list of the rules the girls have concocted to govern the use of their empowering pants, and it's a list that captures a bit of Brashares's crisp comic tone. Rule No. 2 reads: "You must never double-cuff the Pants. It's tacky. There will never be a time when this will not be tacky." Yet these books don't shy away from weightier issues, among them sex. Here is Rule No. 4: "You must never let a boy take off the Pants (although you may take them off yourself in his presence)." Brashares, who worked in publishing before writing her first book, is the product of a pretty good education: she attended the Sidwell Friends School in Washington and was a philosophy major at Barnard. The young women in "Girls in Pants" have more than bluejeans and boys on their minds, too. They are off, we learn, to Brown, Williams, N.Y.U. film school and the Rhode Island School of Design.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOHMAN, SIDNEY IRVING
description: LOHMAN--Sidney Irving, 95, died on February 3. Sidney had a 31 year career with the New York Times starting in 1941. He held various positions until his retirement in 1972. He had a byline for many years working in the Radio Department. It became the Radio and Television Department as TV broadcasting expanded. His column was call "News and Notes from the Studios," and wrote of industry trends including the expansion of sports coverage and the advent of color television. Later he did stints on the Times's international edition, retiring as a copy editor for WQXR. He had a busy retirement collecting stamps, gardening and volunteering with community groups. Sid was loved for his good humor, generosity and affection for shaggy dog stories. He was predeceased by his wife, Sarah Axelrod Lohman, with whom he spent many happy years in their apartment in New York's Lower East Side and their cottage in Lake Carmel, NY. He is survived by his son, Philip and wife Geraldeen of Connecticut, granddaughter Melissa and her husband David Arons of Brooklyn. He was greatly served during his later years in Florida by his niece and her husband, Dr. Michael and Arlene McBride. He was laid to rest beside Sarah on Monday, February 7. He will be missed.

description: Behold the slam dunk, the pulse-quickening, throw-it-down, in-your-face signature move of the National Basketball Association. The dunk is a declaration of power and dominance, of machismo. In a team game, an ensemble of five players a side, it is an expression of self. In a sport devoted to selling sneakers, the dunk is a marketing tour de force, the money shot at the end of every worthy basketball sequence. (When you see the shoes in the 30-second spot, what is the wearer of those shoes always doing?) Next weekend in Denver, the cultural moment that is the N.B.A. All-Star Game will take place, an event set annually amid a weekend of concerts, lavish parties and showy displays of fashion. On such a big stage (and with defensive standards momentarily relaxed), the game itself is sure to be a veritable dunkathon, a string of self-satisfied throw-downs by the league's biggest stars. If I had my way, at the conclusion of the game the dunk would be taken out of commission. Banned as a first step toward rescuing a game that has strayed far from its roots, fundamentals and essential appeal.

title: PAPERBACK ROW
description: DANCING WITH CUBA: A Memoir of the Revolution, by Alma Guillermoprieto. (Vintage, $13.) Guillermoprieto, a distinguished writer on Latin America, vividly recounts her six-month stay in Cuba in 1970, teaching modern dance at the state-run National Schools of the Arts in Havana. Those chaotic days are reconstructed here with a lively eye for detail: from mirrorless dance studios and enthusiastic but poorly trained students to the author's political coming-of-age amid revolutionary upheaval. Last year our critic, Katha Pollitt, said that Guillermoprieto (at right) "uses dance as a lens through which to explore the aspirations and injustices and contradictions of a whole society. It's a fresh and lively perspective." Ana Menndez's deft first novel, LOVING CHE (Grove, $12), about an unnamed narrator's journeys to Cuba in search of the mother she never knew, captures the now mythic early days of Cuba's revolution and the desperate reality that has since set in.

description: One man was stabbed to death and two others were wounded outside a West Side restaurant early yesterday, and a restaurant worker was later arrested in the attack, the police said. According to investigators, the dead man, Michael Ruocco, 27, of 1900 Lexington Avenue, in East Harlem, was celebrating a friend's birthday when he and his companions got into an argument with another group in the restaurant, at 798 Ninth Avenue near 53rd Street, about 3:40 a.m. The fight moved outside, investigators said, and the restaurant worker, Gabriel Cazares, 20, of Queens, stabbed Mr. Ruocco and two others, Joebannie Solis, 16, of Brooklyn, who was hospitalized in critical condition at New York Hospital, and Eric Bedell, 30, of Medford, N.Y., who the police said tried to stop the fight, who was in stable condition. Mr. Cazares was later arrested at his home. Michael Wilson (NYT)

"We're just now beginning that process," a Hall of Fame spokeswoman, Liz Thiels, said last week. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Burned In Basement Fire
description: A 74-year-old man was severely burned yesterday in an early-morning fire in his basement apartment in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn, a Fire Department spokesman said. The man, whose name was not released by the authorities, was pulled from the apartment at 128 Bay 50th Street by Capt. Christopher Joyce of Engine Company 318, and taken to Staten Island University Hospital, where he was treated for burns over 20 percent of his body, said the spokesman, Paul Iannizzotto. When Engine 318 arrived at the fire, which was reported at 2:41 a.m., its members were notified that the man was trapped inside, Mr. Iannizzotto said. Captain Joyce ran into the burning basement, found the man and carried him outside. Mr. Iannizzotto said investigators found that the apartment was an illegal subterranean dwelling, and that the cause of the fire was an overloaded electric cord. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

A former advertising executive with Ted Bates & Co. and Ally & Gargano, his warmth and provocative humor continue to live in the memories of those who knew him. Despite many personal struggles, he generously and indiscriminately reached out to help others. He is survived by his brother Robert Mullan; his daughter Alexandra Jain; his son Peter Mullan; his grandchildren, Nicolas and Katherine Jain; and his friends. Memorial service will be held Tuesday, February 22, at 2:00 at St. James Church, 865 Madison Ave, NYC. Donations in his memory may be made to The Doe Fund, 232 East 84th St., NYC 10028.

title: Umpires Still Taking Sides
description: The scandal of state election officials who are also political partisans has reached a new low. California's secretary of state announced his resignation this month amid charges that his office spent federal money on Democratic Party politics, and the National Association of Secretaries of State passed a resolution allowing its members to continue their partisan activities. There is an urgent need to fix this mess; if election officials won't do it, Congress must act to protect the integrity of federal elections.

title: Arthur Miller: Death of a Legend
description: For anyone who has ever spent an evening absorbed in "Death of a Salesman," watching Willy Loman's ineffably sad decline, there should be little doubt about Arthur Miller's genius. Still, when the mourning ends for Mr. Miller, who died Thursday, the question of the timelessness of his work will remain. Mr. Miller's career had its share of misfires, but on the strength of his best plays, he seems as destined for immortality as his most famous character was for obscurity.

title: Arts, Briefly; A Rare Box Office Hat Trick
description: Surprise: a romantic comedy opened big on Valentine's Day weekend. "Hitch," starring Will Smith (in poster at right, receiving a kiss from his co-star, Amber Valletta) as a suave dating coach for nebbishy men, opened at No.1 with $45.3 million in box office receipts, according to studio estimates. That's the second annual big valentine for Sony Pictures, whose "50 First Dates" opened with $45 million over the same weekend last year. But the good news for Sony does not stop there. The studio had the top three films this weekend: "Boogeyman," last week's No.1, landed at No.2 with ticket sales of $10.8 million, and "Are We There Yet?" reached No.3 with $8.5 million. This is the first time in nearly 16 years that a single studio has had a box office trifecta, Sony executives said. (Universal did it in September 1989 with "Sea of Love," "Uncle Buck" and "Parenthood.") This weekend Clint Eastwood's "Million Dollar Baby" (Warner Brothers) kept fighting strong with $7.6 million, bringing it up one spot to No.4, and "Pooh's Heffalump Movie" (Disney) opened at No.5 on sales of just over $6 million. CATHERINE BILLEY

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Advanced Micro Adjusts Some Prices
description: Advanced Micro Devices adjusted the prices of a number of its PC and server processors yesterday. The chip maker, in a regularly scheduled price adjustment, followed the introduction of higher-performance Opteron server chips with cuts of up to 35 percent on existing Opterons. The company also lowered the prices of its Athlon 64 chips for desktop and notebook PC's by as much as 34 percent and cut its Sempron value chips 6 percent to 19 percent. But in a twist, it also raised prices slightly on a handful of processors, including a pair of Athlon MP server chips and a Sempron for desktop PC's. Most of the Opteron price moves resulted in cuts of 18 percent or more. The chip maker lowered prices on Opteron 800 processors, chips it designed to fit into servers with four or more processors, by up to 25 percent. The Opteron 848, for example, went down 25 percent, to $873, from $1,165. Advanced Micro enacted some of the biggest price changes in its Opteron 200 line for dual processor servers and workstations. It cut between 19 percent and 34 percent off those chips' prices, dropping the Opteron 244 to $209 and the Opteron 248 to $455, a 34 percent reduction for each. The Opteron 150, part of the Opteron line for single-processor servers and workstations, had the biggest drop. Its price was lowered 35 percent, to $417. A.M.D. kept the price of its flagship desktop processor, the Athlon 64 FX-55, at $827. But it cut prices by up to 34 percent on many of the rest of its desktop Athlon 64's.

title: Arts, Briefly; Grammys Win but Lose
description: The broadcast of the 47th Annual Grammy Awards yielded a win for CBS on Sunday night. According to Nielsen's overnight ratings, the music show drew an average of 19.41 million viewers from 8 p.m. to 11:30 p.m. This year's ceremony -- during which the audience saw Ray Charles garner posthumous awards in eight categories, as well as CBS indulging in multiple plugs for the forthcoming movie "Sahara" by its Viacom sibling, Paramount -- was down about 25 percent in viewership from last year's broadcast. Among 18-to-49-year-olds, the Grammys brought in its lowest number in eight years, and in that category, CBS barely edged out ABC for the night. At 9 p.m., ABC's "Desperate Housewives" was slightly lower than usual, though it was still the most-watched hour of the evening: an audience of 22.13 million watched the fastidious Bree Van De Camp (Marcia Cross) run a pair of handcuffs through the dishwasher in preparation to indulge her husband's sexual proclivities. title: Arts, Briefly; Making Movies
description: Columbia Pictures announced yesterday that Deborah Schindler and Elvis Mitchell would become executive production consultants in charge of development and production for the studio's New York office. They have already acquired the rights to remake the new documentary "Ring of Fire: The Emile Griffith Story" into a feature film. Ms. Schindler, who began her career as Martin Scorsese's assistant in the 1980's, was head of Red Om Films and produced features with Julia Roberts for Revolution Films. Mr. Mitchell has been a film critic for several publications, most recently for The New York Times from January 2000 until April 2004. He briefly served as director of development for Paramount in the early 1990's. Reached by phone, Ms. Schindler said: "Our mandate is to create our own entity, unlike New York offices have been in the past. We're going to make films, not just develop them." "Ring of Fire," directed and produced by Dan Klores and Ron Berger, tells the story of the boxer who beat his ring opponent to death in 1962. It was acquired at the Sundance Festival by NBC-Universal and is to be broadcast April 20 on the USA Network. Mr. Klores will produce the remake with Scott Rudin. JOEL TOPCIK

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Agilent Posts 45% Profit Increase
description: Agilent Technologies, the world's biggest maker of scientific testing equipment, said yesterday that first-quarter profit rose 45 percent as sales of biological and chemical instruments increased. Net income climbed to $103 million, or 21 cents a share, in the period that ended Jan. 31, from $71 million, or 14 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Revenue at the company, based in Palo Alto, Calif., rose less than 1 percent, to $1.66 billion, from $1.64 billion. The chief executive, Edward W. Barnholt, relied on the company's life sciences and chemical analysis businesses to help Agilent post its sixth consecutive period of net income after seven quarterly losses. Agilent's chip-making clients pared orders last year to work off inventory gluts, Mr. Barnholt said in December. Agilent said it expected second-quarter revenue of $1.6 billion to $1.7 billion and operating profit, or earnings before interest and taxes, of 18 cents to 23 cents a share. Excluding some costs, first-quarter profit would have been 20 cents a share, topping 19 cents, the average estimate of 10 analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Shares of Agilent rose 30 cents, to $24.02. Mr. Barnholt, who oversaw Agilent's spinoff from the Hewlett-Packard Company in 1999 and 2000, will retire March 1. William P. Sullivan, the company's chief operating officer, will succeed him.

title: Expense Account Alert
description: EXPENSE ACCOUNT ALERT -- Almost half of the business travelers in Europe and the United States who were questioned in a survey released yesterday by American Express say their companies have tightened travel-spending policies over the last two to three years. More than a third say their travel and entertainment expense accounts are getting greater scrutiny. With good reason, apparently: more than a third believe it is either "somewhat" or "quite" common for business travelers to submit expense accounts with "one or more completely false or bogus charges." But most road warriors also disapprove of such fraud. Those in the United States expressed the strongest support (77 percent) for careful audits of expense reports and receipts, while 72 percent in Britain agreed, as did 70 percent in Germany and 64 percent in France. For all their stepped-up vigilance, companies do seem to be loosening up on restrictions against traveling in style. In a survey conducted by the National Business Travel Association and the Travel Industry Association of America, the proportion of corporate travelers who reported their employers restricted the class they could travel on fell to 50 percent last year from 56 percent in 2002. The decline reflected a better economy and "a departure from severe travel restrictions" put into effect after the 2001 terrorist attacks, the survey said.

description: Chris Rock, right, is stirring controversy even before a word of his monologue as Oscar host is heard, which may be exactly what the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences hoped for. The uncensored comic was criticized by the Drudge Report Web site over the weekend for making what it called anti-gay comments, but the academy issued a statement yesterday defending Mr. Rock's weeks-old comments that "are meant to be humorous digs at a show that some people, obviously including Chris himself, think may be a bit too stuffy." Mr. Rock's statement at a news conference on Jan. 21 in Los Angeles for foreign media noted, according to Drudge: "What straight black man sits there and watches the Oscars? Show me one." A spokesman for the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation declined to comment officially but observed that the comment seemed to be aimed more at the Oscars than against gays. The academy denied that members had complained about Mr. Rock's remarks and added: "We can't wait to watch Chris Rock perform on Feb. 27, and we'll be holding on to our hats, too." SHARON WAXMAN

description: The yacht being used to train crew members for South Africa's entry in the 2007 America's Cup competition struck a Southern right whale off Cape Town, injuring the skipper and the navigator. The racing yacht, Shosholoza, was traveling at 10 knots when its keel, which extends some 13 feet below the surface, collided with the whale and brought the boat to a dead stop. The skipper, Geoff Meek, and the navigator, Marc Lagesse, were at the port and starboard steering wheels, both of which were snapped off when they were thrown into them. A third crewman, Charles Nankin, was thrown overboard but was picked up by an accompanying crew boat. A team spokeswoman said the keel was damaged; injuries to the whale, which surfaced nearby after the impact, remain unknown. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLF, HENRY
description: WOLF--Henry. The Trustees, faculty, staff, and students of New School University and Parsons School of Design express their deep sadness at the sudden loss of Henry Wolf. An influential designer, photographer, and art director, Henry Wolf was among the shapers of twentieth century publication design. He had a long and rich association with Parsons, first as a beloved teacher and mentor in the Communication Design Department, and later as a member of the Parsons Board of Governors from 1998 to 2001. In 1996, he was awarded an honorary degree from the University for his outstanding contributions to the field of design, and in 1998 Parsons proudly celebrated his life and work with a retrospective exhibition and lecture series. Henry Wolf was also a philanthropist whose generosity was guided by a passionate interest in the School's past and future. He established a scholarship program that allowed some of the most talented students the privilege of a Parsons education. In every avenue of his engagement with Parsons, he maintained a close interest in the life of students and the academic standards for programs. This kind of broad and deep history with an institution is rare, and Henry Wolf's high standards and determined ideals will continue to have profound influence at Parsons and throughout New School University. We convey our heartfelt condolences to his sister Joan Slawson. Philip Scaturro, Chairman Board of Trustees Bob Kerrey, President New School University Paul Goldberger, Dean Parsons School of Design

Jupitermedia shares rose 41 cents to $17.67. Jupitermedia's chief executive, Alan M. Meckler, said that acquiring the Dynamic Graphics, PictureQuest and Liquid Library brands and making use of Creatas trade shows would help sell more pictures. Jupitermedia has bought three photography companies in the last year. Jupitermedia said it planned to finance the transaction with cash and a line of credit. It will report fourth-quarter earnings today after markets close. The company is expected to post earnings of 15 cents a share, the average estimate of three analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. People taking Thelin for pulmonary arterial hypertension added about 26.5 yards to the distance they could walk in six minutes during the 18-week test, while those on a placebo worsened, the company said. Encysive said it intended to file in April for Food and Drug Administration clearance to sell Thelin, which would be a competitor to Tracleer from Actelion Ltd., which was included in the study. Thelin showed a lower rate of side effects than Tracleer, Encysive said. Stock in Encysive rose $1.29, to $11.80 a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOROSINI, HELEN SIMPSON
description: MOROSINI--Helen Simpson, 71, of Walpole, NH, died February 10, 2005 from complications following surgery for ovarian cancer. Born September 9, 1933 in Boston, MA, the daughter of Mary (Donnelly) and William Simpson, Helen was a graduate of Boston University. Devoted wife and best pal to Charles J. Morosini, Jr., M.D. for 47 years, she and Chuck raised their family and lived for many years in Scarsdale, NY. A great lover of books and a voracious reader, she worked from home as a reviewer for Book - of - the - Month Club while providing a loving home for her family. She later became executive assistant to noted economist Elliot Janeway from 1978 to 1984 and then worked as editor and Sr. vice president at the New York City office of Lloyds of London Press. She and Chuck retired to Walpole in 2000 where she continued to work as a part-time copy editor and at the local library. In addition to her beloved husband, she is survived and deeply missed by her three daughters, Dr. Deborah Morosini-Huschle of Weston, MA, Dana Reeve (widow of Christopher Reeve) of Bedford, NY, and Adrienne Heilman of Harwich, MA, and one brother, William Simpson of Dennis, MA. She also leaves--in body but never in spirit--five cherished grandchildren: James, Peter, Will, Erik and Logan who will always adore and remember their loving and funny "Nonni." A memorial service to celebrate Helen's life will be held at 2:30 PM on Saturday, March 5, at Alyson's Orchard, Walpole, NH. Donations in her name can be made to the Christopher Reeve Paralysis Foundation, www.christopherreeve.org

title: Arts, Briefly; Shakespeare and The Science of Love
description: When it comes to understanding love, Shakespeare will be getting an assist from science at the Royal Shakespeare Company before its actors take on new productions of "Twelfth Night" and "A Midsummer Night's Dream." In an effort to give the players fresh insights into the scientific nature of falling in love in the two comedies, which involve all manner of love matches, Michael Boyd, the artistic director of the Royal Shakespeare Company, has enlisted the services of Liz Dawson of the London Neuro Psychotherapy Group, which integrates psychotherapy with neuroscience. As part of the rehearsal regimen, she will explain that during the first stages of a relationship, a chemical, beta-phenylethylamine, similar to one found in chocolate, is released into the brain, touching off the irrational behavior of being "madly in love." Negative thinking and rational judgment are blocked, furnishing a scientific basis for the expression "love is blind." Mr. Boyd said, "Searching for the truth about the way we respond to each other and giving it vivid articulation is our job." PAM KENT

title: A Zealous Prosecutor of Drug Criminals Becomes One Himself
description: PAMPA, Tex., Feb. 9 - No one prosecuted the war on drugs in the Texas Panhandle more zealously than Richard James Roach. As the blustery and hot-tempered Republican district attorney for five counties overrun with methamphetamines, he had eked out an election victory in 2000 vowing a crackdown and was soon gleefully reeling off the harsh sentences he had wrung from juries: 36 years, 38 years, 40 years, 60 years, 75 years -- even 99 years. title: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: Protest Over Peacekeeping Troops
description: Thousands of Mogadishu residents held a demonstration to oppose the deployment of foreign troops in the country. Somalia has a government in place, but it operates from Kenya because of insecurity at home. Officials of the new government have called for African Union troops to help control the country's lawlessness, but residents, encouraged by hard-line Islamic leaders, said the arrival of any non-Muslim troops would prompt a violent response. "We will take up our arms against any non-Muslim troops that come to Mogadishu," said Sheik Shariff Sheik Muhidin, the leader of the Union of the Islamic Courts of Mogadishu. Meanwhile, a delegation of African and Arab officials arrived to assess the possibility of an observer mission. Marc Lacey (NYT)

description: Representative George Miller of California, the senior Democrat on the House Education and Workforce Committee, called on the Labor Department's inspector general to investigate a $135,540 agreement the department reached with Wal-Mart Stores on Jan. 6 to settle accusations of 24 child labor violations. Mr. Miller said the investigation should consider why the settlement was kept secret for five weeks and why the department agreed to give Wal-Mart 15 days' notice before conducting wage-and-hour investigations in many cases. "I am very concerned about this secret arrangement," he said. Department officials said that the advance notice provision was typical and that they did not announce the agreement because they were waiting for Wal-Mart to pay the fine. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

Two men, Driss Chebli and Imad Eddin Barakat Yarkas, are charged with helping to organize a meeting in Tarragona, Spain, where details of the attacks may have been worked out, the court said. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FORD, NATASHA BOISSEVAIN
description: FORD--Natasha Boissevain, died quietly Sunday morning in Greenwich Hospital after a very short illness. She was 72. The cause was complications of lung cancer, said Dick Ford, her husband of 24 years. Mrs. Ford was born June 14, 1932 in Nice, France of the late Mrs. J. Russell Maguire of Greenwich, CT and the late John Magee Boissevain of Newport, RI and Nice, France. As a New York debutante in 1950, Marjorie Farnsworth referred to her as "a glittering deb who was one of the most beautiful girls to come out in New York society that year." She began her career in 1953 as a receptionist at the Steuben Glass Shop of 5th Avenue; later joining The American Mercury Magazine where she was Managing Editor from 1954 through 1958, at the time one of the youngest managing directors for a national magazine. She also served as Board Chairman of HOTLINE, a telephone crisis and counseling organization. Mrs. Ford is the owner of Natasha & Company, an interior design firm, and was the past owner and president of The American Fitness Institute, Inc. before it was sold to The New York Sports Club in May 1999. Mrs. Ford is an alumna of The Ethel Walker School and received her degree in Psychology, summa cum laude, from Manhattanville College in 1978. Mrs. Ford was an extremely dedicated and loyal supporter of The New York Botanical Garden and its mission. She was a generous Patron of the Garden and was a valued member of the Garden's Horticulture Committee. In addition, she served on many committees for the Garden's fundraising events, and had served as a Vice Chairman for the Garden's annual Rose Garden Dinner Dance and Orchid Dinner. She is a co-member of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club. In addition to her beloved husband and best friend, Dick, she is survived by her three daughters, Sabrina Pray Forsythe of Greenwich, CT; Melanie "Lilly" B. Pray of Boulder, CO; and Natasha Justina Gagne also of Greenwich, CT. Her son, Malcolm S. Pray III predeceased her. She was also predeceased by a half brother William "Billy" de Prorock and a half sister Marina Maguire. A half sister Cynthia Madigan resides in England. A cousin Odette Terrel des Chenes lives in Austin, TX. She had five grandchildren, Courtney Margaret and Nicole Suzanne Fischer; Portia Boissevain Pray; Natasha Alden and Malcolm Parker Grayson. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Natasha's memory may be made to Channel 13, The New York Botanical Garden, or Medecins Sans Frontiers (Doctors Without Borders). A service in celebration of Mrs. Ford's life will be held at Christ Church, 254 E. Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT on Thursday, February 17th at 11AM, followed by a reception at the Round Hill Club, Greenwich, CT.

The friends, Kenneth C. Stine, 25 and Liborio Valguarnera, 25, both of Glasco, were arrested on federal explosives charges, said the Town of Ulster police chief, Paul M. Watzka. A search of Mr. Stine's house found five semiautomatic weapons, a Mac-11 pistol, other firearms, a stun gun, pipe-bomb material and a large quantity of ammunition. But Mr. Watzka said investigators have not found any evidence that the men knew Robert Bonelli, 24, was planning to enter the Hudson Valley Mall and go on the shooting spree that injured two people. Mr. Bonelli is being held in the Ulster County Jail without bail and will be charged with federal offenses later this week, officials said. John Holl (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLF, HENRY
description: WOLF--Henry. One of the foremost graphic designers of the Twentieth Century, died at his home in Manhattan on February 14, 2005. He was seventy-nine years old. Born in 1925 in Vienna, Henry studied art in Austria and France, before arriving in the United States in 1941. After serving in the U.S. Army during World War II, he returned to New York City where he became the art director of Esquire Magazine in 1952. In 1958, he left Esquire to succeed Alexey Brodovitch as the art director of Harper's Bazaar. Henry was also the art director of Show Magazine and at McCann-Erickson. In 1958 he became Executive Vice President/Creative Director of The Trahey/ Wolf Agency. From 1971 until now Henry worked as a designer and photographer. He taught at Cooper Union, The School of Visual Arts, and Parsons School of Design. During the course of a long and illustrious career, Henry was the recipient of awards from The Society of Illustrators, The Art Directors Club of New York, Philadelphia, Chicago, and Los Angeles, as well as the recipient of medals from The AIGA, and The Society of Publications. In 1980, Henry was inducted into The Art Directors Hall of Fame, and into The Royal Society of Arts. Henry is survived by his sister, Joan Slawson, of Manhattan. Throughout a long life, Henry was steadfast in his love of girls, cars, painting and photography, and in his distaste for computers and cell phones. We will miss him very much. The funeral service will be held at The Plaza Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, on Thursday, February 17, 2005 at 1 P.M. No flowers please.

title: World Briefing | Australia: Security Chief Says Detainee Was In Eqypt
description: The head of Australia's security agency, Dennis Richardson, conceded that Mahmoud Habib, the terror suspect recently freed after 40 months in American custody, was detained in Egypt for part of that time. Washington and Cairo have consistently denied that. Mr. Habib, who trained at Qaeda camps, was picked up in Pakistan in 2002 and turned over to the Americans, who, he has said, took him to Egypt, where he was interrogated and tortured for six months before being taken to Guantnamo Bay, Cuba. In an appearance before a parliamentary committee, Mr. Richardson dismissed Mr. Habib's charges that he had been tortured in Pakistan or Guantnamo as "humbug," but left open the possibility that he had been tortured in Egypt. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

title: H.I.V. Strain Adds Urgency to Changes in City AIDS Program
description: Acting with added urgency after a rare and possibly virulent strain of H.I.V. was detected last week in New York, the city's health department is reorganizing its AIDS program to encourage more aggressive collection of crucial information about the treatment and the spread of the disease, the department's commissioner said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Paris: New Rules On Airlines
description: The European Union will impose new rules supporting the rights of airline passengers on Thursday, possibly forcing airlines to pay refunds and penalties for delays and cancellations, even if the cause is bad weather or other factors outside the airline's control. Airline associations are fighting the most stringent of the new rules in court but most airlines are planning to comply. In an earlier statement, Giovanni Bisignani, director general of the International Air Transport Association, which represents 95 percent of the world's airlines, said, "It is irresponsible for governments to effectively punish airlines for maintaining safe operations." Don Phillips (IHT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARIRI, RAFIC
description: HARIRI--Rafic. The Trustees of the American University of Beirut are shocked and saddened by the news of the calamity that has befallen Lebanon and the world in the loss of Rafic Hariri, our fellow Trustee. Not only was he one of the great leaders in the Middle East, but he was also admired and respected in all the capitals of the world, across the political spectrum. This is a great tragedy for Lebanon. It is also a great tragedy for AUB, which has lost a most esteemed and inspirational trustee of long standing over many years, as well as a philanthropist whose generosity has supported so many students and so many programs of the University. We have been grateful to have him as a colleague, and we shall miss him sorely. Richard A. Debs, Chairman John Waterbury, President American University of Beirut

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 - The size of Social Security's financial shortfall in the decades ahead will depend partly on how many people are allowed to immigrate to the United States, a report to be released on Wednesday shows.

description: Continental Airlines said its board had agreed to reduce fees for most directors by 30 percent and to forgo stock-option grants this year to help cut labor costs. The reductions begin Feb. 28 and affect the annual retainer, which was $35,000 last year, as well as meeting fees, which were as much as $2,000 a meeting for directors who are not company employees, Continental said. The retainer and fees for members of the audit committee members are not being cut because of their increased responsibility under United States corporate-governance law. The airline is based in Houston.

description: DETROIT, Feb. 15 - Federal regulators have opened a safety investigation into 2004 models of the best-selling vehicle from Toyota Motor's Lexus division, the RX330 sport utility vehicle, after receiving complaints about failures in its power brakes.

title: PILOTS SEEK TO BLOCK CHANGE IN UNITED'S PENSIONS
description: The Air Line Pilots Association asked a United States Bankruptcy Court in Chicago to block a plan by United Airlines to suspend some pension payments to retired pilots. Judge Eugene R. Wedoff will hear the association's motion on Friday. Last week, United said that it would suspend nonqualified payments to about 3,000 retired pilots. The payments are in addition to the pilots' basic pension benefits. In some cases, the nonqualified benefits are as much as one-third of a pilot's retirement compensation. The airline's move last week came after the Pension Guaranty Benefit Corporation said it would seize control of the pension plan for United's pilots, rather than allow the airline to terminate the plan. United, which filed for bankruptcy in December 2002, wants to terminate four employee pension plans and replace them with 401(k)-style retirement programs, a move that would save millions of dollars annually. United Airlines, a unit of UAL, is based in Elk Grove Township, Ill. Micheline Maynard (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Kentucky: Report On Dust Explosion
description: Federal investigators said that an explosion of resin dust that killed seven workers at an automobile insulation factory in Corbin in 2003 could have been prevented because plant managers and the suppliers of the resin knew that the dust posed a risk. The federal Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board, which conducted the investigation, said more than 150 other serious industrial dust explosions had occurred around the country over the last 20 years. No federal workplace standard exists for combustible dust.

description: The two 13-year-old boys who set fire to a pushcart on Dec. 25, leading to the death of a security guard in a Rockaways housing complex, pleaded guilty yesterday to second-degree murder charges in Family Court in Jamaica. Prosecutors and lawyers for the boys said in court that they had agreed to a deal that would likely result in an 18-month sentence for the boys in a state juvenile detention center. The boys had been setting fires in the hallways and lit the cart on fire. The security guard, Raymond James, 32, was killed after trying to remove the cart from a building in the Ocean Village apartments. He wheeled the cart into an elevator and died after it burst into flames inside. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

You'll adore what you hear and discover what they have in common, like the hustle and ping of their sound, etched with koras and horns. The other is what they sing about: transfixing passion, not for earthly lovers but for the holy men, marabouts, the Sufi saints of Islam. Theirs is a Higher Love, so high it's out of sight.

title: Sanity on Visas for Students
description: The State Department has injected welcome common sense into the security checks imposed on foreign students and scientists who come to this country to study, do research or teach in areas the government deems sensitive. Such visitors were caught up in needless red tape in the wake of the 9/11 terrorist attacks. Huge backlogs built up, and America's reputation for welcoming foreign students and scientists was in jeopardy. Those problems should be greatly mitigated by recent changes by the State Department.

National Briefing | Science and Health: Study Favors Young Doctors
description: Older doctors are less likely to stay current on recommended methods of patient care, which may result in less effective treatment, a Harvard Medical School study has found. The study, published in the journal Annals of Internal Medicine, reported that in almost three-quarters of the cases studied, a doctor's performance, based on knowledge and adherence to accepted care standards, declined with time. For instance, doctors younger than 40 were more likely to correctly prescribe aspirin and beta blockers for heart disease therapy and doctors who graduated more than 20 years ago were less likely to follow cancer screening practices suggested by the American Cancer Society and National Cancer Institute, the study said.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela and Colombia Heal Rift
description: After a closed-door meeting in Venezuela's presidential palace, President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela and President lvaro Uribe of Colombia announced the official end to a diplomatic dispute that had frozen relations between the neighboring countries for nearly a month. Venezuela restricted trade at the Colombian border in January after disclosures that Colombia had paid bounty hunters to arrest a Colombian rebel leader inside Venezuela without notifying Venezuelan authorities. The Point of Miss Gould's Pencil
description: I never met Miss Gould. But deep in a box at home are the proofs of articles I once wrote for The New Yorker, and in the margins is the handwriting of Eleanor Gould Packard -- the magazine's venerable arbiter of style, who died on Sunday at 87. I thought I knew a lot about the English language at the time. I had a Ph.D. in English literature from Princeton, an old-fashioned kind of doctorate with an emphasis on literary history and textual editing. So it came as a surprise to see those proofs. Broader questions had been settled. But it was clear from Miss Gould's annotations -- her very direct strictures -- that a few details of syntax, usage and logic still needed to be fixed.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Minority Party Lawmakers Sue
description: A Democratic senator and a Republican assemblyman sued their own Legislature, its two leaders and Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday, alleging that the three men run the Capitol like a political machine to centralize power and money in their hands -- to the detriment of New Yorkers whose views are in the minority. The lawsuit was filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan by Senator Liz Krueger of Manhattan and Assemblyman Tom Kirwan of Newburgh. The legal action drew a sharp rebuke from Senator Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican majority leader, who, along with Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker, was named in the suit. "I guess if I were in the minority and I couldn't win the majority in fair elections, then I would try and play any game that I could play to disrupt or, you know, denigrate," Mr. Bruno said. A spokesman for Mr. Silver said the speaker had not seen the lawsuit and declined to comment. But a spokesman for the governor, Todd Alhart, said, "No one has done more to try and open up the state budget process and encourage input from members of the Legislature than Governor Pataki." Patrick D. Healy (NYT)

The appeal was issued nearly two weeks after UPN announced that as a result of dismal ratings, it plans to pull the plug on the series on May 13. title: TWO RAILROADS UNDER ANTITRUST INVESTIGATION FOR RATES
description: Two railroads, Union Pacific and Burlington Northern Santa Fe, are facing Justice Department antitrust investigations into rates charged for shipping coal from the Powder River Basin in Wyoming. Union Pacific received a letter from the agency two days ago, said a company spokeswoman, Kathryn Blackwell. Burlington disclosed a similar request in a filing late Tuesday. The Justice Department is reviewing whether posting rates on the Internet by each railroad is permitted under antitrust rules, a Morgan Stanley analyst, James Valentine, said in an investor note. The issue "comes down to whether we have the right to display these prices," Burlington's chief executive, Matthew Rose, said yesterday in a conference call.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: 12 Found Dead In Drug Shootouts
description: Warring groups of drug traffickers battled with machine guns along a major highway in northern Sinaloa State on Tuesday, leaving at least a dozen people dead on the roadside, law enforcement officials said. The dead, one identified as a leader in the Sinaloa-based drug cartel and the others as mostly low-level gang members, were found in three different places along an 80-mile stretch of highway between the state capital, Culiacn, and the beach resort of Mazatln. "We are assuming this was a shootout between gangs," the Sinaloa attorney general, Luis Antonio Crdenas, told reporters. The killings appeared to mark an expansion of a war between the Sinaloa cartel, led by the reputed drug lord Joaqun (El Chapo) Guzmn Loera in alliance with Ismael (El Mayo) Zambada and Mexico's Gulf and Tijuana drug cartels. Until now, most of the killings have taken place along the Mexico-Texas border. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

title: Prostate Cancer Vaccine Shows Promise in a Trial
description: An experimental treatment tripled the survival rate of men with advanced prostate cancer in a clinical trial, doctors said yesterday, a result they said represents perhaps the first significant success for therapies known as cancer vaccines.

Premiere, which is based in Atlanta, had $381 million in sales in 2003. Citizens is based in Stamford, Conn.

The restatement is likely to reduce net income 16 cents to 20 cents a share for 2003, and 34 cents to 38 cents for 2002, the company said. The adjustments are likely to increase funds from operations, a measure of cash flow used by real estate investment trusts, 2 cents to 6 cents for 2003, and reduce funds from operations 22 cents to 26 cents for 2002. The company, based in Arlington, Va., announced the measures after the close of trading.

description: Mexico's gross domestic product rose 4.4 percent in 2004, the Finance Ministry said, its strongest growth since 2000. Driving the increase was growth in the United States, which buys about 90 percent of Mexico's exports. The economy was helped by a 14.7 percent increase in exports, a domestic construction boom and rising consumer credit. Fourth-quarter growth was 4.9 percent. Analysts expect slower growth this year as the American expansion cools. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Property Tax Exemption Questioned
description: The city misses out on $1.5 billion each year in taxes not paid on properties owned by the state and five public authorities, whose real estate holdings are exempt from local property taxes, according to a report released yesterday by City Project, a liberal budget-research group. The report said that because of new categories of property tax exemptions created over the years, only about 40 percent of the total assessed value of all property in the city is currently taxed, compared with 67 percent 30 years ago. "The unchecked explosion of all categories of tax-exempt properties threatens New York City's long-term fiscal stability," the report said. Mike McIntire (NYT)

Prices for the package of software and servers would begin at $30,000, the company said. Veritas is in the process of being acquired by the Symantec Corporation for $11.2 billion. title: Arts, Briefly; Ashley Olsen Strikes Back
description: The actress Ashley Olsen, below right, one half of the Mary-Kate and Ashley billion-dollar media empire, has sued The National Enquirer for libel and invasion of privacy and is seeking $40 million in damages as well as court costs and legal fees. The suit, filed in Los Angeles Superior Court on Monday, says the actress was devastated by the headline in the issue dated Feb. 21 that reported that she had been caught in a drug scandal; it ran next to a photo in which she appeared squinty-eyed and drugged. But the two-page article inside, by Barry Levine and Robin Mizrahi, is about what it called the drug-related activities of Scott Sartiano (a co-owner of the New York restaurant Butter), who is said to be Ms. Olsen's boyfriend, and includes no information linking Ms. Olsen to the use or sale of drugs. Lawyers for Ms. Olsen said The Enquirer had invented a drug link between Ms. Olsen and what the newspaper called Mr. Sartiano's activities to increase newspaper sales. Ms. Olsen is in her freshman year at New York University. Stuart Zakim, head of corporate communications for American Media, publisher of The Enquirer, did not return phone calls seeking comment. CATHERINE BILLEY

title: Arts, Briefly; Can a Saint Wear Tights?
description: Czar Nicholas II dancing in tights has touched off a protest against the touring ballet "Rasputin" among Russian Orthodox faithful in Yekaterinburg, the city where the Bolsheviks killed Nicholas and his family in 1918. According to reports in the Russian media, they are angered not by the portrayal of Rasputin, the monk who held sway over the imperial family, but about that of Nicholas. A priest representing the local diocese told the newspaper Kommersant that it is offensive that "he is not dancing in a czar's costume but in tights. Is it necessary to make fun of saints?" The Russian Orthodox Church canonized the czar and his family in 2000. The production, which had its premiere in St. Petersburg last year, is being performed in Yekaterinburg by the New Imperial Russian Ballet in a theater near the Church of Spilled Blood, which was built recently on the site of the Romanovs' execution and draws many pilgrims. description: The Bush administration's new drug safety board could play an important role in policing the safety of drugs after they are approved and on the market. But if the board is intended to be the administration's primary solution for the glaring weaknesses that have been revealed in the Food and Drug Administration's ability to protect patients from adverse effects that show up only after a drug is widely used, it will fall woefully short.

description: TOKYO, Feb. 16 - The United States ambassador to Japan criticized North Korea on Wednesday for proliferating nuclear weapons materials and called its nuclear program "a deadly threat."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BESAS, ALAN ERNEST
description: BESAS--Alan Ernest. A retired orthodontist, died Saturday in Norwalk, CT at 74 following a stroke. A resident of Norwalk and previously New Canaan, Dr. Besas was born in New York City to the late Max and Elsa Besas. He attended Brown University (Class of 51) and earned a DDS from UPenn in 1954 and a Masters in Orthodontia from Northwestern in 1958. He served in the U.S. Navy aboard the USS Coral Sea. He was a Diplomate of the American Board of Orthodontics, President of the Darien Rotary Club as well as a member of Wilton Rotary and New Canaan Senior Men's Club. A music enthusiast, he served as Treasurer of the Waveny Chamber Music Society for 22 years. He was an avid player of golf and tennis, and a member of the Lake Club in Wilton. Dr. Besas is survived by his wife, Sandra, and stepchildren, Wendy Jackson, Kristen Seymour, and David Jackson, a sister, Marjorie Besas, and a daughter and stepson from a previous marriage, Diana Bustamante and Michael Hunter, as well as six grandchildren. Interment will be private; a memorial service will be held at a later date. Contributions may be made to the Bennett Cancer Center or the Advanced Center for Rehabilitative Medicine in Norwalk.

Buses to Span Kashmir Line, Signaling Step in Peace Talks
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 16 - Signaling a tangible breakthrough in India-Pakistan peace talks, the two governments agreed Wednesday to establish a bus service to allow travel between the capitals of divided, disputed Kashmir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, ALFRED

title: A Performer's Emotional Globe-Trotting Set to Music
description: Melanie Rey has a big bright voice, and her one-woman show, "A Life A Broad" ("Mi Vida en Jira"), has the advantage of being a musical. Five savvy musicians are on stage, playing straight man and Greek chorus along with guitar, drums, keyboard, sax and bass. The songs she writes with Rob Arthur let her go style-surfing in English and Spanish: torching here, balladeering there; Anglo rock, R&B and Tex-Mex.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Inverness Medical Innovations, Waltham, Mass., which makes home pregnancy tests, said it agreed to buy Ischemia Technologies, Denver, which makes a cardiac diagnostic test, for about $22.4 million in stock.

title: Arts, Briefly; Pop News
description: Bruce Springsteen's 19th album, "Devils & Dust," featuring 12 new Springsteen songs, is to be released by Columbia Records on April 26. Mr. Springsteen, below, is planning a tour to accompany the release. Details are to be announced soon. George Michael says pop music is dead. Speaking yesterday at the Berlin International Film Festival, where he presented his autobiographical film "George Michael: A Different Story," he said, "I think my own genre is dead," The Associated Press reported. Mr. Michael, 41, said he wanted to "try to move my career into a different form. I don't know what that's going to be yet."

title: Officer Says He Didn't Check on Victim in Fatal Shooting
description: The first police officer to arrive after another officer had fatally wounded an unarmed man testified in court yesterday that he had walked away from the dying man instead of approaching him to search him or to see if he was injured.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Paterson: Man Found Dead In Jail Cell
description: A Korean man facing deportation was found dead yesterday in an isolation cell of the Passaic County jail, a jail official said. The man, Heq Sung Soo, 50, was found hanging, and apparently committed suicide. He had attempted suicide at least once before. On Jan. 14, Mr. Soo had been brought to the county jail, where he confronted guards, banged his head and bit himself, officials said. Three days later, he was discovered with a braided rope made from his paper gown, and was returned to his cell naked, William J. Maer, a jail spokesman said. On Jan. 20, he had tried to hang himself with material from his jail mattress, Mr. Maer said. Mr. Soo was later sent to Ann Klein Forensic hospital for evaluation but discharged after 19 days, and sent back to the county jail, where he died less than a week later. A spokesman for Immigration and Customs Enforcement said that Mr. Soo had been arrested for overstaying his tourist visa, but was also a suspect in a series of sexual assaults in South Korea. His death is under investigation by the immigration agency's inspector general and by New Jersey authorities. Nina Bernstein (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHERER, LILLIE (STEINBERG)
description: SHERER--Lillie (Steinberg) 89, February 14, 2005. Gentle, loving mother of Ellen. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Devoted sister of Janet, George and late Irving. Longtime Chelsea resident, former nursery school teacher and a "Rosie the Riveter".

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 - The Justice Department argued on Wednesday that tobacco companies should be held financially accountable somehow for the adverse consequences of smoking despite an appeals court ruling that the government cannot seize profits if it wins its civil racketeering case against the industry.

title: Shades of Blue Over Black: A Meditation in Stoneware
description: Adam Silverman, above right, is the master of his pottery domain, and that's the way he likes it. The sole operator of Atwater Pottery in Los Angeles, he says the appeal of being a potter is "working alone, quietly, with my hands, trying to make something so simple, so primitive as a bowl out of clay, become more than just a bowl." Mr. Silverman, a graduate of the Rhode Island School of Design, once had a much flashier career, as a founder of the XLarge chain of stores and the line of hip utilitarian clothing of the same name, which became popular in the mid-1990's. After nearly a decade in the rag trade, he withdrew to a life of throwing pots and bowls both earthy and modern. His pieces include, above left, black stoneware glazed in volcanic blue. An 11-inch bowl is $150, a 5-inch vase $120, a 10-inch vase $160, and a 26-inch vase $520. At OK, 8303 West Third Street, Los Angeles, (323)653-3501, or through the Museum of Art and Design in New York, (212)956-3535.

title: From Paris, Bedclothes That Don't Suggest Sleep
description: "One dreams there, one makes love there . .. from the bed you can remake the world," said Anne-Margreet Honing, the designer of a line of giddy girl-punk bedding (below) made by the Paris firm Lust-Project. Ms. Honing studied painting at L'cole des Beaux Arts and spent five years in Brooklyn before returning to Paris. "My designs for the bed capture my outlook on the world, which is based on irony," she said. The Kiss duvet cover comes in twin through king sizes, $125 to $225; the pillow shams, Kiss or Eye, are $50 each. Other pieces feature bear skulls and black clouds. Available through Space Downtown, (212)352-9968.

title: Study Urges Early Painkillers in Labor for First Deliveries
description: Women in labor may suffer needlessly because doctors mistakenly advise them to delay a common pain treatment for fear that it will impede contractions and lead to a Caesarean section, researchers are reporting.

A New Owner for 5 Theaters on Broadway
description: It's official. The producer Rocco Landesman became the owner of Broadway's third-largest theater chain, Jujamcyn Theaters, yesterday. Mr. Landesman, the longtime president of the chain, said he paid less than $30 million for its five theaters to the estate of James H. Binger, the wealthy Minnesotan who was chairman of the company and who died in November.

He will be terribly missed. Private service. SCHWARTZ--Bernard S. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member, Bernard S. Norton tootled through a snowscape of hills, steaming rivers and indifferent bison this week, giving an unusual personal endorsement to the machines that some consider a blight and others a blessing.

title: A More Professional Output For the Serious Snapshooter
description: High-end Epson printers that use pigment-based inks rather than dye-based ones have found a following among many photographers. But serious shooters have until recently had only two options from the company. The Epson Stylus Photo 2200 is a standard for many professional photographers and accepts paper up to 13 inches wide but costs $700. The Stylus Photo R800 has a lower price, $300, but can handle paper only up to a maximum width of 8.5 inches.

title: The Interplay of Live Action and Film
description: Cathy Weis has made a career of suggesting how very much dance and film have to do with each other, and what peculiar magic the two can make combined. The equipment she uses -- monitors and hand-held cameras, for the most part -- has a homemade feel, as does the imagery she produces with it. The movement she creates and the people she chooses to perform are just as peculiar. And the way she unsentimentally weaves in her own real-life struggle with multiple sclerosis makes the point, without overdoing it, that the body itself produces a rough kind of magic.

Close to a dozen reporters around the nation face legal pressure to reveal sources, and some face the threat of jail terms. A federal appeals panel in the District of Columbia declined this week to spare Matthew Cooper of Time magazine and Judith Miller of The New York Times the prospect of being jailed for up to 18 months. title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Officers Map Site Where Diana Died
description: British and French police officers closed the Pont de l'Alma Tunnel in Paris and used cameras and laser equipment to gather data for a three-dimensional computer model that will be used in inquests into the deaths in 1997 of Diana, the Princess of Wales, her companion, Dodi Fayed, and Henri Paul, their French driver. The inquest into the crash has been suspended while the British police conduct their inquiry, begun last year and expected to last several more months. An official French report concluded that it was a result of the driver, who, it said, was drunk, speeding and was not qualified to drive a large limousine. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: In London, a Very British Bid for the 2012 Games
description: LONDON, Feb. 16 - The Back the Bid advertisements have been appearing for weeks. The promotional banners were unfurled earlier this month. Celebrities like the soccer star David Beckham and the movie star Roger Moore have declared their support for London's effort to be the host of the 2012 Summer Olympics.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: 2,000 Troops To Amazon Region
description: Responding to widespread indignation at the shooting death of an elderly American nun on Saturday, the government ordered 2,000 soldiers deployed to the Amazon jungle state of Par. The nun, Sister Dorothy Stang, was known throughout the region for her work with the poor and landless and for her efforts to preserve the rain forest. The government action comes as disputes about land use and ownership in the world's largest tropical forest are intensifying as the result of new regulations meant to limit deforestation and land speculation. News of the deployment coincided with the killing of another environmental activist on a list of 140 people whose lives have been threatened by logging, ranching and mining interests in the region. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Slaking Your Printer's Exotic Thirst
description: IT struck me recently that buying printers is a lot like buying hamsters. Both are so cute when you get them, not to mention cheap, and the whole family oohs and aahs about the fun times that lie ahead. Only later, when it is time to clean the cage -- or in the case of the printers, to change the ink -- do you realize what a hellish choice you have made.

title: Souvenirs Of a Fabled Island
description: Captain Kidd is said to have buried treasure on Gardiner's Island, but the island's owners accumulated plenty of booty of their own in the years that followed. Items from the estate of Robert D.L. Gardiner (above right, with a portrait of Charles I) will be auctioned March 1 at 2 p.m. at Christie's. Mr. Gardiner, who died in August, called himself "the 16th Lord of the Manor," referring to the house behind him in the photo and to his 3,350-acre island, off the coast of Long Island's South Fork. The land was purchased in 1639 by Lion Gardiner from the Montauketts for a few trinkets, rum, a dog and a gun, and has remained in the family ever since.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PALEN, HARRIETTE ADAMS
description: PALEN--Harriette Adams, 86, of Meadowood at Worcester, formerly of Verona, NJ, died February 15, 2005. She was the widow of Frederick P. Palen who preceded her in death on March 25, 2003. The couple had been married 63 years. Born April 3, 1918 in NYC, she was the daughter of the late Phineas Hillhouse Adams and Marguerite Janvrin Adams. She was a graduate of Nightingale Bamford HS and Barnard College, Class of 1939, with a music major. Music was her lifelong passion. She played the piano and the recorder and attended concerts. As a member of the Montclair Womens Club, Montclair, NJ, she sang in and helped organize their community concert series. Mr. and Mrs. Palen belonged to the Crater Club in Essex, NY where they spent their summers and Mrs. Palen golfed and played tennis. She also took an interest in photography and volunteered to transcribe books to Braille. She is survived by sons Frederick P. (Bill) Palen, Jr. and wife Cynthia of Upper Gwynedd, PA and Edward M. Palen and his wife Teresa Cheetham-Palen of Keene, NY and grandchildren, Jeffrey, Robert, Thomas and Lynn Palen. Her brother and sister preceded her in death: Josephine Bostwick and Walter Wood Adams. A memorial service at Meadowood will be arranged at a later date. (Longenecker, North Wales, PA). Contributions in his memory may be made to St. John's Episcopal Church, Essex, NY 12936 or the American Cancer Society, 1626 Locust St., Phila, PA 19103

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SELUB, FLORENCE BARKAN
description: SELUB -- Florence Barkan. Age 86, died Sunday, February 13th, 2005 in St. James, NY. Devoted sister of Eleanor Siegal and Irma Spivack. Cherished mother of Dr. Laura Selub-von Schmidt and Dr. Steven Selub, beloved grandmother of Justin and Joseph von Schmidt, and Rachel, Sam, Jonathan and Nathaniel Selub. Her boundless devotion to her family was the touchstone of her life. We will miss her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RYAN, HON. EDWARD JAMES

Served in U.S. Army Intelligence Corps 1943-1945 in Europe. Awarded Bronze Star. Graduate of St. John's Law School. Received LL.M from NYU. Professor of Law at St. John's Law School. Served as a United States Bankruptcy Judge in the Southern District of New York and in Houston, Texas from the 1960's through the 1990's. Survived by four children and five grandchildren. title: Arts, Briefly; P. Diddy and Court
description: Random House is suing Sean Combs, below right, the rapper and music producer known as P. Diddy, contending that he kept a $300,000 advance for a memoir that was never completed. The Associated Press reported that the lawsuit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, asks for the return of the advance plus interest. The advance was part of a 1998 contract with Random House's Ballantine imprint, which expected the book to be delivered in 1999. Rob Shuter, a publicist for Mr. Combs, told The Associated Press that there was a "disagreement with Random House that we hoped would be resolved without litigation. We anticipate that this will be resolved quickly." EDWARD WYATT

title: Bits of History (of Bits) on the Auction Block
description: IN the spring of 1946, J. Presper Eckert and John Mauchly sent out a business plan for a company that would sell "electronic computors." In their eight-page proposal for financing, sent to a handful of prospective backers, the two engineers predicted that the market for such a machine might consist of scientific laboratories, universities and government agencies.

title: ThinkEquity Starts Web Log to Gather Ideas
description: BLOGGING transformed political commentary, rattled the media business and inundated the Internet. Does it have a place on Wall Street? ThinkEquity Partners, a boutique investment bank in San Francisco, will find out as it introduces a Web log today. The firm, which specializes in technology, health care and other fast-growing fields, is seeking to make its investment research department -- an albatross at most Wall Street firms -- relevant.

title: Meanwhile: Mending lives after the tsunami
Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLF, HENRY
description: WOLF--Henry. One of the foremost graphic designers of the Twentieth Century, died at his home in Manhattan on February 14, 2005. He was seventy-nine years old. Born in 1925 in Vienna, Henry studied art in Austria and France, before arriving in the United States in 1941. After serving in the U.S. Army during World War II, he returned to New York City where he became the art director of Esquire Magazine in 1952. In 1958, he left Esquire to succeed Alexey Brodovitch as the art director of Harper's Bazaar. Henry was also the art director of Show Magazine and at McCann-Erickson. In 1958 he became Executive Vice President/Creative Director of The Trahey/ Wolf Agency. From 1971 until now Henry worked as a designer and photographer. He taught at Cooper Union, The School of Visual Arts, and Parsons School of Design. During the course of a long and illustrious career, Henry was the recipient of awards from The Society of Illustrators, The Art Directors Club of New York, Philadelphia, Chicago, and Los Angeles, as well as the recipient of medals from The AIGA, and The Society of Publications. In 1980, Henry was inducted into The Art Directors Hall of Fame, and into The Royal Society of Arts. Henry is survived by his sister, Joan Slawson, of Manhattan. Throughout a long life, Henry was steadfast in his love of girls, cars, painting and photography, and in his distaste for computers and cell phones. We will miss him very much. The funeral service will be held at The Plaza Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, on Thursday, February 17, 2005 at 1 P.M. No flowers please.

title: Mendelssohn, With Beethoven's Accent
description: The Emerson String Quartet has been devoting considerable thought to Mendelssohn these last few seasons, having recorded his six quartets, along with the Octet and miscellaneous movements, for a CD set just released by Deutsche Grammophon. Now the group is revisiting those works in a four-concert series at Zankel Hall, with music by other composers providing context.

title: Amid the Firestorm, a Portrait of Harvard
description: Richard Bradley's last book, a decidedly unauthorized biography of John F. Kennedy Jr., rode a wave of controversy to become a No.1 best seller. But that kind of notoriety seemed like a far reach for his new one, "Harvard Rules," which hits the streets this week. A searing portrait of Lawrence H. Summers, the president of Harvard, it did not seem destined for big sales, in part because while academic politics are most notable for their low stakes, they generally have even lower public appeal.

title: Lawyer Defends Well at Duplicate's Pioneer Club
description: The oldest bridge club on this side of the Atlantic, founded in 1887, is the Hamilton in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., a suburb of Philadelphia. It soon became a pioneer in two respects. In 1893 it voted to allow women to play on weekdays, a forerunner of battles to come in other men's clubs. And in 1895 a young lawyer, Milton C. Work, produced a set of whist trays, prototype boards, allowing the Hamilton to be the first setting for duplicate bridge.

title: The Search for the Suburban Underground Star Who Never Was
description: An avant-garde work can be born in any old place, as is proved by Gary Wilson, a strange 1970's-era teenager who walked his pet duck around Endicott, N.Y., on a leash and staged bizarre jam sessions that disturbed the peace in his Capraesque hometown. "You Think You Really Know Me: The Gary Wilson Story" finds the musician 25 years after his seminal record was issued, working the night shift in a San Diego pornography shop and not fully aware of his enduring influence.

title: WorldCom trial star witness admits he lied
A Folksy Lawyer With a High-Powered Client
description: The first four weeks of the trial of Bernard J. Ebbers, the former chief executive of WorldCom, have moved like mud. The company, based in Melbourne, said that before accounting for one-time items, it earned $2.76 billion in the period, which was the first half of its fiscal year. Sales totaled $15.5 billion. Paid Notice: Deaths   WEILER, RHODA GOLDSTONE
description: WEILER--Rhoda Goldstone. Age 97 of Palm Beach, FL died peacefully on Wednesday, February 16, 2005. She was married to Sydney Goldstone, an architect and avid golfer, for 36 years until his death in 1970. She later married Theodore Weiler who also predeceased her. She was a graduate of Adelphi College, taught elementary school and worked in her family's business, Miner's Cosmetic Company, both in New York and London. She was a trustee of the Theodore and Renee Weiler Foundation. Her greatest joy was her family; daughters Abby Pelton Popper and Erda G. Erdos; grandchildren Karen, Gail and Michael Erdos, Lisa, Stephen and Nina Pelton, great grandchildren, Ayla, Julian, Rae, Mimi and Charlie. She was a true friend to many, a great hostess, a wonderful gardener and flower arranger-she loved to laugh, was extremely generous and the world's best grandmother. title: Arts, Briefly; Kid Rock on the Rap Sheet
description: Kid Rock, left, the Detroit rapper, has had an eventful week in Music City. Barely 12 hours after he performed an emotional version of "I Saw the Light" at the memorial service for the country impresario Merle Kilgore, he was arrested early Wednesday by the Nashville police on charges that he punched a disk jockey at a local strip club, Christie's Cabaret. Kid Rock, whose real name is Bob Ritchie, was released after he posted a $3,000 bond; he is charged with simple assault, a misdemeanor. Sgt. James Smith of the Nashville police told reporters that the incident stemmed from an apparent disagreement over the club's music. The police said Kid Rock, who joked about the case during his court appearance and upon his release, had been very cooperative. Kid Rock, who has said he loves country music, recorded the crossover country-pop hit "Picture" with Sheryl Crow and is a close friend of several Nashville stars, including Hank Williams Jr. PHIL SWEETLAND

title: Bull Crashing Through Glass Wall Signals New Direction for Merrill Lynch
description: TWO years after it began efforts to convince investors that Merrill Lynch is not just for buying stocks and bonds anymore, the company is intensifying the image makeover with a bold campaign that takes a certain familiar animal by the horns.

title: Studio Suspends Filming of Crowe-Kidman Movie
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 16 - A prominent film starring Russell Crowe and Nicole Kidman has fallen apart three days before filming was scheduled to start this week in Australia, an embarrassing stumble by Fox Searchlight, the studio behind the Oscar-nominated hit "Sideways."

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Ex-Premier On Trial
description: Former Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz went on trial in Supreme Court in Ankara on corruption charges in a banking scandal. It is the first time a head of the government has faced criminal prosecution in Turkey. Mr. Yilmaz, left, who was prime minister three times in the 1990's, is charged with rigging the privatization of Turkbank in 1998. Gunes Taner, a former minister under Mr. Yilmaz, is being tried with him. Both men deny the charges, with Mr. Yilmaz insisting that he was simply performing his duties as prime minister in the bank transaction. "Sales of a $600 million public asset would always be to the interest of a prime minister in Turkey," he said. Sebnem Arsu (NYT)

title: Rice Says Syria Is at Least Indirectly Responsible for the Blast
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 - Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice roundly criticized Syria during Senate testimony on Wednesday in extended and animated remarks that struck a chord with several senators, who urged her to find new ways to penalize the Syrian government.

title: Considering a Tax Shelter? Think. Then Think Again.
description: Joe Polish, a marketing consultant for small businesses, often advises clients on how to avoid fraud and unethical deals. So he was taken aback when he discovered that he had become the victim of a sophisticated tax scam.

title: MED DIVERSIFIED AGREES TO SELL ELDERLY CARE UNIT
description: Crescent Capital Investment, a unit of the First Islamic Investment Bank, agreed to buy the elderly care unit of Med Diversified for $148 million, the companies said yesterday. The sale of the unit, Tender Loving Health Care, is the final part of Med Diversified's plan to liquidate its assets to repay creditors who are owed more than $1 billion. Unsecured creditors will receive 29 cents to 50 cents on the dollar for their claims, according to court papers. Med Diversified, based in Andover, Mass., filed for bankruptcy in Central Islip, N.Y., in November 2002 after its primary financing source filed its own bankruptcy. First Islamic Investment Bank is based in Bahrain.

title: Fen-Phen Case Lawyers Say They'll Reject Wyeth Offer
description: Lawyers for thousands of people who contend that they were harmed by the diet drug combination fen-phen said yesterday that they would reject a comprehensive settlement offer from Wyeth. But the company said there was a "substantial show of interest" in the deal.
