title: The Lights That Launched A Thousand Faces
description: The Cone Light, above, from the British designer Tom Dixon, is a domesticated version of the professional photo studio light. Made from spun aluminum with a black matte finish, it can hang from the ceiling, sit on the floor or attach to a stand. Its reflective inner surface and acrylic diffuser produces an even, flat light, flattering for close-ups. Versions with American wiring are not yet available, and prices for them have not been finalized, but advance orders are being accepted. For reference, British models are about $670 for the large cone, $220 for the small and $300 for the stand. At www.tomdixon.net.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Senate Backs Repeal Of Virtue Law
description: The State Senate voted 47 to 1 to repeal a 1909 law that had made it illegal to impugn the virtue and chastity of women. The bill's sponsor, Senator Jeanne E. Kohl-Wells, a Democrat, had said that while insults to women's chastity -- including calling them hussies or strumpets or publicly bringing their purity into question -- were not welcome, the law was an outdated relic of sexism. The bill now heads to the House of Representatives. Eight other states have similar laws on their books, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Capping Medical Malpractice Damages
description: Contending that the cost of lawsuits in the state had forced obstetricians and gynecologists to leave their practices, Gov. Sonny Perdue signed into law a bill that caps noneconomic damages in medical malpractice cases at $350,000 total from all health care providers involved in a case and $350,000 each from up to two medical facilities. Under the law, plaintiffs who seek damages for emergency medical care in an emergency department or obstetrical unit must prove by clear and convincing evidence that the health care provider showed gross negligence. They formerly had to show simple negligence by a preponderance of the evidence. Doctors' expressions of mistake or apology will not be admissible as evidence. Ariel Hart (NYT)

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 16 - Alternately sobbing, burying her face in her hands and shooting fearful glances at unseen captors, an Italian reporter being held hostage pleaded for her life and asked all foreigners to leave Iraq as she appeared in a crudely made videotape that surfaced Wednesday.

title: Homo Sapiens Gets a Lot Older in a New Analysis of Fossils
description: Scientists have determined that human fossils found in Ethiopia in 1967 are 195,000 years old, 65,000 years older than first thought. The revised date, they said, makes the skulls and bones the earliest known remains of modern Homo sapiens.

title: Arts, Briefly; Third Album Is the Charm
description: The rock trio 3 Doors Down entered the Billboard charts at No. 1 for its third album, "Seventeen Days" (Universal), with 231,000 copies sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The chart position is the highest so far for the Mississippi band, which has been a strong concert draw and has had steady sales for its first two albums. "Seventeen Days" pushed "The Documentary" (Interscope), the debut album by the Los Angeles rapper the Game, to second place, with sales of 158,000; that disc, which made a huge splash on its release in the music business's usual January doldrums, has sold about 1.2 million copies to date. Green Day's "American Idiot" (Warner Brothers), which won the Grammy Award for best rock album, continues to be a big seller, holding at No. 3; the bedroom-soul singer Brian McKnight entered the charts at No. 4 with "Gemini" (Universal Motown), selling just over 100,000. BEN SISARIO

title: 'Hama Rules'
description: About two weeks ago, a friend of former Lebanese Prime Minister Rafik Hariri stopped by my office to update me on Lebanon and pass on a message from Mr. Hariri, whom I have known since reporting from Beirut in the late 1970's. The message was that the Lebanese opposition to the Syrian occupation was getting united -- inspired both by the example of Iraq and by the growing excesses of the Syrian occupation. Mr. Hariri, his friend said, was planning to use the coming Lebanese parliamentary elections, and a hoped-for victory by the opposition front, to send a real message to the Syrians: It's time for you to go.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit Rises At Reuters
description: The Reuters Group, the news and financial information vendor, said that its net profit rose to 352 million ($668 million) last year, from 50 million a year earlier, partly as a result of a program to cut costs and sell some assets. Sales fell 11 percent, to 2.9 billion, in part because of the weak dollar. The chief executive, Tom Glocer, is in the process of trimming Reuters' 1,300 products to just 50 in 2006, and has promised to cut 440 million in costs by the end of that year. Reuters shares rose 3 percent in London. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Report Says 2 Drank On Transit Job
description: Two employees of a New York City Transit contractor drank beer during their lunch hour, "enough to likely impair their functioning," while they worked on a project to repair four subway stations on the B and Q lines in Brooklyn, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's inspector general said yesterday. WNBC-TV first reported the drinking in November 2003. After an inquiry by the contractor, the Kiska Construction Corporation of Long Island City, Queens, the workers left that project. New York City Transit officials inspected the work they performed on the day of the incident. The transit agency cannot compel contract workers to take drug or alcohol tests, the inspector general, Matthew D. Sansverie, found. He concluded that the agency's monitoring program failed to detect the drinking and that the agency's ability to prevent such conduct was "unsatisfactory." Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: With a Palm-Size Projector, Presentations Can Go Places

Hasbro has an exclusive contract for the United States rights to make games and puzzles with characters from Nickelodeon and Nick Movies, and will rebrand some other games with the characters, said Clark Hare, a spokesman for Hasbro. The first games, expected to be in stores in March, will be Ants in the SquarePants, a version of the game Ants in the Pants, and a version of the Game of Life called the Game of Life in Bikini Bottom, SpongeBob SquarePants Edition. Hasbro is based in Pawtucket, R.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARIRI, RAFIC
description: HARIRI--Rafic. The Trustees of the American University of Beirut are shocked and saddened by the news of the calamity that has befallen Lebanon and the world in the loss of Rafic Hariri, our fellow Trustee. Not only was he one of the great leaders in the Middle East, but he was also admired and respected in all the capitals of the world, across the political spectrum. This is a great tragedy for Lebanon. It is also a great tragedy for AUB, which has lost a most esteemed and inspirational trustee of long standing over many years, as well as a philanthropist whose generosity has supported so many students and so many programs of the University. We have been grateful to have him as a colleague, and we shall miss him sorely. Richard A. Debs, Chairman John Waterbury, President American University of Beirut

The authorities said all the victims were passersby and termed the bombing a failed attempt to kill Dagestan's deputy prime minister, Amuchi Amutinov, whose car was hit by shrapnel after another bombing last November. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMON, RIA D.
description: SIMON--Ria D. Born October 17, 1929 in NYC, died February 14, 2005, at home, Palm Beach, FL. Beloved wife for 22 years of Lenard de Lane, dear sister, sister-in-law, aunt. A graduate of Brooklyn College and Brooklyn Law School, she specialized in matrimonial law, first as a partner in the firm of Stannage & Simon, later in Connecticut. In Florida, she became a divorce mediator. She is cited in "The Best and Brightest Lawyers in America, 1983." An avid sportswoman, she excelled in tennis, figure skating and horsemanship. Her directness, thoughtful advice, and keen interest in people she cared about were appreciated by all who knew her.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Yemeni Witnesses Defend Sheik

After the Sept. 11 attack, the sheik, Mohammed Ali Hassan al-Moayad, condemned it and "said our Islam did not ask us to do that," a Yemeni school teacher, Abdeh Salah Mohammed al-Zahr, a witness called by the defense, testified. But when a prosecutor, Jeffrey Knox, played a secretly recorded videotape in which the prosecutors say that the sheik laughed and applauded a fatal terrorist attack in Israel, the witness insisted that "all of that is lies and forged." William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Saudi Arabia's Meager Election
description: For a demonstration of why the mere act of holding an election is not an adequate path to democracy, look no further than the voting in Saudi Arabia last week. While it's good to see any sign of public life in such a repressed society, a ritual conducted in the name of democracy but without a democratic process or a democratic outcome devalues real democracy. It is as apt to reinforce the status quo as to hasten representative government.

The Listings; 'SHOCKHEADED PETER'
description: Sucking your thumb may not seem like such a terrible offense. But in "Shockheaded Peter," the gloriously ghoulish pocket musical that has returned to New York after a short -- but much talked-about -- run in 1999, the punishment (always death) never really fits the crime (meanness, not eating your soup). So when Conrad, played by a puppet, disobeyed his mother, a sinister man with big scissors paid him a visit and chopped his thumbs off. Performed on a booby-trapped doll's house of a set, the slyly ironic show, which has the highest body count of any production in the theater district, is filled with the kind of gothic tales that will delight kids while scaring them witless. A broken-down master of ceremonies (played by Julian Bleach) from the Boris Karloff finishing school of charm narrates the imaginative musical, introducing himself with typical understatement: "I am the greatest actooor who ever existed," he bellows. The slyly self-parodic show, which has already gained a cult following in London, is based on the sing-songy verse of the 19th-century doctor Henrich Hoffman, an influence on other writers of twisted tales for kids like Edward Gorey and Roald Dahl. This stylish adaptation -- which features the seductive songs of the Tiger Lillies, whose grimacing falsetto-voiced front man Martyn Jacques (above right with Mr. Bleach) plays a mournful accordion -- provides an antidote to the bland and benign family-friendly entertainments on Broadway that are about as fun as eating your spinach. Which, by the way, is highly recommended for children looking to make it to adulthood. (This weekend's schedule: Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 3 and 8 p.m. and Sunday at 2p.m., Little Shubert Theater, 422 West 42nd Street, (212)239-6200. Tickets: $21.25 to $66.25.) JASON ZINOMAN

Paid Notice: Deaths   NESVIG, TIMOTHY WILLEM
description: NESVIG--Timothy Willem, of New York City, died February 8, 2005, at the City of Hope Cancer Center in Duarte, CA, after a courageous 18-month battle against lymphoma. The disease overcame him, but never defeated him. He was 30 and lived in New York City. Tim was an account executive at ESPN/ABC Sports Customer Marketing and Sales in New York. Previously, he worked as a media supervisor at Carat, NY, and a media buyer at DDB/Needham, NY. Tim received a bachelor's degree in economics from Bucknell University, where he also captained the water polo team, receiving All-America, as well as Academic All-America honors in that sport. In 1996, he received the Christy Matthewson Award as Bucknell's outstanding male athlete. Tim was born October 23, 1974, in Santa Monica, CA, and attended the Greenwich, CT, public schools, graduating from Greenwich High School in 1992. He was a four year varsity letterman in swimming and won Connecticut All-State swimming honors in two events. He captained the Greenwich High water polo team and won Eastern Interscholastic and High School All America recognition. As an adult, he became an avid golfer and was a member of the Innis Arden Golf Club in Old Greenwich, CT. Tim is survived by his parents, Jon and Hanneke Nesvig, of Riverside, CT, and two sisters, Mieke and Carrie Nesvig, both of New York City. A memorial service will be held Monday, February 28, 4:30pm, at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th St, New York. The family requests donations be made to the Tim Nesvig Fellowship for Lymphoma Research, City of Hope Cancer Center, c/o Kathleen Kane, 1055 Wilshire Blvd, Suite 1200, Los Angeles, CA 90017. Contributions are tax-deductible.

title: MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS DRUG SHOWS PROMISE IN TRIAL
description: A drug, Tysabri, developed by Biogen Idec and the Elan Corporation, slowed the progression of disability from multiple sclerosis by 42 percent over two years in a study, compared with a placebo. The results came from a trial that examined 942 patients who received either a 300- milligram dose of Tysabri or a placebo every four weeks, Elan said. Tysabri won approval in the United States in November. It is the first new type of drug in eight years to treat M.S., a neurological disorder affecting about a million people worldwide. Analysts expect Tysabri to generate sales of more than $3 billion. Elan, based in Dublin, and Biogen, based in Cambridge, Mass., plan to present the trial data at the American Academy of Neurology meeting in April, Elan said.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Calls To Block Military Aid
description: Two weeks after King Gyanendra dismissed the government and suspended civil liberties, Amnesty International called on donors, particularly Britain, India and the United States, to suspend military assistance. At a news conference in the Indian capital, New Delhi, the group's secretary general, Irene Khan, who met with the king this week, said he was taking Nepal to the "brink of disaster." In Washington later, the American ambassador to Nepal, James F. Moriarty, who was recalled this week, said that if the king failed to restore basic rights in the coming weeks, he would put United States military aid at risk, news agencies reported. Such aid was $4 million last year, with $1.5 million budgeted for this year, he said. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

Annual profit is expected to grow by 15 percent in the next two years, up from an earlier company forecast of 10 percent, Monsanto said. The Listings; MARK KOZELEK
description: In years past, a solo concert from Mr. Kozelek, above, would have meant a roomful of fans hoping to hear songs by the longtime band he leads, Red House Painters. But this concert will probably attract a roomful of fans hoping to hear songs by his other band, Sun Kil Moon, which released a gorgeous debut CD in 2003 called, "Ghosts of the Great Highway" (Jetset). It might be the best album of Mr. Kozelek's career: a calm but fierce collection of slow-building Neil-Young-ish ballads, populated with stubborn fighters and stubborner lovers. These mysterious songs grow bigger and sadder the more you listen to them, thanks partly to the mesmerizing guitar figures lovingly wrapped around his intonations. One of the best songs, a dead-boxer ode called "Salvador Sanchez," appears twice: first loud and frayed, then, at the end, in a hushed acoustic version under the title "Pancho Villa." At this President's Day concert, expect Mr. Kozelek to respond to all the requests and shouted praise and unsolicited commentary with mumbled insults: the last time he visited the Bowery Ballroom, he offered to show one fan the inside of his guitar, although it sounded like an offer likely to leave neither the fan nor the guitar intact. Elliott, Neil Elliott, Martha Coffin, Bruce Elliott, Laura Coffin, and Windsor Dexter Coffin; as well as his brother, David L. Coffin of Naples, FL. title: The Listings; LARRY KEIGWIN
description: My first glimpse of Larry Keigwin was in a piece whose title and time I no longer remember. What did register was a dark-haired, slightly built but sinewy male who tore through the dance with spendthrift abandon and a dazzling technique. The choreographer might have been Mark Dendy. The wildness of the solo rules out the cooler art of John Jasperse and Ben Munisteri, with whom Mr. Keigwin has also performed. Then came his eerie portrayal of a vulpine Nijinsky in Mr. Dendy's "Dream Analysis," and the dance, yearning and pyrotechnical, that he created and performed in Mr. Dendy's "I'm Going to My Room to Be Cool Now, and I Don't Want to Be Disturbed." Today, Mr. Keigwin and his choreography seem to be everywhere, in programs by Keigwin + Company and in his witty burlesque-style Keigwin Kabaret. So it is no surprise that he is opening the five-week 92nd Street Y Harkness Dance Project festival at the Duke on 42nd Street. Mr. Keigwin injects a revivifying dose of blithe high spirits into an often rather solemn art. His festival program includes the New York premiere of "Natural Selection" (above with Mr. Keigwin and Nicole Wolcott) and his signature "Mattress Suite," a duet whose blend of wry humor and the immense sadness of dashed hope is typical of Mr. Keigwin's humane approach to dance. (Keigwin + Company performs tomorrow at 8 p.m. and Sunday at 2 and 7 p.m., the Duke on 42nd Street, 229 West 42nd Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, Manhattan, (212)239-6200 or www.92Y.org. Tickets: $20; $85 for a five-show subscription.) JENNIFER DUNNING

title: The Listings; AARON SPANGLER
description: You don't see much wood carving in elite Chelsea galleries. An antiquated craft with little relevance to modern technologies of communication or to a competitive, fast-paced contemporary art market, it is too hard to learn and takes too much time to do well. So it is exciting to come upon the large, intricate reliefs carved from broad, three-inch slabs of maple and painted black by Aaron Spangler. Mr. Spangler, who is from Minneapolis, lives in Brooklyn and is here having his second solo exhibition in New York, uses his extraordinary technique to elaborate profusely detailed, darkly comic visions of rural, post-apocalyptic ruin. The scenes appear to be set in a remote, Appalachian region where wrecked buildings, crashed cars and trucks and abandoned appliances litter the densely forested landscape. There are other more fantastic elements, too, like the giant ears of corn and the many tire swings hanging from high branches in "Imperial Trees" (above). There is something Medieval and a little fanatical about Mr. Spangler's work, as though its author were a backwoods prophet carving his own Book of Revelations. Drawing closer, you search for narrative clues about what has caused these disastrous scenarios, but few if any are forthcoming. What you do discover are many more details and a more immediate sense of the sculptor's hand. Mr. Spangler is not a fussy finisher; he leaves things a bit rough and this creates a magical tension between the raw material and the epic fantasy. (Zach Feuer Gallery, 530 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212)989-7700, through Feb. 26; free.) KEN JOHNSON

title: Arts, Briefly; Grammy Fallout
description: Days after winning eight Grammy Awards, the posthumously released duets album with Ray Charles, right, "Genius Loves Company" has become the subject of a second lawsuit. A recording engineer had already sued Ray Charles Enterprises and Concord Records over credit on the album. And on Wednesday Don Mizell, a record producer and music executive, filed a suit in Los Angeles Superior Court for unspecified damages exceeding $1 million. In the suit -- filed against Act III Communications, owner of Concord; Ray Charles Enterprises; and Starbucks, which sold large quantities of the album -- Mr. Mizell contends that the companies are in breach of contract by using his concept for the album illegally. title: Arts, Briefly; Kennedy Center Plans Big Education Push
description: The Kennedy Center will spend $125 million during the next five years on performing-arts education, more than any other American arts organization has spent on such an effort, the center said yesterday. The money, public and private funds, will support arts programs for children around the country and pay for more performances at the center in Washington, including a joint project with Disney Theatrical Productions and Music Theater International. The center said that in December it would open its sixth theater, a 320-seat room to be used mainly for productions aimed at young audiences. Other new programs include the development of Web sites on the history of the performing arts and jazz, with performances, interviews and other features. In addition to sending artists into classrooms -- in person and via computer and satellite technology -- the center said that this spring it would begin offering a 15 percent discount on tickets for teachers to attend programs produced by the center. JOHN FILES

title: An Intelligence Director, Finally
description: John Negroponte, nominated yesterday by President Bush to be the first director of national intelligence, would bring many strong qualifications to the job: decades of diplomatic experience, a reputation for successful bureaucratic infighting and some relevant managerial experience. What he has not consistently demonstrated is the kind of bedrock commitment to democratic values, professional independence and frank relations with Congress that he will need to successfully do a job whose powers have already been dangerously diluted. We hope that after what seems likely to be a relatively smooth Senate confirmation process, Mr. Negroponte can put these doubts to rest.

title: Where Whooping Cranes Cheat Extinction
description: SOME of the most majestic birds on the planet congregate each winter just off the narrow road to a 0cavernous barbecue restaurant that calls itself "the Redneck Emporium" on a spit of salt marshes stretching into the chocolate-colored waters of the Gulf of Mexico. Standing five feet in the shallow water, occasionally opening their wings to a span wider than that of an F-150 pickup, these are whooping cranes, part of a population that still numbers fewer than 500 after slowly making its way back from the brink of extinction. They arrive here, at Aransas Bay in Texas in tight-knit family units after flying 2,400 miles from their summer home in the Northwest Territories of Canada.

title: In Mont-Tremblant, Quebec
description: If you're dreaming of a weekend getaway to Courchevel or St. Moritz but can't stand the falling dollar -- or the flights -- consider an alternative: Mont-Tremblant, Quebec. Since 1995, the Intrawest skiing corporation has spent more than $400 million on the formerly sleepy Canadian ski resort. Today, Tremblant, the highest peak (2,871 feet) in the beautiful Laurentian range, boasts European charm with North American comforts. Founded in 1939 by Joe Ryan, a Philadelphia industrialist who dreamed of making the Laurentians a destination for skiers from the United States, Tremblant has 94 downhill trails, 13 lifts, 628 skiable acres and picture-postcard views from every angle. The pedestrian-only ski village resembles Quebec City, with steep mansard roofs and brightly painted shutters framing dormer windows. Tremblant's steep cobblestone streets are lined with chic bistros and lively bars, along with dozens of boutiques and galleries. NANCY M. BETTER

title: FOREVER 21 TO BUY GADZOOKS, BANKRUPT RETAILER
description: Gadzooks, a clothing retailer that sought bankruptcy protection last year, agreed to be bought after an auction bid of more than $33 million by Forever 21, a closely held women's clothing chain. The sale includes 243 stores and operating assets that Forever 21 bid for in an auction sanctioned by the bankruptcy court, Gadzooks said. The deal is expected to close on March 11. Gadzooks, based in Carrollton, Tex., filed for Chapter 11 protection a year ago and closed 125 of its 410 stores, cutting about 1,300 jobs after a strategy of focusing on young women's apparel did not increase sales. Forever 21 is based in Los Angeles and has more than 200 stores and sales of $640 million.

title: Arts, Briefly; The Exorcist Reality Show
description: A commercial television station in Britain that has already pushed the boundaries of British taste with programs on abortions and autopsies said it planned to run a program next week on an exorcism, arousing the disapproval of some clergy members. Channel 4 said that its program was a serious scientific investigation of what happens inside the brain during an exorcism, and cited a new field of research called neurotheology, which examines brain activity during religious experiences. The exorcism is to be performed by a nondenominational minister with a man he has been working with for some years, and the station said the man had been cleared by two psychologists. But the Bishop of Monmouth, a spokesman for the Episcopal Church in Britain, said: "This is not the kind of ministry that should be done on TV. Anglican rules specify that it should take place with the minimum publicity. In these cases you are often dealing with very vulnerable and disturbed people who need to be in a safe environment. It's bound to be entertainment rather than anything scientific." PAM KENT

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Body Parts Found Near Subway Tracks
description: A transit worker on a routine inspection shortly before 3 a.m. yesterday found a plastic bag containing two human legs and an arm beside the tracks of the southbound A train in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the police said. Last night, the police identified the victim as Rashawn Brazell, 19, of Bedford-Stuyvesant. He was identified after the police traced a fingerprint to an arrest for possession of marijuana, the only arrest on his record. Investigators could not say whether Mr. Brazell had been reported missing before the discovery of the remains, or how long they had been at the tracks. Another bag, containing tools, drill bits and what appeared to be blood, was found near the remains, investigators said, but it was unclear whether the two discoveries were connected. Neighbors at Mr. Brazell's apartment building said that he worked at a clothing store in Manhattan and lived with his mother and stepfather. He was last seen by his family on Monday, a neighbor said. Before his remains were found, the police had been seen searching the building, neighbors said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISHER, BERTRAM D.
description: FISHER--Bertram D., 76, of Manhattan and Sagaponack, NY died peacefully on February 17, 2005 with his family at his side. He was a founding partner with Fred Queller in 1970 of the New York law firm, Queller & Fisher LLP, and was selected by The New York Law Journal "Best Negligence Lawyers." He was past president of the Jewish Lawyers' Guild, a former Dean of the New York State Trial Lawyers Institute, a member of the Ethics Committee of the New York State Bar Association, a member of the Board of Directors of the New York State Trial Lawyers Association, and an Associate of the American College of Legal Medicine. His many charitable pursuits led to his selection as Man of the Year by The National Conference for Furtherance of Jewish Education, and by The Institute of Jewish Humanities. Mr. Fisher served on the Board of Directors of Community Mayors of New York State and was the recipient of the Community Mayors Humanitarian Award which was presented by Mayor Rudolph Guiliani for his work with handicapped children. He was a veteran of the Korean War and was awarded the Bronze Star for heroism in combat. Devoted father, loving grandfather, caring brother, he is survived by his daughters, Brooke Fisher of Manhattan, Beth Cutler and her husband Marc of Greenwich, CT; grandchildren Philip and Caroline Cutler; sister Barbara Reingold and his former wife Barbara Fisher with whom he remained close. His generosity, wisdom, gentleness and love remain a blessing to his family and all who knew him. Funeral services will be held today 12:45pm at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St, NY, NY 10023. 212-362-6600. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Greenwich Hospital, Development Office, 89 Lake Avenue, Greenwich, CT 06830. FISHER--Bertram D. The Jewish Lawyers Guild records with profound sorrow the passing of Bertram D. Fisher, a longtime member and former president. He will be remembered as a staunch supporter of Jewish causes and a giant in the legal profession. We extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Michael L. Katz, President Lisa A. Sokoloff, Chairperson of Board of Governors FISHER--Bertram D. We mourn the loss of our dedicated friend and supporter. We extend our sympathy to his family whom he loved. Rabbi Pinchus Wechter The Institute of Jewish Humanities

description: MOED--Marjorie McWilliams November 20, 1916-February 16, 2005. Marjorie McWilliams Moed died quietly at her home in New York, the city of her birth. She was the daughter of the late James and Mildred McWilliams. Her father was the contractor and builder of the Barracks buildings on Governor's Island in New York Harbor, and numerous Loew's movie theaters from New York City to Atlanta, the site of the "Gone With The Wind" premiere. Mrs. Moed was the devoted wife of the late Benjamin Moed; and loving mother of Charles J. Moed, Helen McWilliams Pomeroy, and the late Edward K. Moed; grandmother of Lawrence Ben Pomeroy, mother-in-law of Lawrence K. Pomeroy; and sister of James McWilliams. Mrs. Moed was a graduate of Hunter High School, NY. Her exceptional math skills and photographic memory helped win a scholarship at Wellesley College, Class of 1936, and she attended New York University's School of Law. A resident of Scarsdale, NY, for close to 60 years, Mrs. Moed was a past president of the Wellesley in Westchester Club and the Quaker Ridge Parent Teacher Association. She retired as President of Chedward Realty Corporation. An enthusiast of archeology, she and her husband visited the Dead Sea and Palestinian digs on their honeymoon voyage in 1938. A devoted opera buff, Mrs. Moed regularly attended the Metropolitan Opera with librettos dating from her childhood. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Mrs. Moed's favorite causes: Keewaydin Foundation, Irish Boys, 10 Keewaydin Road, Salisbury, VT, 05769. title: SPIEGEL TO CLOSE FURNITURE STORES IN REORGANIZATION
description: Spiegel, the mail-order marketing company currently operating under bankruptcy protection, filed a reorganization plan yesterday that calls for the company to close 34 of its Eddie Bauer furniture stores and lay off 8 percent of its work force. Spiegel, which is valued at $865 million under the plan, will be renamed Eddie Bauer Holdings. The plan, filed yesterday in the Federal Bankruptcy Court in New York, would give unsecured creditors, who are owed more than $1.3 billion, all of Eddie Bauer's common stock, for a recovery of 90 cents on the dollar. Current shareholders would get nothing under the plan. Spiegel, based in Downer's Grove, Ill., filed for bankruptcy in March 2003 after declining sales and credit card defaults left it with $1.7 billion in debt.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Putin Backs Nuclear Program

Putin said, resisting pressure from the United States, Israel and other nations that worry that Iran's civilian nuclear energy program is a cover to obtain nuclear or radiological weapons. Mr. Putin's declaration came a day after Russia and Iran agreed to sign a pact on Feb. 26 that will require Iran to return spent nuclear fuel to Russia, a step Russia contends will mean that no fuel could be reprocessed for weapons use. "Actions on Iran's part have convinced us that Iran truly does not intend to manufacture nuclear weapons," Mr. Putin said after meeting with Hassan Rouhani, an Iranian negotiator. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

Paid Notice: Deaths   GIMON, JEAN, PAUL
description: GIMON--Jean-Paul, 68, died on Wednesday, February 16, 2005. He will be remembered for his distinguished career in international finance, his love of the mountains, his Catholic faith and philanthropic actions, and, above all, for his devotion to his family. Born in France, in 1936, he received a PhD in statistics from Stanford University. There he met Eleanor Hewlett who became his wife and the mother of his children: Nathalie, Eric, Juliette and Marianne. In 1971, Mr. Gimon joined the Credit Lyonnais and from 1984 to 1996, he was executive vice president and general representative of the bank in North America. Mr. Gimon served on the board of Hewlett-Packard from 1993 to 2000. In later years he applied himself to diverse philanthropic efforts, including the IHES in Paris, the Gimon collection at Stanford University. He is held dearly in the memory of his family and friends for his humor, grace, intelligence and selfless involvement in the life of others. Funeral Mass on Monday at 11:00 AM at St. Catherine of Siena, Riverside, Connecticut.

description: Another season of the reality television stalwart "Survivor" made its debut on Thursday, and before the end of the hourlong program, three people were kicked off the show instead of the usual one-person elimination. In the two months since the finale of the fall edition of "Survivor," CBS has taken a hit on Thursday nights. But what a difference a single show can make: the premiere, shown above, drew an estimated audience of 23.64 million, anchoring a victory for CBS both in total viewers and in the 18-to-49 demographic that advertisers most prize. Against "Survivor," original episodes of NBC's "Joey" and "Will & Grace" each drew fewer than 10 million viewers for the first time this season, according to Nielsen's overnight ratings. CBS's showing was also bolstered by "CSI," the most-watched program of the evening: an estimated 30.42 million viewers observed the forensics team investigate the murder of a man who liked to fantasize that he was a baby. Towels too! It was beautiful; as far as the eye could see, rows and rows of shimmering golden-orange fabric dancing in the light.

title: BRASCAN TO BUY WEYERHAEUSER TIMBER ASSETS
description: Brascan, an electrical generation, real estate and natural resources holding company based in Toronto, agreed yesterday to acquire timberland and sawmills in British Columbia from the Weyerhaeuser Company for 1.2 billion Canadian dollars ($975 million). The transaction included 635,000 acres of private timberland, cutting rights on government land, five sawmills and two manufacturing operations. Brascan, which controls lumber operations in Brazil, eastern Canada and Maine, is shifting its focus to timber and away from mining. Last year, a metals trading company controlled by the Chinese government offered to buy Brascan's Noranda mining operation, although the two sides have not reached an agreement. Weyerhaeuser, based in Federal Way, Wash., has been selling assets to reduce debt. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Security Plans For Border Region

He made the statements during a visit by a delegation of Texas legislators and business executives. Mr. Hernndez, who took office in January, said he had asked federal authorities to keep some 600 federal police officers in the state while reviews of all state and municipal police officers are conducted. His new security chief, Luis Roberto Gutirrez, said that more than 200 police officers with criminal records and drug addiction problems had already been fired. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: CAMPBELL SOUP PROFIT UNCHANGED FROM YEAR AGO
description: The Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that declining soup sales and more spending on promotions left second-quarter profit unchanged from the period a year earlier. Net income was $235 million, or 57 cents a share, in both years. Sales at the company, which is based in Camden, N.J., climbed 5.9 percent, to $2.22 billion, with the decline of the dollar contributing two percentage points. Analysts had expected earnings of 59 cents a share at Campbell, which gets about half of its sales from soups. Campbell said last month that it planned to raise most soup prices in the United States an average of 4.8 percent. Shares of Campbell fell 94 cents, to $28.55.

title: Arts, Briefly; New Jersey Sues Blockbuster Over Fees
description: The New Jersey attorney general's office sued Blockbuster Video yesterday, charging that the company's new fee policy violates the state's consumer protection laws. Blockbuster, the nation's largest video rental company, allows customers to keep videos and games for a week after their original due date with no late fees, but after that grace period the customer's credit card is charged the retail price of the item, minus the rental fee. If it is returned within 30 days, the customer has his money refunded but is charged a $1.25 restocking fee. Calling Blockbuster's ads "fraudulent and deceptive," Attorney General Peter C. Harvey filed a suit in Superior Court in Trenton saying that the policy violates New Jersey's Consumer Fraud Act and Merchandise Advertising Regulations by not properly advertising the penalty or the restocking fee. Randy Hargrove, a spokesman for the Dallas-based company, which operates more than 5,000 stores in the United States and about 160 in New Jersey, said Blockbuster was disappointed by the suit. "We believe this is a terrific program, because there are no more late fees," he said. "We will challenge the attorney general's lawsuit." JOHN HOLL

The real Samurai Shopper endured this winter's rain traveling to Chicago, a city often derided as a pompous Milwaukee. But Chicago, the birthplace of Curtis Mayfield and Quincy Jones and the locus of King Oliver's Creole Jazz Band, has its own clanging, speakeasy sway. Steeped in Howling Wolf and cacophonous architecture, Chicago boasts the world's largest cookie factory and indoor aquarium; its incongruous parts are greater than the flat, sulphurous whole.

title: The Remix; Querelle - A Muse You Can Use
description: Move over Gisele; meet Querelle. In only her freshman year of posing, Querelle, a 19-year-old Dutch model, has worked with Mario Testino for British Vogue, Steven Meisel for Italian Vogue and Mario Sorrenti for W, not to mention advertising campaigns for Prada and Miu Miu. Her personal style -- a spirited, gaudy mix of mainly vintage looks -- directly influenced not one but two creative powerhouses at the Paris spring collections. Marc Jacobs has said that his multicolored, circus-theme collection for Louis Vuitton was inspired by what Querelle wore to a model casting. "Marc likes bright stuff and a mix of different styles, which is what I wear every day," Querelle says, modestly acknowledging her influence. According to Querelle's booker at City models, Jean Paul Gaultier at Herms was also smitten and asked her to keep on the makeup that she walked in with, a look that the top makeup artist Stephane Marais applied to the other women in the show. From head to pointy 60's stiletto toe, Querelle is truly one to watch. LEE CARTER

title: Hollywood Stakes Out a New Free-Trade Zone
description: MEXICO CITY - CHILI westerns and movies about hookers and narcs dominated Mexican cinema during the 1980's and half of the 90's. This low-brow industry, combined with the decrepit state of movie theaters and the influx of home videos, pushed the middle class away from the big screen. Now, however, the arrival of high-tech theater chains and a new generation of Mexican filmmakers have made Mexico the seventh biggest box office in the world. And its film market is still growing while the European and Japanese markets have hit a ceiling.

title: The Revenge of Ellen Swallow
description: Back in the post-Civil War era, Ellen Swallow yearned to get a graduate degree in chemistry from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, which did not admit women. She wangled her way into classes by doing housework for her professors. "Perhaps the fact that I am not a Radical," she optimistically wrote to her parents, "and that I do not scorn womanly duties but claim it as a privilege to clean up and sort of supervise the room and sew things is winning me stronger allies than anything else." Faculty members, it turned out, were happy to let her keep darning their socks but not to give her an advanced degree. Eventually, thwarted in her attempts to get a job in chemistry, she married a metallurgy professor and invented home economics.

title: Haute Tech
description: A few years ago, I was working on a project and needed to carry my laptop around. The problem was that it didn't fit in the biggest tote I had, and I just couldn't bring myself to lug one of those ugly black padded computer bags -- you might as well complete that look with pantyhose and sneakers. Then a beauty-editor friend, with more swag than she knew what to do with, passed me a bag that had arrived full of products from Bliss: baby-blue leather, sturdy handles and almost the exact dimensions of my laptop. It was perfect, and every single time I carried it on the subway, women would ask me where I'd gotten it. It turned out I wasn't the only one who wanted to look more Bond Girl than "Working Girl."

The Face; Fringe Benefits
description: Gazing into the windows of the soul is a lot more compelling through a dramatic set of curtains. So it's no surprise that women have done everything to obtain drop-dead lashes -- literally. In the 1930's, a popular aniline lash tint called Lash Lure was all the rage until its side effects were uncovered: blindness, facial ulcers and, oh yeah, death. These days, the nontoxic supermascaras that are volumizing the market have been joined by a bumper crop of falsies, lash extenders and glosses, all designed to enlarge those peepers. Highly anticipated: fur fakes from Falsettos, an eyelash line from Scott Barnes, who designed Jennifer Lopez's red-fox pair for the 2001 Oscars. His challenge is using recycled fur. As he puts it, "I'm not into killing animals for lashes." ALEXANDRA MARSHALL

title: The Remix; Bidoun - Chic of Araby
description: Fortunately for visual-arts and culture fans, the quarterly Bidoun proves that the Middle East news media runs deeper than Al Jazeera. Bidoun, which means "without" in Farsi and Arabic, has been speaking to young people in the Middle East and beyond for the last year. Artfully designed in New York and printed in Dubai, it might seem an accompaniment to the region's luxury economy, but that's hardly the intent of its founder and editor in chief, Lisa Farjam, 27. Even Bidoun's lighter subjects -- the cultural significance of Norma Kamali harem pants, a perfume by Osama bin Laden's half brother Yeslam, the Los Angeles-based Palestinian designer Rami Kashou -- are treated with varying degrees of seriousness and humor. "We are trying to think of more subversive ways to deal with consumerism and capitalism," Farjam says. "The glossiness of it is just to seduce people to read." To find out where to buy the new issue, devoted to hair, go to www.bidoun.com. MARK JACOBS

title: In the Balance
description: There were two days left before election day, and Gen. Rostam Hamid Rahim, guerrilla war hero and a member of Iraqi Kurdistan's regional Parliament since 1992, was determined that every Kurd vote. Known as Mam (Uncle) Rostam, he told me he had joined the Kurdish nationalist militia, or peshmerga ("those who face death"), at age 15, in 1968. In 2003, he led the peshmerga into the northern city of Kirkuk -- the fourth-largest city in Iraq and its most ethnically mixed and contested -- following the American-led invasion of Iraq. Now 51, he still wore an olive shirt tucked into baggy olive pants, with a sash wrapped around his waist and a khaki vest: the traditional Kurdish garb. A black-and-white-checkered scarf encircled his head; he moved it back every so often to scratch his closely cropped hair.

title: Questions For Dan Glickman
description: Dan Glickman, the new head of the Motion Picture Association of America, defends the value of intellectual property by saying that "the founding fathers, in our Constitution, talked about copyright. They talked about the creative juices that are necessary for a free society and protecting property rights" (Deborah Solomon, Feb. 6). But the founders understood copyright to be a monopoly power, not a property right. Moreover, they were wary of monopolies, which is why the Constitution demands that they be granted "for limited times" only.

title: A Playwright Wrestles With His Judas Complex
description: WHEN Stephen Adly Guirgis first sketched out his vision for his next play, "The Last Days of Judas Iscariot," at a Labyrinth Theater Company workshop in June 2003, he came up with 10 pages. On the strength of that sample, Labyrinth scheduled the play for a reading six months later. The drama was to be set in a courtroom in a fantastical Purgatory and to involve a legal appeal for Judas's rehabilitation. The play's underlying subject was the difference between earthly and divine justice. Barely in time for the reading, Mr. Guirgis produced a 37-page draft. "It was like a trailer for a film -- coming attractions," he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MACMANUS, PATRICIA
description: MacMANUS--Patricia, an editor, writer and critic, died in Washington, DC on February 13. She began as associate editor and feature writer with Harpers Bazaar. For many years she was publicity director at Houghton Mifflin Company and Viking Press, and was an advocate for young writers dissimilar as Jack Kerouac and Louis Auchincloss. In retirement she wrote criticism and reviews for The Saturday Review and other journals; and was a volunteer reading tutor at Lenox Hill Center, Harlem Public Schools, and others. She is survived by her sister Mariquita Macmanus Mullan, and nephews Dr. Fitzhugh and Anthony Mullan of Washington and a niece, Dr. Mariquita Mullan of Boston. They stared at the open cranium, the exposed innards of what was actually a polyresin mold, and shook their heads in disappointment. In the play's final scene, which involves an enraged woman with a baseball bat, they had expected -- or at least hoped for -- a climactic explosion of red-tinged, chunky mashed banana. description: Four years ago, Ziyi Zhang, who had literally soared to the attention of Hollywood as a nobleman's beautiful daughter in "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon," arranged to meet Steven Spielberg. She knew he was interested in directing the best-seller "Memoirs of a Geisha," and though Zhang is Chinese and geishas are Japanese, she recognized the scarcity of great parts for Asian actresses and wanted him to consider her for the title role. It was a peculiar meeting. Aside from the question of nationality, Zhang did not speak English. Ang Lee, the director of "Crouching Tiger," had suggested that she learn the language, but she ignored him. Although she's ambitious, at the time she was not concentrating on the West. "In China, they don't care about American films," Zhang reasoned. "And no one thought 'Crouching Tiger' would be so successful."

"It's a lot harder than I thought it would be," says Ms. Fitch, a former graphic designer who moved back in with her parents when she started her line of natural skin-care products. "I used to think I'd be able to get up whenever and sit on the couch watching TV. But being an entrepreneur" -- successful enough to catch the eye and nose of Whole Foods buyers in her first year -- "is a ton of work."

title: Pop Rocks
description: They are called fancy diamonds. Or -- when they are particularly stellar examples -- fancy intense, fancy vivid or fancy deep. They get their kooky candy color from the presence of boron or atomic radiation. And in the case of red diamonds, the real gemological flukes, it's a matter of nature goofing off on the job. The legendary diamonds, like the Hope (blue), the Dresden Green or the Tiffany (yellow) are guarded jealously behind glass, but relatively modest baubles like the 2-, 3- and 14-carat rings on these pages are flaunted to advantage on manicured hands clutching flutes of Champagne or, on occasion, a statue of a little gold man.

title: Seeing Orange

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISSMAN, NORMAN
description: WEISSMAN--Norman. Born September 12, 1914, Bronx, to Samuel and Rose. Died February 14, 2005, Los Angeles, CA. Attended DeWitt Clinton H.S. Graduated City College, 1935. Ph.D., biochemistry, Columbia P&S, 1941, under the direction of Rudolf Schoenheimer and Harold Urey. He taught and did research at Harvard University until joining the U.S. Army to do research at Camp Detrick during WW II. After the war he returned to teaching and research at Johns Hopkins University; The Downstate Medical School at Maimonides Hospital, Brooklyn; and the Dept. of Pathology, University of Utah Medical School, from which he retired in 1970. In that year he joined BioScience Laboratories, Van Nuys, CA, where he became Senior Research Scientist, developing testing methods for the organization and becoming a toxicologist of national repute before retiring in 1982. His early love of the outdoors--his children remember wonderful stories of Boy Scout outings from the Bronx--found scope on moving to Utah in 1957. He enjoyed skiing and family camping trips, and was an early environmentalist, becoming president of the Utah Audubon Society around the time Rachel Carson published Silent Spring. He was a warm, generous man, deeply attached to family and missed by his wife of 67 years, Louise (nee Brody) of Encino, CA; brother, George (Mildred) of Rye, NY; children, Eric (Barbara), Lake Forest Park, WA; Jane Avery (Dennis), Willimantic, CT; and David (Marianne), Salt Lake City, UT; nine grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Private services.

The Artist Formally Known for Prints
description: 'Because of my name, people assumed I was a woman, which I thought was great," Yinka Shonibare said with a giant smile. Although we'd spoken on the telephone before, we'd only just met a few minutes ago and were now sitting in the sparse living room of his East London row house. In his presence -- he has a Herculean head and a Dickensian body -- I was reminded of something he'd said on the phone, about how, during a period of intense tribulation, being able to do his work had been a great comfort to him. What's striking in Shonibare's case is not only that art helped him to survive and tell his story but also that his work tackles the big issues, identity and race, with a humor rare for political art.

title: Unintelligent Design
description: Recently a school district in rural Pennsylvania officially recognized a supposed alternative to Darwinism. In a one-minute statement read by an administrator, ninth-grade biology students were told that evolution was not a fact and were encouraged to explore a different explanation of life called intelligent design. What is intelligent design? Its proponents maintain that living creatures are just too intricate to have arisen by evolution. Throughout the natural world, they say, there is evidence of deliberate design. Is it not reasonable, then, to infer the existence of an intelligent designer? To evade the charge that intelligent design is a religious theory -- creationism dressed up as science -- its advocates make no explicit claims about who or what this designer might be. But students will presumably get the desired point. As one Pennsylvania teacher observed: "The first question they will ask is: 'Well, who's the designer? Do you mean God?"'

title: Not Just a Fight Director, but a Fight-to-the-Death Director

They stared at the open cranium, the exposed innards of what was actually a polyresin mold, and shook their heads in disappointment. In the play's final scene, which involves an enraged woman with a baseball bat, they had expected - or at least hoped for - a climactic explosion of red-tinged, chunky mashed banana. Instead, they saw only a faint spattering of stage blood.

There are at least two other major components of facial aging, namely gravitational sagging and volume loss of soft tissue. Only cosmetic surgery effectively addresses all three mechanisms of facial aging.

title: Trail Blazers
description: Simone Shubuck has a floral fixation. To support herself during her starving days, she created flower arrangements at the restaurant Babbo, where she still does the centerpieces. Her art is filled with fauna and flotsam: doodles of birds, feathers, an eyeball, a Cartier bracelet, a phone number. The result feels hermetic, like school scribblings. Shubuck, influenced by outsider art from the 1960's Chicago school of Imagists and by the graffiti artist Barry McGee, says, with regret, "It's so clichd to be drawing flowers." But it's not at all girlie. Shubuck, who shows at Zach Feuer Gallery (LFL) in Chelsea, splices in lyrics from Method Man's and Jay-Z's different aliases. "I grew up in the white suburbs," says Shubuck, whose work will be at the Armory show this month. "I really wanted to be street."

Yurman finds inspiration in the unexpected: his custom-made amulets range from brass-knuckle rings inlaid with diamonds to cuff links made from animal teeth. He's even made a gold-capped necklace from his lunch: spareribs he took home in a doggie bag. Despite his well-dressed clientele and his collaborations this season with the clothing company As Four and the hipster boutiques Nom De Guerre and SSUR Plus, Yurman isn't overly impressed by fashion: "I'd prefer it if people wore my jewelry with nothing at all. title: The Remix; La Belle Emmanuelle
description: In the pantheon of soft-focus, soft-porn stars, no one holds a patchouli-scented candle to Sylvia Kristel, the crimson-lipped star of "Emmanuelle." In the 1974 classic, which presented a pseudo-intellectual agenda of sexual liberation that was part Simone de Beauvoir, part Heidi Fleiss, Emmanuelle explored interests as diverse as squash, skinny-dipping and under-age lesbianism and posed searing questions like, Does it count with a girl? Thirty years later, her spirited romps have aged about as well as Beta tapes. Her come-hither sense of bourgeois style, however, has stood the test of time. In a season filled with innuendo and flirty femininity, her garden-party dresses, A-line skirts and sheer halter tops feel remarkably up to date. Derek Lam's lychee prints are parfait for a Bangkok soiree; ditto for Proenza Schouler's palm-frond chemises and flowing gowns with peekaboo bras. But Veronique Branquinho truly captures the sensuous essence with slinky dresses, loose knits, fringed wraps and gold maillots. Branquinho's show was bookended by a tableau of long-haired girls on rattan peacock chairs (above), which our heroine favored for lounging in various stages of undress. "I'm a big fan," says Branquinho, who found the film's lighting and look inspiring. "I also love Emmanuelle as a character. She is never afraid." ARMAND LIMNANDER

description: You cannot truly understand what Los Angeles is like on Oscar night unless you live here. It's crazy. Complete gridlock from the hundreds of limos all doing the party hop. And there are a million parties -- the Vanity Fair party, the Governor's Ball, all the studio parties and the after-party parties. You've seen the endless TV coverage and the trail of magazine clippings for months after it's all over. But the one party you will never see photos of -- and will never ever get invited to -- is 28 floors up, overlooking the Hillcrest Country Club. Its host is Dani Janssen, who is, according to Frank Sinatra, one of the original Hollywood broads. Sitting with her in her penthouse as she holds a teacup toy poodle in one hand and a superlong More cigarette in the other, we quickly discover why on Oscar night, Dani's is the only place to be.

title: GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Janet Windbish, Conrade Hinds II
description: Dr. Janet L. Windbish and Conrade Carlyle Hinds II were married on Thursday at the Watermill, a caterer in Smithtown, N.Y. The Rev. Salvatore Termini, a Pentecostal minister, officiated.

title: Steak Isn't the Only Attraction
description: ANDREW'S BY THE POND in Wading River is a different kind of steakhouse. Its executive chef, John Fritz, was once the chef and owner of La Primavera in East Hills and has talents beyond firing up a grill.

title: Unhealthy Fats: Who Needs Them?
description: To the Editor:

title: Winning Back Europe's Heart; A U.N. Seat for Europe
description: Hamburg, Germany - What do Europeans want from the United States? As President Bush prepares for his first trip to Europe since his reelection -- a five-day swing through Belgium, Germany and Slovakia -- the Op-Ed page asked a variety of Europeans to name the single most important thing Mr. Bush could do to reinvigorate trans-Atlantic relations.

title: DATEBOOK
description: PARIS

title: After a Fire, a Phoenix
description: After water damage from a fire and a resolution of ownership issues, a spiffily renovated Martin Brothers has emerged as the Columbia University neighborhood's most sophisticated wine shop. Mike Martin, the wine director, has eclectic tastes. An example is Cantina Terlano's 2003 Terlaner Classico ($13.99), a tangy blend of sauvignon blanc, pinot blanc and riesling italico from Alto Adige, in northern Italy.

title: A Textbook Case of a School in a Spiral
description: It is 1965, and the brick walls of St. Teresa elementary school, in an area of Queens once known as Irishtown, are bursting at the seams. Fifty-four boys crowd into Sister Mildred Marie's sixth-grade classroom, while her counterpart, Sister John Marie, rides herd over 46 sixth-grade girls. Enrollment has just hit a new high of 1,000.

title: Oh, Those Doors of Misperception
description: New Brunswick - THOSE seven shiny doors, gussied up with red-and-black lacquer moldings in the Art Deco-style hotel suite designed by R. Michael Miller for "Lend Me a Tenor" at George Street Playhouse here, should demand star billing. During Ken Ludwig's zany, if formulaic, 1989 send-up of a regional opera company's fund-raising gala and its missing featured performer, the doors are shaken, pounded and slammed, nonstop, all the while shamelessly hiding a parade of comely females in varying stages of undress.

title: Reveal, Innocent, Ethnic
description: Reveal / (ri ve -l) / tr. v. / to make known (something concealed or secret), e.g., "This spring, it's incumbent to reveal your itsy-bitsy, teeny-weeny boy-cut bikini"; / n. / a reality television denouement when an ugly duckling's makeover is unveiled, as in, "The reveal on 'The Swan' last night was amazing -- she looked like a model, and all they gave her was facial reconstruction, breast augmentation, liposuction, a tummy tuck, Lasik surgery, Da Vinci veneers and a Diva hearing aid!" Often used in conjunction with "transformation" and "journey."

title: With Historic Status Elusive, Some Wonder if Queens Is the Problem
description: New York has 92 historic districts, including 9 in the Bronx, 3 on Staten Island, 17 in Brooklyn and 57 in Manhattan. Queens, the city's largest borough by area, has six, and residents often cite that low number as evidence that the Landmarks Preservation Commission has not given the borough its due.

title: Nuclear Reality: America Loses Bite
description: WASHINGTON - NOT so long ago, the terrifying rules of nuclear chicken were clear.

title: At 40, Hopkins Completes His 20th Title Defense
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 - Once again, 40-year-old Bernard Hopkins defied his age and dissected his opponent.

title: Corrections

After his first term, he kept an earlier promise not to seek re-election; he did not originally come to that decision as his term was ending.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a proposed fare increase being sought by New Jersey Transit misstated the hometown of Assemblyman John S. Wisniewski, the Democratic chairman of the Transportation Committee, who wants to increase the gasoline tax and put the state in a better position to finance transportation projects. He is from Sayreville, not Bordentown.

title: Bough Breaks, Threatening a Traditional Wishing Tree
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 15 - What does it mean if the main limb of a lucky Wishing Tree suddenly snaps during religious festivities and plunges to the ground, crushing the faithful?

title: The Get; What's Your Bag?
description: Express yourself with a hobo sac in arm-candy colors.

title: My Addicted Son
description: I work with troubled youth, and I have been looking for a personal story about methamphetamine addiction shocking enough to get a parent's attention but also one with a measure of hope. David Sheff's article (Feb. 6) is the story I need. It makes a very important point about resiliency. With proper treatment and parental guidance, meth addiction can be overcome, especially among young adults, whose resiliency continues to amaze me.

title: Paige Pantezzi, Eric Weiner
description: Paige Erica Pantezzi and Eric J. Weiner are to be married today at the Harold Pratt House in Manhattan. Patricia Bruder Debrovner, an adjunct leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, is to officiate.

title: The Bacon Code
description: WHEN two Westport authors, Lawrence and Nancy Goldstone, decided to write a history of the 13th-century scientist Roger Bacon, they had no idea the trail would lead them to one of the world's great mysteries.

title: The Remix; Foxymorons - Kath & Kim
description: The most talked-about new show in fashion is not on the runway, but a deadpan Australian TV comedy called "Kath & Kim." A suburban renovation of "Ab Fab," with a twist of "Strangers With Candy," "Kath & Kim" -- shown on Trio -- stars Jane Turner and Gina Riley, respectively, as a grammatically and stylistically challenged mother and daughter. The problems these self-styled "foxymorons" have with diction ("I look a hundred bucks!" or "She's the bain-marie of my existence!") are compounded by their ripped-from-the-tabloids looks, which run from 1980's Coogi sweaters and poodle perms (on Kath) to midriff-baring contempo flimsy (on Kim). As the corpulent Kim explains, in an accent that could cut through steel (pronounced "stoil"): "Mum likes to team with the theme -- she's classic, like Papilloma Picasso, with a perm. I have a foxier figure, like Rachel Hunter, so I love bumster jeans, diamante-studded G-strings and clacky moooles." Wisecracking, mall-fashion-wearing hornbags (that's Australian for "hotties"), Kath and Kim are as refreshing as a Foster's at a backyard barbie. Or, as Kim is fond of saying, about herself, "What's not to loik?" HORACIO SILVA

description: Correction Appended

title: Repairs in a Stabilized Apartment
description: Q. I have been living in the same rent-stabilized apartment in Manhattan for more than 20 years. Certain areas of my apartment -- including the kitchen and bathroom -- have not been upgraded since the building was built in the 1930's. I plan to have some basic work done, including replacing bathroom floor and wall tiles that are broken or in need of a face-lift. I would like to know how much of this type of general maintenance the building owner is required to do. . . . C. Kelly, Manhattan.

title: Airlines and Fliers Hit Tax Plan
description: Air travelers and airlines have quickly established themselves as among the loudest critics of the budget proposed by President Bush for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1.

title: The Remix; Textile Messaging
description: Long before fashion's love affair with pattern, Mark Eley and Wakako Kishimoto were scissoring the quirkiest prints this side of the Atlantic. Last year, the couple opened a stand-alone shop in Bermondsey in London to sell ready-to-wear and their favorite archival pieces. "We opened the space to serve as platform, to educate people about us," Eley says. It is also a quasi laboratory for their art and design collaborations: tables and chairs bearing a graphic lightning-bolt ("flash") pattern; a capsule collection for Ellesse, the Italian sportswear company; and luggage for Globe-Trotter. (They've also made textiles for Alexander McQueen and Marc Jacobs.) "We like to work with brands that have a heritage, companies that make sense with our aesthetics," Eley says. They recently entered the hospitality sector, designing lighting, linens, chairs and wallpaper at the House at Hautefage retreat in Bordeaux. MAURA EGAN

title: Collecting Wisdom, Discarding Weight
description: ON the eve of this President's Day, it is timely to think of our history and just how much it is worth. In dollar amounts, that is.

description: Correction Appended

description: Schubert: Piano Sonata in B flat (D. 960); Songs Leif Ove Andsnes, pianist; Ian Bostridge, tenor. EMI Classics 5 57901 2; CD.

title: Thug Love
description: Rockers and rappers have been collaborating since Run-DMC and Aerosmith hooked up for "Walk This Way" in 1986. In the last few years such partnerships have taken a surprisingly gentle turn as rap's biggest egos line up to work with some of popular music's most emotionally vulnerable-seeming stars: Jay-Z and the earnest nu-metal band Linkin Park on the album "Collision Course"; the proudly thuggish Nelly and the confessional country singer Tim McGraw for the single "Over and Over Again." Timbaland has said he wants to produce only Coldplay, fronted by the sensitive Mr. Gwyneth Paltrow.

title: Deserting the Post: League Turns Soft in the Middle
description: When I read about the trade that sent Shaquille O'Neal to the Miami Heat from the Los Angeles Lakers last summer, I flashed back to the night of Oct. 3, 1974. I was the general manager of the Milwaukee Bucks, and that was the night Kareem Abdul-Jabbar asked to be traded.

title: The Keeper of a Golden Legend
description: IT seems so well-meaning, the little dirt path of minimalism. Get rid of all the stuff you don't need or want -- all the clutter that keeps you from seeing the beauty of life, the beauty that is somewhere underneath that pile of clothes. But now the concept of clutter, of sentimentally holding on to things, is so vilified that there is even a 12-step program devoted to its more extreme practitioners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WAGNER, ALAN B.
description: WAGNER--Alan B. On February 18, 2005. Beloved husband of Phyllis. Devoted father of Michael Jacob and Daniel. Cherished brother of Mindy Wagner. Manager of the International Resource Center of Queensboro Public Library. Funeral service is at 10 AM at "Gutterman's Inc." 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: After the Prize, Just Playing His Own Horn, Not Tooting It
description: IT was a cold, dark night in February, a night out of a noir detective novel, when the Grammy Winner walked through the neon glare under the el and into the door of Willie's Steak House. A couple of strangers stepped up to congratulate him: "Hey, I saw you on TV." But here at Willie's, in the East Bronx, the regulars are not easily impressed.

title: Shifting Sands
description: This page does not have particularly strong feelings about the fate of the actor Roy Scheider's house in the Hamptons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FELD, HAROLD
description: FELD--Harold. January 5, 1915 - February 19, 2005. Adored husband of the late Isabel. Cherished father of DeeDee and the late Gerry. Loving and proud grandfather of Ben Harris. Devoted brother of the late Max Feld and the late Regina Rosen. Dear brother-in-law of the late Harold Jurman. Mr. Feld received his law degree from New York University at the age of 21, and served most courageously in the Navy during WWII. He received many honors and awards for his commitment and generosity to worthy causes. He was a Board member of Ushiva College, a Board member of Ben Gurion University and was awarded a "Keeper of the Flame" medallion from the United Jewish Appeal Federation of New York. Harold was loved by many and respected by all. Funeral services and shiva private.

title: Bonds to Report on Tuesday
description: Barry Bonds, who is recovering from arthroscopic surgery on his right knee, was expected to report to the Giants' training camp along with other position players on Tuesday, ESPN.com and the team's Web site reported. Bonds, who testified to a grand jury in the Balco steroids case, was expected to address reporters that day.

title: Amsterdam's Lloyd Hotel
description: THE BASICS -- Opened in September, the Lloyd is as eccentric and liberal-minded as the rest of Amsterdam. Built in 1921 by the Royal Holland Lloyd shipping company as a migrant hotel, the building later was a prison. Four local partners and the architecture firm MVRDV have reinvented the stone harbor building into an airy 116-room hotel with a democratic concept: guests can choose from four levels of lodging, from small $104 rooms (at $1.30 to the euro) to spacious $390 suites. But the service and sense of style are the same no matter how much one pays. One room features a table and chairs by Tjalko Lokhorst, and the hallways are still waiting for Hella Jongerius's white plastic and bronze lamps.

title: Q & A
description: We have a child with a serious food allergy and would like information about places that accommodate people with life-threatening food allergies. -- Dana Krug, West Windsor, N.J.

title: PHOTO-OP
My Addicted Son
description: Sheff correctly points out that his son was not the only victim of his addiction to crystal meth. Family members of addicts live on an emotional roller coaster characterized by pain, progress, hopefulness and hopelessness. I hope Sheff's son Nick can once again prove himself a worthy recipient of his brother Jasper's unconditional love and affection.

title: Corrections

Holding a Pencil, Never Missing a Basket
description: In December 1968, Baruch College's men's basketball team played its first game and a 1956 Baruch graduate named Burt Beagle was on the sideline as the official scorer, recording every basket, assist, steal and rebound.

title: My Addicted Son
description: It takes great courage to write something so personal. Through stories as personal as Sheff's, we can begin to understand the dynamics of addiction and how important it is to keep our children and family members safe and sober.

title: Editors' Choice
MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: RICH girls always have trouble determining who loves them for themselves. Rich, plain girls have it doubly hard. In THE HEIRESS (1949), Catherine Sloper (Olivia de Havilland, in her second Oscar-winning performance) is a New York doctor's drab daughter. And she has a devastatingly handsome suitor, Morris Townsend (Montgomery Clift). Her father (Ralph Richardson) believes that Morris has to be a fortune hunter. William Wyler directed this classic drama, based on Henry James's novel "Washington Square," by way of Ruth and Augustus Goetz's 1947 Broadway play. The final scene, when Morris returns, professing his love anew, will rip your heart out -- Tuesday at 6 p.m. on TCM.

title: F.D.A. Moves Toward More Openness With the Public
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 - Almost every headline about the remarkable hearings this week by a federal drug advisory panel focused on whether several huge-selling pain pills were safe. Just as significant, though, was what may well be the start of a cultural transformation at the Food and Drug Administration.

title: 'Nature Noir': The Lone Ranger
description: NATURE NOIR A Park Ranger's Patrol in the Sierra. By Jordan Fisher Smith. 216 pp. Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.

title: The Therapeutic Mind Scan
description: Psychiatrists are among the few doctors who don't look at the organs they treat. Imagine an orthopedist setting a bone without taking an X-ray. It would be like an auto mechanic diagnosing a faulty radiator without popping the hood. You would think he was a crook. Yet that is just what psychiatrists typically do. Instead of looking at the brain, they rely on interviews, experience, hunches and trial and error.
