description: Art and Royalty

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'CONNOR, COLLEEN A.
description: O'CONNOR--Colleen A. A journalist, educator and passionate advocate of progressive causes, Colleen died on February 16, 2005 at 55, after a long, courageous struggle with breast cancer. She leaves behind legions of heartbroken friends, who loved and admired her razorsharp wit and tenacious embrace of life. In a colorful, varied career, Colleen served in the Carter and Clinton administrations; was a columnist for The Record of Hackensack, an editor at Newsweek and wrote for People; worked as a director of public education for the ACLU, and at her death, was senior research associate at Georgetown University's Center for Public and Non-Profit Leadership. As much as her public contributions, Colleen's legacy is in the tapestry of friendships that will enshrine her in memory. Contributions may be made to the Colleen A. O'Connor Scholarship at the Alliance for Justice, 11 Dupont Circle, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20036.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOUDSMIT, ARNOLDUS, M.D.
description: GOUDSMIT--Arnoldus, M.D. Rochester, NY, Friday, February 11, 2005. Age 96. Predeceased by his wife, Hellen C. Goudsmit. He is survived by by four daughters, Doris Albert of Pittsford, NY, Frances (Allan) Tessler of Jackson, WY, Jacqueline Ann Nieman of NYC, and Eleanor (Douglas) Miller of Sandy Hook, CT; a cousin Ini Lederer of Haifa, Israel; nine grandchildren; 15 great-grandchildren; five nieces and a nephew. Born in Amsterdam, the Netherlands, Dr. Goudsmit earned his M.D, there in 1931. In 1933 he and his wife Hellen came to the US, where each earned a Ph.D. in biochemistry at Cornell Medical College (1936). His training in Internal Medicine was at the Mayo Clinic. Beginning in 1939 he was Assistant Professor of Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania; and during WWII he was a medical officer on Iwo Jima with the Army Air Corps. He practiced medicine in Youngstown, OH, taught at the University of Pittsburgh Medical School, and served as the first president of the Ohio chapter of the American Society of Internal Medicine. His vision and leadership led to the founding of the American Society of Clinical Oncology in 1964 (for which he was honored last June). In the late '60's he left private practice to assume a role as Oncologist at the Dearborn VA Hospital. Later he became Chief of Surgical Oncology at the Minneapolis VA Hospital. At age 70, Noldus enrolled in Divinity School. For a time he was Associate Minister at the First Unitarian Society of Minneapolis. He then combined his love of medicine and theology by becoming a hospital chaplain. He was a wonderful pianist, an avid hiker, an active cyclist and cross-country skier. After he moved to Rochester, NY, in 1998, he continued to attend numerous medical meetings and traveled extensively. He enriched our lives with his wisdom, kindness and vitality, as well as his warmth and optimism. We are grateful for his example of a life well lived. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, April 2, 2005, at the First Unitarian Church of Rochester, 220 Winton Road South, at 2 PM. Contributions may be directed to Advent House (a hospice house), 1010 Moseley Road, Fairport, NY 14450; Rochester Rotary Charitable Trust, 125 E. Main St, Rochester, NY 14604; or The ASCO Foundation, 1900 Duke Street, Alexandria, VA 22314, in his memory.

title: A Tweed Suit for the Bearded Lady
description: THE weather-beaten 1917 building housing the Coney Island Museum, a block from the Boardwalk at Surf Avenue and West 12th Street, is wrapped in vibrantly colorful sideshow banners, one of which breathlessly promises visitors a "Freak Show, Here, Alive" and features the giant hand of an old-time carnival barker. Its index finger points in the general direction of Aaron Beebe's office.

title: PENNSAUKEN CHURCH FILES SUIT
description: The Living Faith Christian Center, a 6,000-member church currently occupying the old South Jersey Expo Center in Pennsauken, has filed a suit against Pennsauken Township, Camden County and the Camden County Improvement Authority, saying they are taking that building away from the church illegally. Living Faith bought the old Expo Center in 2002, when its rapidly growing church outgrew its former building in Cherry Hill. The property is on land that is part of a controversial redevelopment project in Pennsauken. Earlier this month, the township county, and the Improvement Authority scrapped plans for an arena and convention center on part of the property, but continued in eminent domain proceedings and negotiations to buy the affected properties. Robert Strauss

title: Sidney Waxman, Innovator of Dwarf Pines, Dies at 81
description: Sidney Waxman, a horticulturist who hunted tirelessly for the odd growths on pine trees called witches' brooms whose cones could be propagated into dwarf evergreens for the front lawns of suburbia, died on Feb. 10 at his home in Storrs, Conn. He was 81.

title: The Remix; It Takes Two - Designer Collaborations
description: Now that "Sex and the City" is over, it really is pass to be single. It's a fact not lost on the fashion houses that are announcing high-profile partnerships with the frequency of flagship-store openings in the late 90's. Stella McCartney seems at home interpreting polished athletic wear for Adidas (far left). The Imitation of Christ designer Tara Subkoff marries Lower Manhattan irony and post-irony in her work with Easy Spirit to create politically determined, vaguely sarcastic feminist flats that look like a gladiator sandal but feel like a sneaker. Diane von Furstenberg has two twofers, lending her face to a Samsung mobile phone (center) decorated with her 1974 Andy Warhol portrait as well as designing an eponymous line of statement jewelry for H.Stern (near left). The music-world polyhyphenate Pharrell Williams has weighed in on Louis Vuitton sunglasses that are sure collectibles. And then there is the ultimate marriage of art and corsets, as Matthew Barney is in discussions with Proenza Schouler to design the costumes for his next cinematic opus. Can the Barneys Biennial be far behind? MARK JACOBS

title: Letters to the Editor
In Mumbai, Those Bollywood Nights Heat Up
description: ANOTHER Thursday night in Mumbai, another celebrity-packed crowd at the Olive Bar and Kitchen.

title: The Plaisir Principle
A Sky-High Playground
description: ASPEN, Colo. - ASPEN'S air is as thin as its denizens are rich, which was repeatedly illustrated last weekend at the upper level of the 39 Degrees lounge at the Sky Hotel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUILFOYLE, SHIRLEY ANNE
description: GUILFOYLE--Shirley Anne. Of NYC. Beloved wife of the late John W. Guilfoyle, International Telephone & Telegraph executive. Died at home on Thursday, February 17, 2005 at age 81. Born in Chicago, IL, she and her late husband traveled extensively throughout the world. Loving mother of Patricia (Sandy) Guilfoyle and grandmother of Dr. Rebecca Goldstein, Aaron John Guilfoyle and his wife Liz, and the late Jennifer Goldstein. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street Sunday February 20, 4-7 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 10 A.M. at St. Catherine of Siena Church, 411 E. 68th St. Interment of Christ the King Cemetery, Franklin Lakes, New Jersey.

title: O Brother, Where Art Thou?
description: The smart and shapely novels of Peter Robinson win all the awards while rarely making the best-seller lists. But whenever I am asked to lecture on the British detective story, I choose one of his immaculately constructed books to illustrate the perfection of the form. If I were to give that lecture today, I would stick with Robinson, this time using STRANGE AFFAIR (Morrow, $24.95), his 15th novel featuring Detective Chief Inspector Alan Banks, a Yorkshire copper who is rock-solid on the job but given to black moods in times of personal crisis.

title: The Get; Flat Is a Feminist Issue
description: Free your toes and your mind will follow.

title: His Art Is His Joy. It Just Didn't Fit My Plan.
description: THE parking lot at my son's graduation is a sea of motorcycles: black, yellow, loud, smoke-belching, flame-adorned, sparkling with chrome so bright you have to look away. Far from the dappled shade of any Ivy League campus, this blazing blacktop belongs to the Motorcycle Mechanics Institute in Phoenix, Ariz., a sprawling complex of freshly whitewashed, warehouse-size buildings with red and blue accent lines. Inside are classrooms, labs and mock dealers shops for the students who, like my son, Alex, study to become certified in the assembly and repair of motorcycles.

title: Not-So-Magic Schoolbuses
description: New Rochelle - NOW that the Environmental Protection Agency has cited areas of Orange, Rockland and Westchester Counties with violating federal fine particle pollution, or soot, standards, it's time to get serious about reducing air pollution.

title: American Choppers
description: "Smiles are looking too much alike." This is strange criticism coming from Dr. Smile himself, Jonathan B. Levine, the man who credits himself with shaping Christie Brinkley's "iconic American smile." Levine is a prosthodontist, an expert in the restoration and replacement of teeth. He is sizing up the smiles on "The Swan" and "Extreme Makeover."

title: TAKE THAT!
description: The men who run Emmis Broadcasting have been busy apologizing for a song parody mocking tsunami victims that was broadcast on the company's Hot 97 radio station in New York in January, but not too busy to negotiate raises.

title: Winning Back Europe's Heart; No New Wars
description: Vienna - What do Europeans want from the United States? As President Bush prepares for his first trip to Europe since his reelection -- a five-day swing through Belgium, Germany and Slovakia -- the Op-Ed page asked a variety of Europeans to name the single most important thing Mr. Bush could do to reinvigorate trans-Atlantic relations.

title: The Remix; Leaf Motif
description: Of the myriad prints that hit the New York runways, Alejandro Cardenas's elegantly kitschy florals and tropical scenes for Proenza Schouler were hard to miss. But he is reluctant to take credit. An artist and graphic designer, Cardenas, 27, says it's his job to translate what the label's designers, Lazaro Hernandez and Jack McCollough, have in mind. "One thing we don't do is copy vintage stuff," Cardenas says. "I enjoy the fact that I'm a draftsman."

title: Corrections
description: An "In the Region" article in some copies last Sunday about the construction of a new music arts center at Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, Conn., misstated the names of two designers of the project and a faculty member. The founder of Centerbrook Architects of Essex is Jefferson B. Riley, not Wiley. The New York theater designer who participated is Charles Cosler, not Colson. The chairman of the Hotchkiss music department is Fabio Witkowski, not Fadio Witkowsky.

title: Slowing the Pace Along Brazil's Coast
description: FOR most Americans, accustomed to thinking of Rio de Janeiro as their first and only destination, Brazil's vast northeast shoulder is largely uncharted territory. While Europeans have in recent years begun flocking to the region's spectacular beaches and fallen under the spell of its infectious music, American visitors have lagged far behind in exploring the many delights that seaside resort cities such as Recife, Natal and Fortaleza can offer, all at a fraction of what comparable packages in the Caribbean would cost.

title: Bad Economy Leads Iranians to Seek Fortune in Supernatural
description: TEHRAN, Feb. 19 - Rojan spread the tarot cards swiftly on a prayer mat. "In the name of God," she said as she began carefully switching their places. "There is a lot of energy in this room."

title: Kitchen Voyeur: Clam Shack
description: 'Well, why don't we make all three?" Francine Farkas Sears announced buoyantly on the phone. We were trying to determine the "best" one-pot dish to serve for dinner at her house. Rather than wrestle with hypotheticals, this extremely well organized former stockbroker, current C.E.O. of her own company, mother of four and wife of three or four decided to make them all: a chicken bouillabaisse, braised lamb shanks and a Southern fricassee of chicken with yams and two dozen shallots.

title: That Pesky New York Nickel
description: Until this year, most committee meetings for the New York State Legislature were gaveled open and closed in the blink of a chairman's eye. The sessions were often so brief that members barely had time to devour the bagels and coffee dutifully provided by the staff, much less the subject at hand. Not so these days in the new reform-minded Albany. In important new ways, the public has been invited to the table -- at least for now.

He had just appeared live on "Your World," a business program, to discuss a scandalous brawl that had taken place at a game between the Indiana Pacers and the Detroit Pistons. He does not represent either team or the league, but as a publicist who has a nose for conflict he was asked how this fight would affect the N.B.A. brand.

title: A New Generation Finds Paradise in Honolulu

Mr. Brothers and his girlfriend, Monique Zordan, were adding some city time to their Hawaiian vacation after hearing that Honolulu was attracting a youthful, high-spirited crowd. A friend, Mr. Brothers said, had come back from Honolulu, raving about how it was a "happening place," and they weren't letting the opportunity pass them by.

title: The Cuban Import
description: A question mark hovers above Kendry Morales like a halo. One of the newest members of the Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim baseball team, which begins spring training this week, he may be the best young hitter ever to defect from Cuba. Or, just as likely, he may be another overhyped bust, like so many Cuban prospects before him. When I met him last summer, a couple of months after his flight from Cuba, at his temporary home in the Dominican Republic, there were only two people who seemed certain of his success. One was Morales himself. The other was John Di Manno, an accountant from Toronto.

title: INVESTIGATION OF SCHOOL AGENCY
description: Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey has asked the state's new inspector general, Mary Jane Cooper, to investigate reports that the state agency charged with building local schools has overpaid for construction and management contracts. Mr. Codey's decision came after articles in The Star Ledger, of Newark, that reported that schools built by the state School Construction Corporation have typically cost 45 percent more than schools built by local districts. School Construction is charged with managing $8.6 billion to build schools in low-income districts. A spokeswoman for Mr. Codey said the inspector general is still assembling a staff and is expected to begin work on the investigation sometime in the next few weeks. John Sullivan

title: The Remix; Game Plan
description: Looking for something to wear for beating around the bush? It's your season: every house from Viktor & Rolf to Max Mara has gone on safari. MaxMara's take, pictured here, is soothingly traditional (read: it won't alarm rhinos), especially when paired with this scarf and necklace, both from Herms; Calvin Klein sandals; and a Tod's bracelet. Elsewhere, Stefano Pilati's green safari jacket (part of his first collection for YSL Rive Gauche) dips into the archives with flair. Tom Ford's successor at Gucci, Alessandra Facchinetti, offers a similar shape. Diane von Furstenberg has also entered the game park, pairing a Lauren Hutton-worthy shirt with satin shorts, while Roberto Cavalli's safari hat might ward off the Serengeti vultures. Meanwhile, Dolce and Gabbana are straight out of Africa. Inspired by a recent trip to Botswana and Zambia, the designing duo tiered their models arms' with bangles, draped their bodies in snakeskin, shod them in zebra-patterned boots and topped even their heads with leopard print. Too bad no one thought of binoculars. ALEXANDRA ZISSU

title: Contributors
description: NOBUYOSHI ARAKI The Japanese artist Nobuyoshi Araki is known for his erotic photographs of flowers and young girls trussed in a bit of rope and not much else. For this issue, the 64-year-old photographer, three of whose books are pictured at far right, shot the "Like a Virgin" fashion feature (Pages 202 to 209). While the images of young Japanese models wearing the pretty white clothes of spring portray a certain innocence not often associated with Araki's work, the project was not, in fact, an extreme creative departure. The shoot took place at a former "love hotel" in the Shinjuku neighborhood of Tokyo, a building that is close to the artist's heart and work -- a place, he says, where you can feel something of both death and life. Araki also took with him some specimens from his collection of plastic dinosaurs and lizards, a signature flourish that appears in the photographs in a "Where's Waldo?" manner. A new series of his work, "Kaori," featuring the model Kaori, is at the Reflex New Art Gallery in Amsterdam. He is currently preparing a major retrospective at the Barbican Centre in London for later this year. ALIX BROWNE

title: La Belle Emmanuelle
The Remix; Vintage Point
description: Now that New York has reinstated its recycling program, fashion lovers are taking it to heart, raiding their own wardrobes for items from the uncomfortably recent past. This practice, known as "shopping your closet," is the product of a shrinking fashion cycle, when a garment goes from new to vintage within a ridiculously short time span. Where one was once expected to wear a signature desinger piece for a couple of years before mothballing it, it is now newly permissible, for example, to reanimate a six-year-old Pleats Please if the extraordinary folds of Lanvin's spring collection compel one to do so. A bowas-dress by Viktor & Rolf might inspire the resurrection of a Vivienne Westwood gown with a giant wilted bow from 1994. And the spirit of Proenza Schouler's gold bodysuit might be enjoyed in a silver bustier from Dolce & Gabbana that dates to fall/winter 1998. Is the idea of vintage Mark Jacobs too confusing? Mark Jacobs

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOED, MARJORIE MCWILLIAMS
description: MOED--Marjorie McWilliams November 20, 1916-February 16, 2005. Marjorie McWilliams Moed died quietly at her home in New York, the city of her birth. She was the daughter of the late James and Mildred McWilliams. Her father was the contractor and builder of the Barracks buildings on Governor's Island in New York Harbor, and numerous Loew's movie theaters from New York City to Atlanta, the site of the "Gone With The Wind" premiere. Mrs. Moed was the devoted wife of the late Benjamin Moed; and loving mother of Charles J. Moed, Helen McWilliams Pomeroy, and the late Edward K. Moed; grandmother of Lawrence Ben Pomeroy, mother-in-law of Lawrence K. Pomeroy; and sister of James McWilliams. Mrs. Moed was a graduate of Hunter High School, NY. Her exceptional math skills and photographic memory helped win a scholarship at Wellesley College, Class of 1936, and she attended New York University's School of Law. A resident of Scarsdale, NY, for close to 60 years, Mrs. Moed was a past president of the Wellesley in Westchester Club and the Quaker Ridge Parent Teacher Association. She retired as President of Chedward Realty Corporation. An enthusiast of archeology, she and her husband visited the Dead Sea and Palestinian digs on their honeymoon voyage in 1938. A devoted opera buff, Mrs. Moed regularly attended the Metropolitan Opera with librettos dating from her childhood. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Mrs. Moed's favorite causes: Keewaydin Foundation, Irish Boys, 10 Keewaydin Road, Salisbury, VT, 05769. Operation USA, 8320 Melrose Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90069. www.OPUSA.org

This had a certain ring to it, yet it was a ring I couldn't help feeling I had heard before and would hear again. So I resisted, successfully. The subtitle ended up being two words that went beyond simple clich into profound vanilla: "A Biography."

title: Cuff Love
description: The Texan style maven Lynn Wyatt doesn't do anything halfway, and her Verdura cuffs are no exception. "I think one cuff is beautiful, but two make twice the statement," says Wyatt in her honeyed drawl. The longtime couture client would almost be derelict not to own a pair. Verdura's founder, Duke Fulco di Verdura, designed the originals in 1936 for Coco Chanel, who loved them so much that she rarely removed them. Like Chanel, Wyatt wears hers day and night. "They look as wonderful with a black cashmere sweater and trousers as they do with a white gown or cocktail dress," Wyatt says.The Maltese crosses on her bracelets are detachable, so she can wear the gold, pearl and coral ones either on the cocholong cuffs shown here (cocholong is a white stone exclusive to Russia) or on a pair she owns in carnelian. "At the end of the day I'm just a very practical girl. I take off the Maltese centers with a little screwdriver that came with the cuffs. In the summer I usually wear the white pair. In winter, the coral and gold on the carnelian is a knockout."Verdura fits each cuff (prices start at $12,000) to its owner's wrist and lets her decide where on the wrist she'd like to wear it. "I like mine to be a bit looser," Wyatt says, "so I can wear them under a sweater." The famously svelte socialite adds with a chuckle, "My waist size might change, but hopefully my wrists will stay the same." SANDRA BALLENTINE

The new look is more Jayne Mansfield than Heidi Klum -- not unlike the relatively modest two-piece number modeled by Babette March on the first Sports Illustrated swimsuit cover. Granted, this was hot stuff back in 1964, when the mini was starting to revolutionize fashion, and decades before the little Brazilian stringy thingy became the norm. Carolina Herrera's boy-cut has pinup appeal, while Yohji Yamamoto's for Y-3 is more befitting the figure of the swimmer Jenny Thompson. But any way you cut it, the bikini is going to be big, requiring so much fabric, it's like getting four pieces for the price of two. ALIX BROWNE

title: The Remix; Dress You Up - The Immaculate Collection
description: All that cabala and yoga has taught Madonna to look deep within . . . her closet. So she hired Karine Prot to catalog every incarnation of her wardrobe, from tour and movie costumes to outfits from 20 years of public appearances. Going through the Material Girl's material isn't as easy at it seems, even for someone like Prot, who assisted Hamish Bowles, of Vogue, on the Jacqueline Kennedy exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Not only does Prot have to clean and pack each item, but she also has to identify it. "I do my own informal research," Prot says. "A lot of the Madonna-fan Web sites are really helpful." When stumped, she can turn to the expert. "Madonna usually remembers everything about a piece." The matriarch of pop agrees, saying, "God gave me a steel-trap memory, which serves me well most of the time."

description: A glorious splash of orange, the 7,500 "gates" by Christo and Jeanne-Claude, twists and turns through Central Park from 59th Street to 110th Street. The installation became a 21st-century happening last week, pulling in throngs from across the continent and over the ocean. Many visitors, caught up in the frenzy of saffron, plunged into matching costumes. Some carried orange African daisies. Dogs wore orange. The color made a backdrop for statues, lending a party air, which will vanish after Feb. 28, to clear the way for nature's spring painting.

title: The Remix; The Plaisir Principle
description: Gentry Lane is precisely the sort of American whom Oliver Wendell Holmes was referring to when he equated Paris with heaven. Though raised in Southern California, Lane has lived in the city of lumire since 1998. And not only has she assimilated to such a degree that she flounces around town in high heels and a fur coat, but she also earns her living designing lingerie, a signifier as Franaise as unfiltered Gauloises. "Most French lingerie is made in Asia now," explains Lane, 35. "Mine is all made domestically, right down to the lace trim." Of all her pieces, which have names like Kept Woman and the Heiress, Lane's best-seller is her cashmere jersey panties, which she was prompted to design after reading that Coco Chanel was the first designer to use cashmere wool jersey for outerwear (it was considered suitable only for undergarments at the time). Cut from a knit that's made exclusively for her by Loro Piana, Lane's whisper-soft briefs, which range from $78 to $135, come in a thong, a boy short and what she calls "the big-girl panty." Thanks to Henri Bendel and Victoria's Secret, Lane sells her goods here in her native land, where they'll perhaps be most appreciated. "I cut big," she says. "I cut for Americans." NANCY MacDONELL SMITH

title: Inside the List
description: AN "UNDERDOG" BOOK: It's rare for a first novel, especially a "literary" one, to make the Times best-seller list -- but Curtis Sittenfeld has pulled off that feat with her dreamy and mordant debut, "Prep." The novel, about a Midwestern girl's experiences at an elite East Coast boarding school, makes its first appearance this week at No. 11 on the hardcover fiction list. Sittenfeld, who is 29, says she wasn't prepared for the book's reception. "I saw 'Prep' as an underdog book," she said in a telephone interview. "There wasn't exactly a bidding war for it. My agent sent it to 15 publishers before Lee Boudreaux, an editor who was then at Random House, loved it and bought it." There are a lot of reasons "Prep" is resonating with readers, says Daniel Menaker, Random House's executive editor in chief -- he cites the book's eye-catching cover, and the fact that the novel addresses timely and complicated class and race issues. "But most important," he says, "the book happens to be terrific." After a first printing of 16,000 copies, there are now some 70,000 copies of "Prep" in print; Paramount recently bought the film rights. Sittenfeld's original title for her novel was "Cipher," and she is now glad she was talked out of it. "People thought it must be a murder mystery," she said. Before publication, she came up with a long list of other potential titles -- including "Class Day" and "The Privilege Thief" -- before settling on "Prep." "The title was Lee Boudreaux's idea," Sittenfeld said. "It came to her as a kind of vision. Now I can't imagine it any other way."

These earthworks must be impervious to weather and erosion and convey archetypal warnings, as language and societal institutions may become unrecognizable over such a time span. Since this problem demands what could be termed "anti-art," designed to repel rather than attract viewers, Heizer, with his ornery personality and megalomania, may be just the man for the job.

title: Hyperreality Hobbying
description: Reborn Dolls A couple of years ago, Mandy Gernand was poking around on eBay for dolls, which she collected. Then she noticed something weird -- among the listings for the dolls, she recalls, were "all these pictures of babies." Of course, these were not actual babies being auctioned. They were reborn dolls. "Reborning" is the name that has emerged for a curious process of altering and enhancing a baby doll to look and even to feel as much like a human baby as possible. Gernand decided she had to buy one. Once she got it, she decided she had to make one. Soon she started selling her reborn dolls through eBay as well as her own Web site. (Occasionally the dolls are sold at fairs and the like, but the market is mostly online.) Recently she listed a doll that she named Alexandra, and the highest of the 21 bids was for $510. "This whole reborn-doll thing is like this secret society," Gernand says. "People don't find it unless they stumble upon it."

title: French Dressing

The loose ribbon ties at the neck of a dress seem to invite someone to pull. There's also a sense of comfort. Even women who would never consider wearing a full skirt -- oh, no, no, no, moi? -- are surprised at how easy it is with Elbaz. That's the secret to Lanvin's rebirth: he's putthe chic back in French fashion and made clothes you can actually wear. Now there's a concept. Three French actresses -Virginie Ledoyen, Juliette Binoche and Audrey Tautou -- show how easily it's done.

title: Up Front
description: Although the Book Review does not have staff reviewers, some contributors appear in the section so often that we identify them as regulars. One such is Liesl Schillinger, who has written 16 reviews for us in the past year, on books ranging from a history of the chess queen to the new novel by Larry McMurtry and the latest manifesto by Ann Coulter. A voracious reader since childhood, Schillinger is the daughter of academics -- her father taught Russian, her mother taught journalism. "I grew up in university towns in the Midwest, mostly West Lafayette, Ind. and Stillwater, Okla.," she wrote in an e-mail message. "I had a reading list my mother drew up, from the time I was 5, a book a week. I never thought to question the list." Her reading wasn't confined to English. At age 10, she began studying French alongside college students at Purdue, and later added Spanish, German, Italian and Russian. It was good training for fact checking at The New Yorker, the job she landed after she graduated from Yale in 1988. She has been at the magazine ever since -- she's now an arts editor there -- apart from a brief stint in Russia editing the English supplement of Moscow magazine. Schillinger went over in the spring of 1993 and stayed, she recalled, "till the end of the summer, living in workers' apartments in a far-flung district on Moscow's eastern periphery, in the middle of a grove of apple trees" -- digs as exotic in their way as the five-star establishment she writes about this week in "Hotel Confidential" (Page 23). title: Wallet Scrutiny
description: Driving to work, I found a wallet in the road containing identification and more than $300, which I suspected was the "bag money" of a street-corner drug dealer. I did some online research, and the guy has had legal troubles and currently owes child support. May I mail him his ID, send half the money to his ex-wife to support his child and keep the rest as a reward for my good deed? E.B., Connecticut You should not return ill-gotten gains to the ill-getter -- if you found bags of money stolen from a bank, you would deliver them to the bank, not the bank robber -- but why are you certain that this is what you have found? That $300 is not so magnificent a sum as to require a felonious accounting. You simply don't know the source of this money. If you have a strong suspicion that the wallet is evidence of criminal behavior, turn it in to your local police station. If not, mail it back to its owner.

The lawsuit drew wide publicity, particularly because it included allegations by at least 19 of the men that they had been abused by one former priest, James T. Hanley. The case was unusual in that Mr. Hanley helped it by providing a sworn statement about how he had committed numerous acts of sexual abuse against children. Tina Kelley

They then boarded a Manhattan-bound F train, the police said, but officers found them a few stops later, at the Van Wyck Boulevard Station. The men were held there until the victim arrived and identified them as his attackers, the police said. The suspects were identified as Raheem Bailey, 28, of 112-19 208th Street in Queens, and Alonzo Jones, 25, of 302 Turtle Road in Woodbury, Conn. They were charged with robbery and assault, the police said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: The Americans Are Coming
description: Rarely has a visit to Europe by a U.S. president generated as much anticipation as the one by George W. Bush that gets under way today. The reason is obvious: trans-Atlantic discord has escalated over the last four years, raising doubts about the validity of the North Atlantic alliance, and even over whether the term "Western" still connotes a shared vision of the world. We believe that it does, and that NATO can remain the premier instrument for guaranteeing the security and freedom of countries that buy into the values that bind Europe and America. But it will take a lot of hard work to undo the damage of these four years. Banquets and speeches about shared histories are good, but Iraq, Iran, Syria, North Korea, China, Africa and a host of other places need joint attention.

title: Arts, Briefly; Read a Book, See a Movie
description: This year's Guardian Hay Festival, an annual bookfest in Hay, a town on the Welsh-English border with 1,300 inhabitants and 39 bookstores, will be adding a film festival to its events. Spike Lee, below, Jane Fonda and Goldie Hawn are on the list to appear at its inaugural program, which will take place in a new but temporary state-of-the-art theater at Hay Castle from May 27 to June 25. Among the authors who have agreed to participate this year in the 19th festival -- typically the event draws up to 90,000 visitors -- are Ian McEwan, Kazuo Ishiguro, Philip Pullman, David Mitchell and Joan Didion. The theater director Peter Brook is also said to attend. Elvis Costello has confirmed that he will perform and other pop stars are being lined up. The full program is to be announced on April 1. title: Arts, Briefly; 'Hitch' Cruises at No. 1
description: The Valentine spirit endured at the box office as romance trumped the demonic over the Presidents' Day weekend. Sony Picture's record-breaking romantic comedy "Hitch," starring Will Smith, below, held the No. 1 spot at the box office for the second weekend in a row with $31.8 million in estimated ticket sales, narrowly beating the theological thriller "Constantine" (Warner Brothers), starring Keanu Reeves, which opened at No. 2 with $30.5 million in receipts. "Hitch" has grossed $90,115,000 in just 10 days of release. The family comedy "Because of Winn-Dixie" (Fox), starring Jeff Daniels, Cicely Tyson and AnnaSophia Robb, about a girl who adopts a stray dog, opened in the No. 3 spot with $10,850,000 in sales. "Son of the Mask," New Line's second attempt to resuscitate a Jim Carrey franchise without Mr. Carrey ("Dumb and Dumberer" was the other), opened at No. 4 on sales of $7,675,000. Clint Eastwood's "Million Dollar Baby" (Warner Brothers) continues to pack a punch in the top 5; it took an estimated $7,190,000 over the three-day frame. CATHERINE BILLEY

The man, Bereford Muarry, 46, was staying at 107-42 Remington Street and started fires to stay warm, said Brian Grogan, a supervising fire marshal. On Friday night, one of those fires got out of control and burned through the roof, officials said. A neighbor saw Mr. Muarry leave the house that night and later called fire marshals, the authorities said. Mr. Grogan said Mr. Muarry had been charged with third-degree arson, reckless endangerment and criminal mischief. No one was hurt in the fires. Patrick O'Gilfoil Healy (NYT)

Mr. Palange did not realize that Robert, who was taken to Stony Brook University Hospital, had wandered into the path of the car. Mr. Palange will not face charges in the accident, but he was arrested on an unrelated charge of violating an order of protection that his wife had taken out against him, the police said. Despite the standing order, Mr. Palange had been staying at his wife's home with her permission, the police said.

title: Arts, Briefly; Ailing Versailles Sculpture
description: Versailles began a fund-raising campaign last week to save its deteriorating outdoor statues. The park is seeking about $365,000 from private sources to restore the first batch of 25 items from the its collection of 286 sculptures, cases and marble statues. Donations of $4,000 to $40,000 had already started to come in, encouraged by tax benefits, a spokesman for the Versailles museum and gardens said. Companies and individuals contributing money to the restoration will have their names inscribed on small plaques on the base of each item. The garden park, open to the public since the reign of Louis XIV, receives about seven million visitors each year and is a Unesco World Heritage site, but the sculptures have suffered from natural erosion and from pollution and are in urgent need of repair, the spokesman said. description: "Third Watch" and "Medical Investigation" shared a storyline and characters on Friday night and brought NBC a victory in Nielsen's overnight ratings. On Sunday CBS edged out ABC in households, but ABC, as usual, was No. 1 in the 18-to-49 demographic because of the strength of "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition" and "Desperate Housewives" in that age group. Sunday's much-anticipated gay-marriage episode of "The Simpsons" drew almost 10.5 million viewers and helped deliver a second-place finish for Fox among 18-to-49-year-olds for the night. Paid Notice: Deaths   NESVIG, TIMOTHY WILLEM
description: NESVIG--Timothy Willem, of New York City, died February 8, 2005, at the City of Hope Cancer Center in Duarte, CA, after a courageous 18-month battle against lymphoma. The disease overcame him, but never defeated him. He was 30 and lived in New York City. Tim was an account executive at ESPN/ABC Sports Customer Marketing and Sales in New York. Previously, he worked as a media supervisor at Carat, NY, and a media buyer at DDB/Needham, NY. Tim received a bachelor's degree in economics from Bucknell University, where he also captained the water polo team, receiving All-America, as well as Academic All-America honors in that sport. In 1996, he received the Christy Matthewson Award as Bucknell's outstanding male athlete. Tim was born October 23, 1974, in Santa Monica, CA, and attended the Greenwich, CT, public schools, graduating from Greenwich High School in 1992. He was a four year varsity letterman in swimming and won Connecticut All-State swimming honors in two events. He captained the Greenwich High water polo team and won Eastern Interscholastic and High School All America recognition. As an adult, he became an avid golfer and was a member of the Innis Arden Golf Club in Old Greenwich, CT. Tim is survived by his parents, Jon and Hanneke Nesvig, of Riverside, CT, and two sisters, Mieke and Carrie Nesvig, both of New York City. A memorial service will be held Monday, February 28, 4:30pm, at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th St, New York. The family requests donations be made to the Tim Nesvig Fellowship for Lymphoma Research, City of Hope Cancer Center, c/o Kathleen Kane, 1055 Wilshire Blvd, Suite 1200, Los Angeles, CA 90017. Contributions are tax-deductible.

title: Most Nonstops
description: MOST NONSTOPS -- Delta Air Lines has the most domestic nonstop flights scheduled this month, according to OAG, the publisher of airline flight schedules and other industry data. Delta scheduled 135,089 domestic nonstops for February (on planes with a total of 13.6 million seats.) That is 15.8 percent of the total domestic nonstop flights. American, the operating unit of AMR, was second with 119,661 nonstops and 12.7 million seats, a 14 percent market share. Next were United, the operating unit of UAL, with 96,796 domestic nonstops with 9.6 million seats, for an 11.3 percent market share. Then came US Airways (89,585 nonstops with 7.5 million seats and a 10.5 percent market share), and Southwest (78,194 nonstops with 10.6 million seats and a 9.2 percent market share), OAG said.

title: Arts, Briefly; British Charity Rejects 'Jerry Springer' Opera Donation

The group, Christian Voice, has recently become a vocal foe of the musical, protesting a BBC television broadcast. On Christian Voice's Web site, its national director, Stephen Green, calls the show "a gratuitously nasty, hateful, spiteful and blasphemous piece of work." The charity, Maggie's Center, said in a statement, "Maggie's exists to help cancer sufferers, their families, friends and carers, and to risk causing offense to anyone seemed unnecessary." The Christian Voice called the center's rejection a victory, labeling the donation "tainted money." The Avalon company, which produced the musical, declined to comment but has said it would still make a donation to another charity. PAM KENT

title: High School Reform, Round 1
description: President Bush raised the country's hopes last month when he previewed a $1.5 billion initiative that would promote desperately needed reform in the American high school system. The package laid out in the president's budget proposal touches on many of the right issues, but it is underfinanced and poorly conceived -- and dead on arrival in Congress, which has signaled its intent to ignore crucial provisions of Mr. Bush's proposal. The White House, which failed to push for adequate funds for its last big education initiative, the No Child Left Behind Act, has only itself to blame for failing to do the necessary preparation before unveiling this big idea. Nevertheless, Congress should understand what's at stake here. As school reform grinds to a halt in Washington, American students are falling further and further behind their peers in Asia and Europe, where universally accessible quality schools are producing highly skilled workers at a rate that far outstrips schools in the United States.

title: Choosing Iraq's Prime Minister

That now makes him the leading contender. But his support base remains dangerously narrow, extending not much further than the 140 national assembly seats, out of 275, held by the Shiite bloc. Others remain in the race, including Ayad Allawi, the interim prime minister since last June. On paper, neither man looks like an ideal choice to lead Iraq through the troubled times ahead. Perhaps a better alternative will surface. But a more realistic hope is that the very challenges of running a diverse democracy may force one of these imperfect politicians to rise to the occasion.

title: CANTOR FITZGERALD LOSES BOND TRADING PATENT CASE

The ruling was a blow to Cantor and its ESpeed electronic-trading unit, which sued the ICAP units Garban and BrokerTec for patent infringement in 2003. Michael Spencer, chief executive of ICAP, said in a statement that the company was "delighted" with the ruling. A Cantor spokesman, Michael Geller, declined to comment on the verdict.

title: Arts, Briefly; Saving Shakespeare's Rose
description: Sixteen years ago the site of the 16th-century Rose Theater in London, the workplace of the young Shakespeare as featured in the film "Shakespeare in Love," was discovered underground during routine construction work in London's Bankside district. Since the discovery, volunteers and patrons -- including the theater stars Judi Dench, Peter Hall, Janet Suzman and Susannah York -- have worked to raise money to establish a museum to display the artifacts found at the dig. On March 8 the group is to announce a project director for the museum, a necessary step to obtain public money from the Heritage Lottery Fund. The director of the Rose Theater Trust, Tony Toller, said about $9.5 million was needed to complete the excavation and added that the group had had difficulty finding the right person to be project director. "He really needs to be three different people," Mr. Toller said. "An archaeologist, an engineer and a marketing man." PAM KENT

Creative, brave, warm, fun, funny, feisty, a true friend. She was loved by many, many people. She is an inspiration to everyone who was lucky enough to know her. Robin asked for a homecoming rather than a memorial service. The Homecoming will be Sunday, February 27th at 5PM at the Hugugeot Memorial Church, 901 Pelhamdale Ave, Pelham, N.Y. title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Prison Terms In Rock Band Killings
description: Two members of a heavy metal band called the Beasts of Satan were convicted in a double slaying in 1998 that fanned fears in Italy of satanic cults, as well as violence and drug use, among teenagers. The band leader, Andrea Volpe, was sentenced to 30 years in prison for the murder of a 19-year-old woman, also a member of the band, apparently on the belief that she personified the Virgin Mary, and her 16-year-old boyfriend. Mr. Volpe, who confessed to the crimes and led the police last year to the long-missing bodies, was also convicted for killing his 27-year-old girlfriend last year. Another band member, Pietro Guerrieri, received 16 years in prison for the 1998 killing, while a third man was acquitted. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: 9 Soldiers Die In Chechnya
description: Nine Russian soldiers were killed and three others wounded by Chechen separatists in the outskirts of Grozny, Chechnya's capital, Russian officials said. The attack, one of the most lethal in recent months, occurred when the soldiers from the 42nd Motorized Rifle Division stopped at an abandoned chicken farm in Prigorodnoye and came under fire. A roof collapsed during the brief battle, killing the soldiers, the officials said. Gen. Sergei Surovikin, the division commander, appearing on television, said two separatists were killed, including an Arab, and another injured. title: Arts, Briefly; A Spike in Thompson's Book Sales
description: A cult figure in life, Hunter S. Thompson is likely to remain one long after his death, at least judging by book buyers' response to his suicide in the last three days. No fewer than nine books by Mr. Thompson were ranked among the top 100 best-selling books on Amazon.com yesterday. On Barnes & Noble.com, seven titles were on the top-100 list yesterday afternoon. Unfortunately for readers, most of the titles were temporarily sold out, with delivery times ranging from two days to two weeks. Among the top sellers were the Vintage paperback edition of "Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas"; "Hey Rube," a collection of recent sports articles published last year by Simon & Schuster; and two archetypes of what came to be known as gonzo journalism, "Hell's Angels" (Ballantine), right, and "Fear and Loathing: On the Campaign Trail '72," (Warner Books). description: Two young men fell into a violent argument early yesterday morning, starting at a party in an apartment in the Sheepshead Bay section, spilling down a stairwell, and ending in a public courtyard with one man stabbed to death, the police said. William Rothman, 18, a student at Kingsborough Community College, was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead on arrival after 1 a.m. The other man, also 18, was detained by the police for questioning, but had not been charged. His name was not immediately released. Witnesses said he and Mr. Rothman were friends, but they began to argue at a party on the sixth floor of Sheepshead Bay Houses, an apartment complex over Mr. Rothman's former girlfriend. The two men left a trail of blood and broken glass. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

Before retiring, he was Chairman and CEO of the EDS Global Securities Industry Group. Previously, he was a Senior Vice President of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Incorporated and also spent 9 years in the Operations Division of J.P. Morgan & Co. He was the recipient of the 1998 Ellis Island Medal of Honor, appeared on The Today Show and was quoted in the Wall Street Journal, the New York Times, the Los Angeles Times and American Banker. He was a graduate of Pace University and Harvard Business School's Advanced Management Program. He was also the author of the book, "Securities Operations: A Guide to Operations and Information Systems in the Securities Industry." Shanghai General Motors, a venture between General Motors and China's largest carmaker, the Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation, will start selling the Chevrolet Epica in April, it said in a statement. It did not give a sales goal. General Motors is using models developed by its affiliates under its own brand as it seeks to introduce new models faster in China. The Chevrolet Epica was based on a model developed by G.M.-Daewoo Auto and Technology, in which G.M. has a 42.1 percent stake.

title: ICAHN FILES SUIT IN CHALLENGE TO DRUG COMPANY
description: High River L.P., an investment company controlled by Carl C. Icahn, said it had sued a generic drug maker, Mylan Laboratories, seeking time to nominate candidates to the company's board. Mr. Icahn, who reiterated his $20-a-share offer to buy Mylan, said in a news release yesterday that he was challenging bylaw amendments Mylan announced Friday, under which nominations had to be made within 10 days. His suit was filed in Federal District Court in Scranton, Pa. Mr. Icahn opposes the company's $4 billion bid to buy King Pharmaceuticals. Separately, King restated financial results to account for product returns, an adjustment that threatens to jeopardize the Mylan deal. The changes raised net income by $7.6 million for the first half of 2004, while cutting earnings by $13.9 million in 2003 and by $100,000 in 2002, King said.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T May Be Liable For Phone-Card Fees
description: AT&T might be liable for as much as $500 million in fees related to prepaid calling cards after federal regulators rejected the company's request for an exemption. The cards provide communications services that are subject to fees, the Federal Communications Commission said yesterday. AT&T might owe the government $160 million as a result of the decision, according to the F.C.C. The company said it would appeal. Competitors including Verizon Communications could use the ruling as grounds for collecting as much as $340 million in card-related fees from AT&T. The decision, released yesterday, had been made Feb. 16. "We are deeply disappointed in today's decision," an AT&T spokeswoman, Claudia Jones, said. "In order to reach its desired outcome, the F.C.C. has reversed years of precedent and reregulated enhanced prepaid calling card services."

description: Marvin Traub, who ran Bloomingdale's from the late 1970's to the early 1990's, has joined Mohan Murjani, a former jeans maker, to run a retail development and consulting business in India. The venture, to be called Murjani Traub India, will have offices in New York and Mumbai. Although Mr. Murjani sold most of the stake he held in Tommy Hilfiger years ago, he kept the rights to distribute Hilfiger in India and opened the first of the Hilfiger boutiques last April. The new venture was scheduled to be announced this morning. Mr. Murjani said recently that he planned to expand his licenses in India to include watches, home furnishings, underwear and fragrances. Mr. Traub, who established his own consulting firm after leaving Bloomingdale's in 1991, will offer advice to retailers considering expanding into India, where the number of malls is soaring, a joint press release said. Tracie Rozhon (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Mack Attack
description: Mack the Knife is back, and Alan Cumming, below, is going to be doing the cutting. Mr. Cumming, the Scottish actor who made his name in the United States in the Roundabout Theater Company's revival of "Cabaret," is returning to the scene of the crime as the devilish Macheath in a new revival of Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill's "Threepenny Opera," aiming for an April 2006 opening on Broadway. The production will be directed by Scott Elliott, currently bathing in the success of his revival of "Hurlyburly," and will have two starry female leads: Edie Falco, who will play Jenny Diver, a fallen woman, and Nellie McKay, the precocious pop star, as the impressionable Polly Peachum. Like "Cabaret," "Threepenny," last revived on Broadway in 1989 with Sting as Macheath, will play Studio 54. JESSE McKINLEY

title: Racist incidents jarring the French
KELSO & COMPANY TO ACQUIRE INSURANCE AUTO AUCTIONS
description: Insurance Auto Auctions, which sells salvaged cars on behalf of insurance companies, agreed to be bought by the closely held investment firm Kelso & Company of New York for about $385 million. Insurance Auto's stockholders will receive $28.25 a share in cash at closing, a 26.1 percent premium to Tuesday's closing price. Insurance Auto's largest stockholder, ValueAct Capital, voted in favor of the deal, which the board approved unanimously. Insurance Auto Auctions first sold shares to the public in July 1993, and sales have risen in every quarter since the third period of fiscal 2003. The company is based in Westchester, Ill.

description: A fire tore through a city office containing files from hundreds of criminal investigations inside the Brooklyn Municipal Building yesterday morning, the authorities said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: School Financing Could Widen Deficit
description: The city's budget deficit next fiscal year would widen by $525 million if the State Legislature were to require the city to pay 40 percent of the additional money that a State Supreme Court justice says is needed for city schools, according to a report released yesterday by State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi. The report analyzes Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposed budget for the year that begins in July. It said education financing is one of several issues that could add hundreds of millions of dollars to the city's budget. Gov. George E. Pataki had proposed that the city cover 40 percent of the extra school financing. The city insists the state should cover all of the additional costs. The state is appealing the court's ruling, which determined that the city needs an extra $5.6 billion a year, but left it to the Legislature to determine how to divide the costs. Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARLIANT, SAMUEL
description: BARLIANT--Samuel. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Samuel Barliant of Chicago and Boca Raton, Fla. A Technion Guardian who reached the highest level of commitment to the ATS, the Technion and Israel, and a devoted member of the Chicago Chapter board of directors, he transmitted his profound sense of dedication to his children and grandchildren. These include his daughters, Diana J. Barliant, a member of the ATS Board of Regents, a former national board member, and a vital force in the San Diego Chapter; Barbara Sonnenblick and her husband Paul, active members of the Northern California Chapter, and their daughter Beth; and Laurel Burgess. A lawyer and entrepreneur, Mr. Barliant founded Barliant & Company during the Depression and turned it into a leader in equipment for the food processing industry. He made his first visit to the Technion in 1988 under the guidance of his longtime Chicago friend, past ATS president Leonard H. Sherman. Subsequently, along with his late first wife Dorothy and her mother, he dedicated the Dorothy Turner Barliant/Nathan Turner Dormitory. Later, he was a leading supporter of the Florence and Jack Bellock Southern Region Dormitory and provided generously for the Technion through a major planned gift. Along with his second wife Tania, he was recognized with the Albert Einstein Award, the highest ATS honor. We extend our sincere condolences to Tania, Mr. Barliant's daughters, Diana J. Barliant, Barbara Sonnenblick and Laurel Burgess, and the entire Barliant family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Stephen A. Laser, President Evelyn Berger, Chairman Board of Directors Melvyn H. Bloom Executive Vice President Lawrence I. Richman Chicago Chapter President Kenneth F. Lorch Chicago Chapter Chairman Richard D. Zelin West Central Region Director Edith Mullin, Boca Raton Chapter President

Specialist Maupin, of Clermont County, just east of Cincinnati, is listed as the only American soldier in captivity in Iraq. He was captured after his convoy came under fire outside Baghdad; his captors later released a videotape of him surrounded by a half-dozen masked men. Albert Salvato (NYT)

description: BEFORE he went into government at the World Bank and Treasury Department, Lawrence H. Summers was a star economist. The habits of mind that made him a successful researcher -- including the style and rhetoric that economists use when they talk to each other -- help explain why he is now embroiled in controversy as president of Harvard.

title: Desert Cool, Hot From the 50's
description: WHEN Maria Grasso began shopping for a second home in Palm Springs, Calif., she had never heard of an Alexander house. She knew only that she wanted something with simple lines, a "complete departure" from her Spanish style house in the Hollywood Hills. Like many Angelenos in recent years, she had been drawn to the midcentury look of Palm Springs -- a retreat favored by the Rat Pack -- and to the prospect of a desert place where she could relax and entertain in ways she never had done at home.

title: First Real Challenge in 20 Years for Manhattan District Attorney
description: He is a last link to a fabled political past, to Bobby Kennedy's New York, even to F.D.R.'s New York. Patrician, public-spirited, tennis-playing, Ivy League educated, a naval hero in World War II, Robert M. Morgenthau has served as the Manhattan district attorney, running what is sometimes called the country's premier prosecutorial office, for 30 years. He is 85 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about complaints that the elementary school admissions process in an Upper West Side district favors wealthy white families referred incompletely to a comment by Mark Diller, co-president of the parents association at Public School 87, who said, "We cannot accept this notion that we are somehow out of bounds for trying to find the best schools for our children." Mr. Diller, who spoke at a public meeting on Feb. 15, said he was responding to earlier criticism by an Education Department official that too many parents in the district were trying to avoid sending their children to their neighborhood schools -- not to general allegations of favoritism.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Environmentalist Gunned Down
description: A volunteer patrolling a rain forest reserve near Rio de Janeiro was killed by a shotgun blast Tuesday night, and environmentalists blamed poachers for the killing. Colleagues of the slain man, Dionisio Julio Ribeiro, told Brazilian news services he had been threatened by trespassers in the Tingua nature reserve, part of a patchwork of remnants of Brazil's Atlantic rain forest, 93 percent of which has been destroyed. The killing occurred as federal troops tried to restore order in the Amazon state of Par after the Feb. 12 murder of Sister Dorothy Stang, an American nun working with peasants who had clashed with illegal loggers. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Kahlo and Moore in Motion
description: A cultural exchange between Britain and Mexico will bring to London the first major exhibition of the work of Frida Kahlo (1907-54, self-portrait below) in Britain in more than 20 years and to Mexico a selection of sculptures by Henry Moore (1898-1986). Tate Modern will be the site of the Kahlo exhibition from June 9 to Oct. 9. At the same time, sculptures by Moore, the Briton whose work was influenced by pre-Columbian art, will be shown at the Museo Dolores Olmedo Patio in Mexico City. The Tate exhibition will offer a comprehensive examination of Kahlo's career with more than 70 pieces (including two from Madonna's collection) from the Mexican artist, who began painting after a serious traffic accident in her teens. Lesser-known works, including early watercolors, and paintings from her later life, influenced by Eastern religions, are intended to give a fuller picture of Kahlo's output and worldview. Among the works to be shown will be "Moses" (1945), a synthesis of imagery and symbols from world religions, history and human reproduction, and a marriage portrait, "Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera" (1931). PAM KENT

title: World Briefing | Americas: Paraguay: Interior Minister Replaced
description: Interior Minister Nelson Mora was forced to step down amid growing public outrage at the death of Cecilia Cubas, the 32-year-old kidnapped daughter of a former president. His replacement as the head of the country's security apparatus is Rogelio Bentez, a former mayor of Encarnacin who becomes the fourth person to hold the post in 18 months. President Nicanor Duarte Frutos also fired 32 senior police officials but chose to retain the director of the national police, which was accused of bungling the investigation into the kidnapping last September of Ms. Cubas, whose body was found last week. Larry Rohter (NYT)

description: The Federal Trade Commission, the agency that is charged with enforcing rules on consumer privacy, now estimates that about 10 million Americans become victims of identity theft every year. Part of the problem, the agency says, is that the crime is just plain easy to commit.

He was participating in a mourning ritual as part of Ashura, a holy Shiite festival -- not reacting to results showing that his political alliance had won a slim majority of seats. A second caption for a Reuters photo misstated the reason a Shiite was shown flagellating himself in a Baghdad procession. He was taking part in the same mourning ritual, not celebrating the election outcome.

title: Monmouth Prosecutor's Actions Hurt F.B.I. Inquiry, Officials Say
description: TRENTON, Feb. 23 - As the F.B.I.'s corruption inquiry involving elected officials in Monmouth County intensified in December, federal investigators contacted the county prosecutor, John A. Kaye, and cautioned him not to take any actions that might tip off the targets of their sting operation, law enforcement officials said Wednesday.

title: Urbina's Ordeal Played Out Far From the Field
description: LAKELAND, Fla., Feb. 23 - Ugueth Urbina answered his cellphone on one of those numbing days last September, the kind of days that would keep haunting him for almost half a year, and heard an unfamiliar voice. The man told Urbina that he was with the group that had Urbina's package.

description: Any thought that the leaders of New York's bid for the 2012 Olympics would try to charm the International Olympic Committee's evaluation commission with understatement exploded last night along with the fireworks arcing over Columbus Circle.

title: In This Postpunk Sprint, No Room for Nostalgia
description: "This is a song about being lazy," Barry Hyde of the Futureheads announced during the band's set at the Bowery Ballroom on Tuesday night. Then the song, "A to B," made a liar out of him, or at least its music did. It raced through five different sections before it reached the first verse of lyrics, with more to come; there were vocal harmonies, ebullient clap-alongs, jerky stop-start chords and bits of counterpoint, all racing by in three supercharged minutes.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Ex-President Avoids Charges
description: The Supreme Court dealt a setback to efforts to punish former officials for the murder of leftists three decades ago as it ruled that an international genocide treaty signed in 2002 could not be used to charge former President Luis Echeverra in connection with a 1971 student massacre. Prosecutors said they still held out hope the court would rule in their favor on the question of whether Mr. Echeverra, 83, can be tried for genocide under Mexican law. Mr. Echeverra's lawyers have maintained that the 30-year time limit for charging someone with mass murder under Mexican law has already expired. But prosecutors have asked the Supreme Court to consider three arguments that would extend that limit by several years, and the court has yet to rule on those arguments. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

title: In the Aftermath of War, Reconstructing Their Lives
description: The set of the Unbound Theater's production of "The Workroom" is effectively dark and claustrophobic: a brick-walled garret with the audience just inches from the actors. Jean-Claude Grumberg knows his material well; there's a reason that certain scenes evoke the film "The Last Metro," which Mr. Grumberg wrote with the director Franois Truffaut. The semiautobiographical play is based in part on the experiences of Mr. Grumberg's French-born Jewish mother, who worked as a seamstress during and after World War II. His Romanian father was deported and killed in a concentration camp.

title: Arts, Briefly; Ray Charles Rides the Grammys
description: Never say the Grammy Awards don't affect sales. Albums by Ray Charles and Green Day, right, have jumped to the top of the charts for purchases since the Grammy Awards ceremony on Feb. 13. Charles's posthumously released duets album, "Genius Loves Company" (Concord), which took eight prizes, including album of the year, reached No. 1 on sales of 224,000, a weekly gain of 200 percent, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It is the highest chart position for the album, which was released in August and so far has sold 2.4 million units in the United States, and the only time since 1962 that a Ray Charles album has reached peak position on the Billboard pop album chart. (His classic "Modern Sounds in Country and Western Music" was No. 1 for 14 weeks that year.) Green Day's "American Idiot" (Reprise), a steady seller in recent months, won the Grammy for best rock album and reached No. 2 with 202,000 sales, an increase of nearly 50 percent from the week before. The season's rap blockbuster, the Game's "Documentary" (Interscope), slipped slightly, with 131,000 sales, bringing it down one notch to No. 3. Maroon5, which won the Grammy for best new artist, jumped 13 spots to No. 9 with "Songs About Jane" (Octone/J), selling 78,000 copies. BEN SISARIO

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chechen Charged In American's Death
description: Prosecutors charged another man in the murder of Paul Klebnikov, an American investigative journalist and the editor of the Russian edition of Forbes. The latest suspect is a Chechen identified as Muslim Ibragimov, a spokesman for the Prosecutor General's office said. Mr. Klebnikov was shot outside his Moscow office last year. The authorities have said the murder was related to his journalism, which had been critical of Russia's richest men and, more recently, of a Chechen leader he described as "a barbarian." The investigation has not inspired confidence. Prosecutors previously announced the arrests of three other Chechens, but backtracked on two, saying the arrests were premature. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUE, FRANCIS J., JR.
description: RUE--Francis J., Jr. 83, died February 21, 2005 in Fort Myers, Fl. after a brief illness. He is survived by his wife Rosina and his four children Mary V. Brodhead (Dal), Francis J., III (Sally), Robin and William B. (Maggie); loving grandfather of Farrar, John, Daniel and Douglas Brodhead, Katherine and Jonathan Rue, Rosina Williams and Francis J. Rue, IV and Liam Farrell Rue. He was the son of the late Virginia and Francis Rue and the brother of the late Mary Randolph Rue Farr and the late Virginia Rue Brauns. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and Princeton University Class of 1943. He received his MBA from NYU in 1950. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ex-Chief Of Parents' Group Is Charged

She did not have authorization to write checks from the group's account. Robin Brown, 43, was the president of the United Parents Association of New York City, a coalition of parent groups. She was charged with stealing about $13,000, a spokeswoman for the Manhattan district attorney's office said yesterday. Ms. Brown was charged with grand larceny on Feb. 15 and released from jail after posting $5,000 bail, a Correction Department official said. The case was first reported in The Daily News. Calls to Ms. Brown and the office of the parents' association were not returned yesterday. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Charged In Subway Killing
description: A Washington Heights man was charged yesterday with murder in the shooting death of German Cabrera, 26, whose body was found on Saturday on a subway platform at West 18th Street and Seventh Avenue in Manhattan, the police said. The man, Elio Cruz, 33, of 655 West 190th Street, was charged with shooting Mr. Cabrera in what the police said was anger over his involvement with Mr. Cruz's wife. "We believe it was a love triangle," said Deputy Inspector Bernard Cosenza of Manhattan South detective operations. He said Mr. Cruz, a restaurant worker who had been questioned by detectives on Sunday, was charged after consultation with the office of the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau. Although no gun has been recovered, Inspector Cosenza said, the evidence against Mr. Cruz included surveillance video and statements by witnesses. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

The promoters and the director, John McColgan, said they wanted the 19th-century melodrama to tour to Broadway as well but have yet to confirm details. The play, written by Dion Boucicault in the 1870's, lies between camp melodrama and a buddy action movie, with a lovable rebel hero -- the shaughraun, which means rascal in Gaelic -- who battles the British Army and the nefarious villain trying to steal his mother's land. title: Arts, Briefly; Trouble for UPN Comedies
description: It's been a tough season for UPN's comedies. The network's sitcoms on Monday and Tuesday nights, geared toward an African-American audience, have sharply declined over all since last year, whether because Nielsen Media Research undercounts minority viewers -- a complaint that UPN and CBS have raised, and Nielsen announced this week it is trying to address -- or because the shows have simply become less popular. But what is undeniable is that two of them, "All of Us" and "Eve," have been doing even worse in recent weeks because they are in direct competition with the Tuesday installment of "American Idol." This week's "All of Us" brought in about 2.3 million viewers, and "Eve" attracted about 2.2 million. Comparing those numbers to "Idol" in the same time period (28.10 million) is absurd, but the sitcoms' closest competition, WB's "Gilmore Girls," more than doubled their ratings in both viewers and households. Because of the steamroller that is "Idol," Fox won Tuesday's Nielsen race in all important measures by a wide margin. KATE AURTHUR

title: The Listings; SHANNON HUMMEL AND CORA
description: I was startled, the first time I saw the choreography of Shannon Hummel, by how completely the dancers in her all-female company, CORA, seemed to own the pieces that they performed. And what they performed was often like a vivid, true short story, a mix, perhaps, of Eudora Welty and Elizabeth Bowen. Her pieces, whether solos or group dances, evoke whole small universes of emotions and relationships, both simple and complex. Ms. Hummel's new "Elsewhere," which will be performed by CORA this weekend, addresses the dilemma caused by hope and its propensity for both sustaining and destroying. "Elsewhere" (featuring Julie Betts, above, with Anna Smith) might be a barren wasteland, a lush forest, an ocean or a desert, she has written. The piece itself delves "into the lives we live or fail to live when we focus on what may happen rather than what is." Ms. Hummel began her career performing with companies in Washington and Atlanta before receiving a degree in dance from James Madison University. She formed CORA in 1997 and has helped develop, and worked in, programs intended to bring dance to isolated, often rural communities where exposure to the arts is often limited. In her finely wrought dances, you seem to hear the voices of the anonymous women in those communities, and they are indistinguishable from the big-city voices of her dancers and their New York audiences. (Tonight through Sunday at 8 p.m. at the Joyce SoHo, 155 Mercer Street between Houston and Prince Streets, (212) 334-7479. Tickets: $15.) JENNIFER DUNNING

Arts, Briefly; Selling Ireland
description: Irish culture, coming from an island of five million in half the area of New York State, has long punched above its weight. And the Irish government wants to keep it that way. A new agency, Culture Ireland, will spend $2.6 million this year, with greater sums promised, to promote the national culture abroad by handing out grants and making sure the Emerald Isle is always on the map. "This is an opportunity for Ireland to celebrate its many voices across many countries and continents, to lift up its own diaspora in that celebration," said the agency's chairman, Micheal O Suilleabhain, who is also a composer and academic. The agency's board includes poets and musicians alongside professional arts administrators, but it also has an ulterior purpose: helping trade bodies lure foreign investors to Ireland. The country's cultural exchange with China last year, when dozens of artists and performers visited each partner country, was soon followed by a huge trade mission, and several Irish businesses won lucrative Chinese contracts. Arts, Briefly; Storms at La Scala
description: Barely 10 weeks after it reopened to acclaim after three years of renovation, Milan's legendary opera house, La Scala, is once again in turmoil. Yesterday, the board of the Teatro della Scala Foundation fired Carlo Fontana, the company's general manager for more than a decade, and named its current artistic director, Mauro Meli, in his place. The move prompted Milan's culture commissioner, Salvatore Carrubba, to resign in protest, and La Scala's labor unions have threatened new strikes after forcing cancellation of Tuesday's opening of a new production of Tchaikovsky's "Queen of Spades." The crisis, however, was not unexpected. Mr. Fontana had long been in conflict with Riccardo Muti, above, La Scala's all-powerful music director, over programming. He has also been blamed for the company's financial problems. Officials have estimated its current deficit at $2.6 million, but other reports put it much higher. Last week, board members said they hoped to reach agreement with Mr. Fontana on his early departure; when no agreement emerged yesterday, he was summarily dismissed. ALAN RIDING

title: Unmasking a Chameleon of the Lens

title: So Much Rain, and Southern California Has Never Seen Such Greens

It seems to make no difference to the cattle grazing the coastal pastures that overlook the surf. The oldest barns along the coast highway an hour north of San Francisco show a pale green, like a wash of seawater over the barn wood. The sheep along the fence lines look almost as if they were fleeced with the Spanish moss hanging from oaks along the highway. The light is as variable as the rain and the salt breeze. Moisture catches in the manzanita and sage. Pastures stream with water, and creeks rumble down the cliff face, making for the sea across open beach.

The Listings; SACRED MUSIC IN A SACRED SPACE
description: This series at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola is best known for choral concerts and organ performances, but tonight St. Ignatius will present its first ever piano recital. It's hard to imagine a more appropriate work with which to break fresh ground than "Vingt Regards sur l'Enfant-Jesus" by Oliver Messiaen (above), the remarkable French composer whose music, like the stained glass windows of a cathedral, reflects a deep Catholic faith through an often dazzling array of colors. Messiaen wrote the monumental "Vingt Regards" in 1944, reflecting a new interest in the piano spurred by his contact with Yvonne Loriod, a brilliant young pianist at the Paris Conservatory who would later become his wife. At once Catholic in its faith and catholic in its appeal, the two-hour work consists of 20 brief "gazes" of the infant Jesus, viewed from theological perspectives (the Father, the Cross, the Virgin) and mystical ones (time, the heights, the spirit of joy). It offers a glorious compendium of Messiaen's musical world: chords that pulse with an inner radiance, ecstatic emotions transcribed with the same fidelity as the famous birdsongs that pierce the music's fabric. Most of all there is a deeply sensual (and deeply French) feel for instrumental color. Tonight, the pianist Paul Kim, a specialist in Messiaen, will perform the work in its entirety. He is not widely known in New York, but his bio includes an impressive endorsement from Ms. Loriod herself, who purportedly praised his playing as "perfect in every way." (Tonight at 7:30, Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th Street, (212)288-2520. Tickets: $25; $20 for students and 65+.) JEREMY EICHLER

In the letters, written while Shelley was a student at Oxford, he pretends to be a clergyman as he elaborates on his theories of atheism, which became a tenet of his career as a rebel poet. In one letter he wrote, "Christ never existed. The fall of man, the whole fabric indeed of superstition which it supports can no longer obtain the credit of Philosophers." Shelley and Hogg were subsequently expelled from Oxford after distributing a pamphlet titled "The Necessity of Atheism" to bishops and heads of colleges. Mr. Jackson said, "The owner, who was left the trunk of manuscripts by her next-door neighbors, had thought of selling them in a garage sale before contacting Christie's." The letters are expected to fetch $38,200 to $57,300 when they go on sale June 8 in London as part of a sale of valuable printed books and manuscripts, which will also include a copy of Christopher Columbus's letter announcing his discovery of the New World, printed in 1494, and a copy of Galileo's "Siderius Nuncius" (1610), including the first account of astronomical discoveries made with the telescope.
