title: The Listings; URS FISCHER
description: The ever-irreverent young Swiss artist Urs Fischer is given to big sculptural surprises. For his first gallery show two years ago, he cut a gigantic ellipse out of the back wall of the Gavin Brown gallery, then on West 15th Street, and leaned it against an adjacent wall as if it were a monumental blank thought balloon. For his second show at Mr. Brown's gallery, now on Greenwich Street in the West Village, Mr. Fischer began in a more constructive mode, building a modest but life-size alpine cabin out of sourdough bread, using different kinds of loaves as cobblestone walls, half timbers and shingles, plus expanding foam, screws and a wood infrastructure. Set on a large patch of Oriental carpets, "Bread House," above, was definitely startling. It inserted a slightly barbed bit of Old World sentimentality, wholesomeness and craft into the pristine confines of the art gallery; Heidi's grandfather lived here. But Mr. Fischer wasn't finished. Two weeks after the opening, with the focaccio shingles drying and curling away from their beams, he simply knocked off the entire roof and left it strewn about, like so much sawdust. He also added, as a bit of wildlife, four parakeets that, too young to fly, hop around the interior. The perky tribute to tradition has become a half-ruin in a crunchy desert, a monument to ephemeralness and artistic license, and a disruption of business-as-usual in the art world. After all, even though it is made of the staff of life, "Bread House" is, in the parlance of the 1960's, also made of money, as in "dough" or "bread." Two large inkjet paintings further contrast the Old and New Worlds with montaged images of a tough-looking street in Long Island City and a classic Swiss beer hall, replete with wood paneling, bulls-eye glass and a ceramic stove. The titles -- "A Shovel and a Hole" and "A Novel and Its Novelist" -- seem to sum up Mr. Fischer's basic approach, which is to get beneath the surface of things. Appropriately, tunnel-like networks of thick black lines edged in searing red burrow across both paintings. (Gavin Brown's Enterprise, 620 Greenwich Street, at Leroy Street, West Village, (212)627-5258, through March 5; free.) ROBERTA SMITH

description: IT sounds like a setup: "So Bob Dole, William S. Burroughs and Wilt Chamberlain walk into a bar." These three former Lawrence residents probably didn't share too many Boulevard Pale Ales in the noisy collegiate pubs along Massachusetts Street. Separately, however, each represents a key element of this laid-back university town's vibe. Senator Dole, a former University of Kansas student and namesake of the Robert J. Dole Institute of Politics, embodies the Great Plains values and civic engagement that date back to the town's origins before the Civil War. Mr. Burroughs, the Beat Generation writer and a presence in Lawrence the last 16 years of his life, is the uncontested symbol of its bohemian and creative set. And Mr. Chamberlain, a product of the university's legendary basketball program, remains among the most towering figures in a sport that has obsessed and defined Lawrence for a century. Wife of the late Melvin Moore, M.D., mother of Abigail and Eli, mother-in-law of Lynn, grandmother of Benjamin Wexler and Alyssa and Melanie Moore, sister of Bernice Pohl Feldman. Passed away after a courageous struggle following a long illness. Born in Brooklyn to Elsie Brickner and Dr. Samuel H. Pohl. Educated at the Yeshivah of Flatbush, Herzlia Teachers College and Jewish Theological Seminary Teachers College, graduate of Wellesley College class of 1949 as a Durant Scholar. Vice-president of NYANA, member of the Lion of Judah Society, chair of the UJA-Federation Task Force on Women, member of the Board of Directors of the New York Jewish Women's Foundation, steady volunteer in the annual Passover Outreach Program. Prime supporter of Wellesley College and patron of the arts. Valued congregant of the Hampton Synagogue. She will be greatly missed by her many friends and family. title: Arts, Briefly; Iraq Movie Wins Appeal
description: The Motion Picture Association of America has reversed an earlier ruling and given a PG-13 rating to the Iraq war documentary "Gunner Palace," the film's distributor, Palm Pictures, announced Thursday. The reversal followed an appeal mounted by Michael Tucker, who directed the film with his wife, Petra Epperlein, and Andy Robbins, Palm's head of theatrical marketing, after the association rated "Gunner Palace" R for profanity in January. An appeals board composed of exhibitors and studio representatives voted 9 to 3 to overturn the decision after a presentation in which Mr. Tucker and Mr. Robbins argued that the profanity was not gratuitous in the film's wartime context and that teenagers approaching recruitment age should be allowed an unvarnished view of war's realities. Reached by telephone yesterday in Los Angeles, the two hailed the decision. "The board did its job yesterday," Mr. Tucker said, adding that "they recognized that context is everything" and that "it's about advising parents." Mr. Robbins said: "These are the times we live in. If the military should have unfettered access to our children, why shouldn't our children have unfettered access to the realities of the military?" "Gunner Palace," which follows the daily lives of soldiers stationed in the abandoned palace of Uday Hussein after the fall of Baghdad, will open in limited release on Friday. JOEL TOPCIK

Revenue increased 5 percent, to 4.3 billion, meeting analysts' estimates, helped by new ad campaigns, including 2012 Olympic bids and new business from clients like Unilever. Separately, WPP submitted a proposal to acquire NOP World, a market-research unit that may be sold by United Business Media, also based in London. United Business said it had several potential buyers for the unit, which analysts estimated may be sold for 275 million to 350 million. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Bidder Steps Aside

In withdrawing its bid, Sumitomo acknowledged that it had little chance of overcoming a $29 billion bid from Mitsubishi Tokyo because it was preferred by UFJ's management. Mitsubishi Tokyo and UFJ plan to complete the deal by October and create the world's largest banking group in terms of assets. Todd Zaun (NYT)

The company, based in Marlborough, Mass., will eliminate 100 jobs in the United States, 90 in Britain, and 30 in Ireland, 3Com said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 3Com said in December that it likely would not reach a goal of achieving profitability by the first quarter of fiscal 2006, ending in August.

title: Arts, Briefly; From Dump to Gallery
description: If they weren't in an art gallery, viewers might think they had stumbled across a pile of rubbish. An installation (detail right) that went on view this week at the Serpentine Gallery in London, created by the Turner Prize-nominated artist Tomoko Takahashi, comprises more than 7,600 items collected over 15 weeks from sources like trash bins, garage sales, friends and charity shops. Artificial Christmas trees, toy snooker and pool sets, a Spider-Man toy, wooden garden gates, vintage sewing machines, stuffed birds, a plastic electrical kettle and other objects have all been carefully arranged, to strike a balance between chaos and order, by Ms. Takahashi, 38, who lives in Britain, for the installation, titled "My Play-Station." Anyone who likes something can go back on the last day of the show, April 10, when the public will be invited to take away pieces as the artist dismantles her work. PAM KENT

National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Hurricane Relief Bill Signed
description: Gov. Michael F. Easley signed a bill that provides $247.5 million for damage caused by the remnants of hurricanes that killed 11 people in the state last year. The legislation especially helps parts of mountainous western North Carolina, which were devastated in September by floods and landslides resulting from tropical depressions Ivan and Frances. According to the National Weather Service, tropical depression Ivan killed eight people and a tornado spawned by Hurricane Bonnie killed three; another man drowned in residual rip currents two days after Hurricane Alex hit. The bill provides loans, grants and matching money for federal aid to help homeowners, businesses and local governments rebuild, and also provides for updated flood mapping. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: ROCHE RECEIVES U.S. APPROVAL FOR HEPATITIS DRUG
description: Roche Holding, the Swiss drug maker, said yesterday that it had received regulatory approval in the United States to use its Pegasys medicine to treat hepatitis C in patients who are infected with H.I.V. The Food and Drug Administration cleared the treatment, the first hepatitis drug approved for use in H.I.V.-infected patients, to be used in combination with Roche's drug Copegus. Between 300,000 and 400,000 people infected with H.I.V. in the United States also have hepatitis C.

title: PENSION FUND SUES A.I.G. OVER DIRECTOR NOMINATIONS
description: A union pension fund sued the American International Group yesterday, seeking to force the insurer to allow investors to nominate candidates to the company's board. The American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees said A.I.G. should be required to ask shareholders whether they want to nominate director candidates, according to the suit, which was filed in federal court in Manhattan. In January, A.I.G. denied the union's request to include such a proposal on its May shareholders' ballot. Gerald McEntee, chairman of the union, said the Securities and Exchange Commission had failed to establish a clear standard for all companies. "We have no choice but to seek relief in the courts," Mr. McEntee said in a statement.

World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Homes Burned In Witch Hunt
description: The police in northeastern Limpopo Province arrested 90 youths and said more arrests were likely after a rampage in which 39 homes were burned to the ground, apparently in a fruitless hunt for a witch. The burnings began early Thursday around the village of Giyani and continued until the youths were arrested yesterday. One died in a gunfight after officers tried to stop the crowd from burning one house. Moatshe Ngoepe, the police superintendent in the provincial capital, Polokwane, said the homeowners included traditional healers, traditional leaders and church officials, all apparently denounced as witches before the gang set their homes afire. "We thought this kind of thing was in the past," the South Africa Press Association quoted Mr. Ngoepe as saying. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Older Shows Lose Luster
description: With sweeps continuing, CBS was No. 1 in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49 on Thursday, and its lineup -- "Survivor," "CSI" and "Without a Trace" -- attracted an average of 23.57 million viewers over the course of the night. NBC placed second in both measures, but two veteran shows brought in surprisingly low numbers. For original episodes in the 18-to-49 demographic, "Will & Grace" tied its lowest rating in more than six years, and "ER," with Sharif Atkins, above, had its lowest rating ever. At 9 p.m. on NBC, "The Apprentice" drew 14.11 million viewers, 5.9 million fewer than watched this Donald Trump show on the equivalent Thursday last February. Also at 9 p.m., Fox broadcast a special, "Stars Without Makeup," in place of the poorly performing "Point Pleasant." The switch paid off: 7.37 million viewers witnessed the parade of flawed celebrities, around 3 million more than usually tune in for the tribulations of the devil's daughter on "Point Pleasant." title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Arrests In Fake License Scheme
description: The federal authorities in Cincinnati have charged 15 people, including a State Bureau of Motor Vehicles worker, in a scheme to obtain falsified Ohio driver's licenses or identification cards for immigrants from the Middle East and Africa. At least 6 of the 13 men who received the falsified documents from March to September 2004 are in the United States illegally. In an indictment unsealed Thursday, the Justice Department identified Mohammad I. Shalash, 30, of Cincinnati, as the ringleader of the operation that used Tammy Black, 40, a bureau worker in Cincinnati, to produce the licenses or identification cards, and to sell them to immigrants for up to $300. Ms. Black used expired visas to complete the license applications, court records say. Mr. Shalash remains at large; a judge released Ms. Black without setting bond. Albert Salvato (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Film Museum Must Move
description: The Moscow Film Museum has been served an eviction notice by its landlord, a private company that may have the support of the Oscar-winning filmmaker Nikita Mikhalkov, the museum's director said yesterday. The dispute over location broke out after a private concern bought the building from the Association of Filmmakers of the Russian Federation and demanded that the museum leave its space in the Kino Center "as soon as possible," said the museum's longtime director, Naum Kleiman. Mr. Kleiman confirmed that the museum was being offered alternate space at the Mosfilm studios, but he said the location was far outside the city center and in disrepair. The eviction "harms those who want to see real cinema, not just Russian films but Italian, African, French," Mr. Kleiman said. "We show films that no one else will show. It's a provocation, and we need to defend the museum." He said he believed Mr. Mikhalkov, whose "Burnt by the Sun" won the Academy Award for best foreign-language film in 1995, was on the board of the company that bought the building. Mr. Mikhalkov could not be reached for comment late yesterday. ERIN E. ARVEDLUND

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Executive Changes At Honda
description: The Honda Motor Company said Koichi Amemiya, the longtime head of its United States operation, would retire in June as part of widespread changes in its executive ranks. Honda will promote its head of finance, Satoshi Aoki, left, to replace Mr. Amemiya, 64, as executive vice president, the second-most powerful post behind the chief executive, Takeo Fukui. Mr. Aoki, a 36-year Honda veteran, will serve as chief financial officer, pending shareholder approval of the changes in June. Honda said Koichi Kondo, 58, a managing director with experience in overseas markets, will take charge of Honda's business in the United States. Mr. Kondo was already one of Honda's top executives in the United States. Honda also said it would reduce its board to 21 members, from 36, to streamline decision making. Todd Zaun (NYT)

Although Edith disliked Lawrence for having, she thought, caricatured her brother Sir Osbert in the novel, as the gin took its effect on each of us, I boldly assured her that the offending book was not actually the work of Lawrence but of Truman Capote. He was Executive Vice President and General Counsel of Restaurant Associates Corp. where he helped convert a chain of coffee shops into a group of innovative specialty restaurants, which went public then private again. Klepper negotiated agreements for restaurants in Rockefeller Center, the Seagrams Building (Four Seasons and Brasserie) the Pan Am Buiding, the United Nations, the Metropolitan Opera House, the Metropolitan Musesum of Art. He has been a waiter, economist, statistician, movie producer (the 1954 Robinson Crusoe), and associate professor, and worked for the Department of Justice. He enlisted in the Air Force in 1942 and honorably discharged with the rank of Major. He held degrees from New York and St. Lawrence Universities, Brooklyn Law School, George Washington University, Harvard University and the New School. He was born in Brooklyn and lived at times in Washington and Germany. He is survived by his wife Anne, his daughter, Leslie, his son-in-law; and three grandchildren as well as his sister, Elaine Schulman. title: Roman's Fate (in Six Short Hours)
description: MIDWAY through the Cannes Film Festival two years ago, there began to be a bit of murmur -- to call it buzz would be an overstatement as well as a clich -- about "The Best of Youth," which was being shown outside the main competition. Since it is the custom of journalists in Cannes rarely to refer to movies by their titles, this one, originally made for Italian television and directed by Marco Tullio Giordana, was usually mentioned as "that six-hour-long Italian miniseries." For those few who had seen it, the extravagant running time was a badge of honor; for those who hadn't (like me) it was an excuse. Though the description is perfectly accurate, it seems at once to enlarge the film and to belittle it. Having seen it recently, from start to finish, for the third (and I hope not the last) time, I prefer to think of "The Best of Youth" as a Roman epic.

title: The Picture No-Show

He behaved badly to me over the years, and I do not feel kindly toward him. Must I participate in his bid for posterity by lending him this important portrait? Anonymous, New York Posterity can wait 15 minutes. Or 15 years. That's one of its appealing qualities: it's so patient. If your artist's work is as important and his fame as great as you say, he can endure a delay in this painting's exhibition. His pocketbook and self-regard may suffer; posterity will not.

title: 'The Crisis'
Inside the List
description: JUICED: If you want to sell an addiction memoir these days, the conventional wisdom holds, you'd better be prepared to lay out the lurid details -- the more gruesome the better. (James Frey's book, "A Million Little Pieces," published in 2003, may be the one to beat for a while. It opens with the author missing four front teeth, wanted in three states and covered with "a colorful mixture of spit, snot, urine, vomit and blood.") Koren Zailckas has cannily taken the opposite tack. Her new memoir, "Smashed: Story of a Drunken Girlhood," which enters the hardcover nonfiction list this week at No. 10, is so poised and elegiac that she comes off as the Norah Jones of her plastered generation. No crime sprees, strip club jobs or spooky detox centers here. "Smashed" goes down with a slow, genteel burn. Zailckas, who is 24 and grew up in one of Boston's middle-class suburbs, coolly explains how she began drinking at 14, had her stomach pumped a few years later, threw up a lot, lost her virginity while blacked out and finally got sober at 22. Not a pretty story, but not a Belushi-level meltdown, either. Zailckas's failure to flame out in a more spectacular fashion has bugged some critics. As Rebecca Traister put it recently in Salon: "A reader could easily close the book and say, 'That was her big drunken girlhood? I got drunker than her! Where's my book deal?' " Zailckas got her $150,000 book deal, I suspect, because she is often a terrific writer, and one who knows how to frighten parents. "I haven't met a girl yet who hasn't been interested in drinking," she writes in her memoir. "Every time I've seen a bottle emerge, girls have followed it the way children follow Browning's Pied Piper of Hamelin: with small feet pattering, wooden shoes clattering, little hands clapping and little tongues chattering."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GILLESPIE, ALFRED
description: GILLESPIE--Alfred. Our dear friend, Al, died on February 12 from cancer. He was 80. He was the author of the 1977 novel, "Gilliam Unbuttoned" and of numerous short stories and articles. He was born in Brooklyn, N.Y., on May 19, 1924. From the early 1960s onward, his articles and stories appeared in many magazines. One of his stories, "Tonight at 9:36," appeared in "The Best American Short Stories 1970" and "Redbook's Famous Fiction." Through most of his career, he was promotion manager at a number of magazines at Curtis Publishing Co., Time Inc., Travel & Leisure and Modern Maturity. He retired in 1993. Gillespie the last of six children of Dr. John F. Gillespie, a veterinarian, and Lillian Blankley Gillespie. In World War II he served as an officer-in-charge of an LCT in the Pacific. In 1953, he married Jean Ann Hollis of Ridgewood, N.J. They lived for 13 years in Brooklyn Heights, before moving to Croton-onHudson in 1967. Jean died on December 1, 2004. Their son Kevin now lives with his wife, Eleanor Chin, and their daughter, Emma, in Boston. Messages can be left at 914271-8422. We will be sending out information about a memorial gathering this spring. His memory reminds us of how good we can be.

We drank martinis while she put the finishing touches on a letter to The Times of London; D. H. Lawrence's novel ''Lady Chatterley's Lover'' was under attack for obscenity. Although Edith disliked Lawrence for having, she thought, caricatured her brother Sir Osbert in the novel, as the gin took its effect on each of us, I boldly assured her that the offending book was not actually the work of Lawrence but of Truman Capote. The red-rimmed eyes atop the long Gothic face narrowed: ''Surely the dates are not right.''

In the fall of 2000, Levenson traveled to the South, seeking answers to why African-Americans were acquiring H.I.V. at seven times the rate of whites. This unflinching history profiles a wide range of individuals transformed by the epidemic's sweep: from infected patients and their families to public health workers struggling to contain a crisis compounded by poverty, drug use and teenage pregnancy. Levenson looks at the AIDS epidemic's intersection with region, race and politics, and "artfully threads together the ways in which this horror came to be," Adrian Nicole LeBlanc wrote in the Book Review.

title: What Dean Means
description: Two weeks ago, on the eve of Howard Dean's election as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, his old rival John Kerry -- the same John Kerry who had once been caught hissing "Dean, Dean, Dean, Dean" into an open microphone, in what sounded like an imitation of Jan Brady's "Marcia, Marcia, Marcia" -- sent an e-mail message to his supporters. "Let's welcome Howard Dean and give him the groundswell of grass-roots support he needs," Kerry wrote enthusiastically, urging his followers to contribute to the party. The turnabout here, if anyone really stopped to think about it, was mind-bending. It was Dean, after all, who pioneered the Internet campaign, and it was Dean who had to urge his supporters, the most motivated in the Democratic universe, to accept Kerry as their nominee. And although Kerry emerged as the safer, consensus choice for president, it was Dean, alone among Democrats, who retained the personal loyalty of street-level activists and millionaire donors. Kerry urging his fans to give it up for Dean was like the leader of a warm-up band begging the audience to wait around for U2.

But a month later, Ms. Drosos received bills from the banks that held her mortgage and her home equity loans, both of which were supposed to be paid off from the proceeds of the sale. When she called her lawyers who handled the sale, she said, she was stonewalled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOORE, ELAINE POHL
description: MOORE--Elaine Pohl. June 18, 1927-February 25, 2005. Wife of the late Melvin Moore, M.D., mother of Abigail and Eli, mother-in-law of Lynn, grandmother of Benjamin Wexler and Alyssa and Melanie Moore, sister of Bernice Pohl Feldman. Passed away after a courageous struggle following a long illness. Born in Brooklyn to Elsie Brickner and Dr. Samuel H. Pohl. Educated at the Yeshivah of Flatbush, Herzlia Teachers College and Jewish Theological Seminary Teachers College, graduate of Wellesley College class of 1949 as a Durant Scholar. Activist in Jewish and Zionist causes over the course of a lifetime. With her husband, Elaine held many leadership positions in the Yeshivah of Flatbush, often addressing the students in fluent Hebrew. Active for many years in New York United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies Women's Division, including a tenure as its over-all chairman. Vice-president of NYANA, member of the Lion of Judah Society, chair of the UJA-Federation Task Force on Women, member of the Board of Directors of the New York Jewish Women's Foundation, steady volunteer in the annual Passover Outreach Program. Prime supporter of Wellesley College and patron of the arts. Valued congregant of the Hampton Synagogue. She will be greatly missed by her many friends and family. The appeal of the bags, which range in size from clutches to totes, may lie in the fact that they wittily mix high-end luxury with unabashed trendiness. Ms. Alexander's bags are made in Italy from leather or leather-trimmed linen (the two pictured here are Garden of Love handbags, $1,528 each at Henri Bendel) and are adorned with crystal butterflies, ladybugs and flowers. They possess the heft and handle of an Herms Birkin with none of the fashion gravitas -- perfect for the type of shopper willing to invest in 15 minutes of fabulousness.

United States soldiers needed buttons for their uniforms, so Aaron Benedict of Waterbury started melting pewter pots and pans to mold into buttons. With that, the company was open for business.

Yet she was not with him at the end, nor did she know that her three daughters were in town, gathered round his bedside. As his ability to draw breath slowly ebbed, it is probable that she was at home watching HBO, reading a novel or fixing herself a snack. They were married 47 years -- "all wonderful," to quote my mother, who apparently wasn't counting the last five, when her husband, at 63, became ill with Alzheimer's, her world disintegrated and nothing between them was ever wonderful again.

title: UP FRONT
description: IN this issue, William T. Vollmann reviews a new biography of Pol Pot, written by the British journalist Philip Short. Vollmann, a novelist and journalist who lives in California, has long been obsessed with Cambodia's political and military history; he made his first trip to the country in 1991, while working on "Rising Up and Rising Down," his seven-volume meditation on violence and morality. (The book took him 23 years to write.) "When I first heard about the Khmer Rouge and the phenomenon of people being expelled from Cambodia's cities, it seemed so strange, so creepy, to me," Vollmann said in a telephone interview. "It was difficult to understand why a regime would do something like that." He set out to meet members of the Khmer Rouge, Vollmann recalled, "to try to figure out if they were brilliant, subtle ideologues with an agenda that could be explained, or if they were just simply brutal and stupid."

title: Strike Up the Band in 13/4 Time: Progressive Rock Returns
description: IT'S no wonder progressive rock was nearly laughed out of business when punk rock came along. With its album-length suites and cosmic philosophizing, its quasi-classical pomp and showy instrumental interludes, prog rock was long-winded, pretentious, cerebral, fastidiously technical and decidedly self-indulgent -- all of which suddenly became no-nos as punk attacked all the ways rock had grown hifalutin and out of touch in the 1970's. Prog had been nerdy all along, the province of musicians and fans who could get all excited about a meter change or a dissonant guitar line. And punk destroyed any hopes that prog might have harbored of gaining cachet to match its elevated ambitions.

He is survived by his wife of 25 years Ilse Strauss Russell, his children Marjorie Ann Russell, David, Jr., Sargent (Ellen) and Sara Meling, his stepsons Robert Strauss (Ann), Jeffrey Strauss (Janis) and Daniel Strauss (Cindy). title: Picking Up A Broadway Tab
description: IT'S just like your regular old grocery bill. That is, of course, if your grocery bill included items like hair care, makeup and Teamsters. These are the expenses, large and small, paid by producers on Broadway, where running a big, splashy musical like "Wicked" can cost up to $600,000 a week. The precise breakdown of spending is usually shrouded in secrecy, especially for a show that's still running. "Caroline, or Change," the civil rights-themed musical by Jeanine Tesori and Tony Kushner, closed Aug. 29, and its weekly budget was significantly lower than most musicals. But a look at its itemized expenses shows some of the ways costs can start to pile up. Between cleaning costumes and paying accountants, housing the star and keeping the lights on, "Caroline" needed more than $350,000 to run every week.

title: An Early Lesson in Prada
description: These days, women aren't letting a little pregnancy get between them and their Prada. Chic mothers-in-waiting are now altering their own designer clothes to fit burgeoning bellies -- sewing elastic triangles into hip seams, adding stretch panels to waistbands or lengthening hemlines on blouses. "When I was pregnant, I figured I may never be able to fit into my nice clothes again, so why not alter them?" said Jeanine Lobell, the creator of Stila Cosmetics, who stitched elastic panels into the waistbands of Helmut Lang pants and the seams of Dries van Noten blouses. "When you find a designer you like, you don't want to have to give the clothes up because you're pregnant." For like-minded do-it-yourselfers, the Denim Doctors at Fred Segal in Los Angeles will tailor jeans to fit an expanding girth for a fee of $30, while Liz Lange Maternity sells elasticized, pull-up versions of jeans by labels like Citizens of Humanity and Earl for $175 a pair. Bella Bands -- soft, stretchy tubes for the waist ($25.95 at www.pregnancystore.com) -- can provide wardrobe extensions by letting women wear regular skirts and pants, unbuttoned and unzipped. And Dynasty Tailors in New York City (212-679-1075) and Susie's Custom Design in Los Angeles (323-462-5520) will maternitize clothes with elastic triangles or panels for $35 to $45 a garment. DANIELLE PERGAMENT

title: My Ghetto Days
description: I was 7 years old, a scrawny white kid, and I was standing in front of some 30 second graders, all of them black. One after the other, the boys and girls in the sun-drenched Miami classroom giddily peppered me with questions. What is it like to live in the "nice" part of town? How many swimming pools do you have? Are all of your brothers and sisters white, too? (The girl who asked this last question was roundly hooted by her classmates.) I tried to answer the rapid queries, but I became shy. As the only white person in the room, I felt painfully under scrutiny and downright weird. I might as well have been a snowman. When I began to stutter, the friendly lady teacher told me I could sit down.

And it won't be so easy to block a layup, so there will be more incentive to drive to the hoop. Also, the court is too narrow for these big guys. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BEARE, GENE KERWIN
description: BEARE--Gene Kerwin. Of Saint Louis, MO, died Tuesday, February 15, 2005. He was 89. Born in Chester, IL., he graduated from Washington University with a B.S. in Mechanical Engineering in 1937 and earned his Master's degree from the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration in 1939. Following graduation, he joined Automatic Electric Company in Chicago, left to serve in the Navy as an officer, and returned to Automatic Electric. Climbing the corporate ladder, he eventually became president of international affiliated companies, vice president of operations and director of Automatic Electric International. Following a merger with General Telephone Company in 1959, Mr. Beare moved to Darien, CT., where he became president and a director of Sylvania International, and later, the president and director of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc. Retiring from GTE in 1972, he became executive vice president and director of General Dynamics Corporation, and relocated back to Saint Louis. After retiring in 1980, Mr. Beare served as a director on many boards including Asbestos Corp Ltd., American Research and Development Corp., Westvaco Corp., Emerson Electric Company, Nooney Realty Trust in Saint Louis, Saint Joe Minerals Corp. in New York, American Maize-Products Corp., Datapoint Corp. in San Antonio, and Middlesex Mutual Building Trust in Boston. He is survived by his third wife, Lena May Stetzinger Beare, and two daughters, Gail Kathryn Beare of Pittsfield, MA., and Joanne St. Vrain Beare Sandomenico of Mamaroneck, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRODSKY, IRWIN L. ''IRV''
description: BRODSKY--Irwin L. "Irv", on February 25, 2005, of Hartsdale, NY. Mr. Brodsky was born in Ellenville, NY on December 30, 1933 the son of Harry and Kate (Krilow) Brodsky. He was a 1951 graduate of Ellenville H.S. and a 1955 graduate of Penn State University, School of Journalism, where he was a member of Sigma Alpha Mu fraternity. He married Marcia Dee Samuels in Pittsburgh, PA on February 17, 1956. She died in March of 1974. He was Director of Public Relations for ABC Sports for 27 years. After leaving ABC in 1987, he worked freelance in Public Relations and Publicity until 1995. His clients included, among others, Sports Television International and motorcycle daredevil, Robbie Knievel. He helped introduce Monday Night Football and ABC Sports live coverage of the Triple Crown horse racing and managed publicity and public relations for nine Winter and Summer Olympiads. Mr. Brodsky is survived by his daughter, Susan Owens, sons, Duke Brodsky and Howard Brodsky, his sister, Shirley Kunst, seven grandchildren, and several nieces and nephews. His sister, Evelyn Charnis, pre-deceased him. Funeral services Sunday (today), 1 PM, at Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Donations in his memory to the American Cancer Society - Pancreatic Cancer Research would be appreciated.

title: 'Harold's End': Shell Shock

There may be almost 100 pages here, but they are small in size and somewhat airy. This book has been padded unabashedly: there's an introduction by Dave Eggers, who first published an early version of the text in McSweeney's; an afterword by Michael Ray, LeRoy's editor; a dozen watercolors by the Australian artist Cherry Hood; and nearly four full pages of acknowledgments (Billy Corgan, Gus Van Sant, Tatum O'Neal, Lou Reed and sundry others are gushingly thanked). It's no exaggeration to say it takes more time to read through the press packet than the actual story -- a modest, sometimes affecting tale of a boy, his pet and scatological perversion.

title: Spiritual Offering at the Altar

Moving through these 20 meditations on Friday night, as played by Paul Kim at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, evoked for me Giotto's 14th-century fresco cycle in the Cappella degli Scrovegni in Padua. Both recount Jesus' life in a series of tableaus with bright colors and strong hard edges; both occupy the boundary area between two-dimensional iconography and moments of warm humanity.

title: Arts, Briefly; Accepting the Worst, in Person
description: As Oscar preparations were under way at the Kodak Theater in Hollywood on Saturday night, a very different awards ceremony began at the Ivar Theater just down the street -- the irreverent Razzies, which honor the worst in film. By the end of the evening, Halle Berry, right, who three years ago took home the best actress Oscar for her role in "Monsters Ball," was named worst actress of 2004 for her role in "Catwoman." Crediting her mother with teaching her the value of laughing at herself and being as gracious in defeat as in victory she showed up to receive her trophy, making her the first winner to get the award in person since Tom Green scooped up his Razzie for "Freddy Got Fingered" in 2001. Britney Spears received a worst supporting actress award for her cameo in Michael Moore's documentary, "Fahrenheit 9/11" (a film that received no Oscar nominations). That film also garnered awards for President Bush for worst leading actor and Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld for worst supporting actor. The Razzies, now in their 25th year, are selected by a membership of about 675 and are presented the night before the Oscars. John Wilson, the founder of the Golden Raspberry Award Foundation, told The Associated Press: "We're not trashing Halle Berry as a human being. We're only saying, we're so sorry you chose to do this." CATHERINE BILLEY

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Mad Black Woman' Edges Out 'Hitch'
description: Audiences may have been tired of the funny Valentine "Hitch," the film that was No. 1 at the box office for two weeks, going instead for a revenge comedy in which a woman gets even with a man who dumped her after 18 years of marriage. "Diary of a Mad Black Woman" (Lions Gate), starring Kimberly Elise, Cicely Tyson and, below, Tyler Perry (who wrote the play upon which the film is based), took in $22.7 million in receipts in 1,483 theaters, said Paul Dergarabedian, president of Exhibitor Relations, a box-office tracking company, narrowly beating Sony's "Hitch," starring Will Smith, which landed in the No. 2 slot with $21 million in estimated three-day receipts. (Its cumulative gross to date is $122 million.) The demonic thriller "Constantine," starring Keanu Reeves, came in at No. 3 with $11,820,000 in receipts, and a cumulative gross of $50,752,000. Two other films opened this weekend at the bottom of the top five: the horror film "Cursed" (Miramax) -- from the "Scream" team, the director Wes Craven and the writer Kevin Williamson, and starring Christina Ricci -- opened with $9,563,999 in ticket sales at No. 4; and the Tommy Lee Jones comedy "Man of the House" (Sony) opened at No. 5 with $9 million. description: A small private plane crashed as it took off from an airport in West Milford yesterday afternoon, killing both people on board, according to a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration. The police identified the victims as Harold Botsford Jr., 79, of Ringwood, N.J., a flight instructor, and Ted Fletcher of Franklin Lakes, N.J., a licensed pilot, whose age was not given. They reported engine problems shortly before the plane, a Cessna 182, crashed at Greenwood Lake Airport about 1 p.m. yesterday, said the spokesman for the aviation agency, Jim Peters. The police did not say who was piloting the plane when it crashed. Patrick O'Gilfoil Healy (NYT)

description: "You are here for four years," Henry Rosovsky, who long served as Harvard's dean of faculty, once told a group of students. "The faculty is here for life. And the institution is here forever." The quote became part of Harvard lore: a campus film society promoted a James Bond movie with the slogan, "You are here for four years; Dean Rosovsky is here for life; and Diamonds Are Forever." But it also came to embody, for my generation of students and alumni, Harvard's imperious view of its place in the world.

title: Arts, Briefly; Lives, Illustrated
description: Schoolchildren who loathe reading biographies will soon have a more enjoyable option. Hyperion Books for Children, a division of Disney Publishing Worldwide, and the Center for Cartoon Studies are teaming up to publish biographies in comic-book form for young readers. James Sturm, the founder of the center, located in White River Junction, Vt., will be involved in the first two books of the series. Mr. Sturm and Jason Lutes will write "Houdini," about the noted escape artist. The book will be illustrated by Nick Bertozzi. Mr. Sturm will also write "Satchel Paige," about the flamboyant baseball pitcher (above, a bronze statue of the player at the Negro League Baseball Museum in Kansas City, Mo.), who began his career in the Negro leagues. The artist is to be announced. Each book will be 80 to 96 pages, including background material on the subject's era. The first two books are scheduled for fall 2006, and two new biographies will follow each year. GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

Arts, Briefly; Reality Runway Ratings
description: Last Wednesday, Bravo's "Project Runway" brought in the channel's best ratings for the 2004-5 season, as well as a win for the night among all ad-supported cable stations. An audience of 2.01 million viewers watched Jay McCarroll, below, win the fashion design contest, beating both the favorite, Kara Saun, and the reviled villain of the show, Wendy Pepper. The judging was based on the three contestants' runway shows during New York's fashion week. Among the three, Ms. Pepper, the scheming dressmaker from Virginia, was abolished first by Heidi Klum, the host. "You're out -- auf wiedersehen," said the deadpan Ms. Klum, using her standard elimination tagline. Mr. McCarroll will receive $100,000 to start his own fashion line, along with a spread in Elle magazine. The show began in December and became a word-of-mouth hit: the number of viewers who saw the finale was almost five times the number of those who watched its premiere. Whether there will be a second season of "Project Runway" is unclear: because of the expected split between Disney and Miramax, the show's producer, its renewal is still being negotiated, Mediaweek reported. KATE AURTHUR
